401 of 598 DOCUMENTS


South Carolina Tax Com. v. Schafer Distributing Co.


No. 18497


Supreme Court of South Carolina


247 S.C. 491; 148 S.E.2d 156; 1966 S.C. LEXIS 284



May 3, 1966 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant South Carolina Tax Commission (commission) appealed from a judgment of the Court of Common Pleas for Richland County (South Carolina), which reversed a commission decision that respondent beer company was liable for a tax penalty for selling beer on a Sunday, in violation of § 4-204, Code of Laws 1962 (South Carolina).


OVERVIEW: On a Sunday, when a schedule change meant that 10,000 troops on Shaw Air Force Base needed beer immediately, a base representative reached a branch manager of the beer company, at home after church, and advised him of the emergency. In response, the beer company immediately delivered 500 cases of beer to the base. The commission found the beer company guilty of selling beer on Sunday, but the common pleas court reversed, ruling that the statute invoked had no application to a sale of beer on Shaw Air Force Base, and that the sale in question took place there. On appeal, the commission challenged the ruling that the sale took place on the base. The court affirmed. The court ruled that the offer to purchase was conditioned on delivery to the base that day, and so acceptance of the offer took place on the base. The court noted that whether or not title to personal property contracted to be sold passed before or without delivery of the subject matter depended largely on the intention of the parties and the facts of the particular transaction.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the common pleas court.

 

402 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Moffett v. Traxler


No. 18470


Supreme Court of South Carolina


247 S.C. 298; 147 S.E.2d 255; 1966 S.C. LEXIS 257



March 2, 1966 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff, a taxpayer, individually and representing all others similarly situated, challenged the right of defendants, a mayor and a city council, to proceed with the issuance of general obligation bonds of the city to defray the cost of various municipal improvements. The taxpayer appealed a South Carolina lower court's order upholding the right of defendants to issue the bonds in question.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayer argued that 54 Stat. 83, which purportedly ratified an amendment to S. C. Const. art. II, § 13, was invalid because it was not properly ratified, and no subsequent legislative action was taken to implement it. The taxpayer also alleged that poorer electors were discriminated against in violation of due process and equal protection because voting in municipal bond elections was restricted to those electors who had paid all local, county, and state taxes for the prior year. Affirming, the court held that the provisions of art. II, § 13, requiring that every act or resolution having the force of law shall relate to but one subject that shall be expressed in the title, did not apply to legislative action in proposing and ratifying constitutional amendments. Further, the constitutional amendment in question was self-executing, when read in conjunction with § 47-835 of the Municipal Bond Act. Consequently, no further legislative action was required to relieve the city of the need for a freeholder' petition as a condition precedent to the holding of the bond election. Finally, it was not unconstitutional to require the payment of taxes as a condition of voting.


OUTCOME: The judgment was affirmed.

 

403 of 598 DOCUMENTS


State v. Defee


No. 18418


Supreme Court of South Carolina


246 S.C. 555; 144 S.E.2d 806; 1965 S.C. LEXIS 248



November 5, 1965 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] And it is so ordered.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The State appealed a judgment of the trial court (South Carolina), which granted a motion to quash an indictment against defendants, charging them with violating § 16-414 of the Criminal Code of Laws of South Carolina of 1962.


OVERVIEW: Defendants were charged with violating § 16-414, which prohibited importing, printing, publishing, selling or other wise distributing certain obscene materials. The State argued that the trial court had erred in quashing the indictment. However, on review, the court affirmed the trial court's judgment, adopting its judgment as its opinion. In doing so the court approved of the trial court's finding that § 16-414 had been effectively repealed by § 2 of the Act No. 265 of the South Carolina Acts and Joint Resolutions (1965). The court noted that § 2 of the new act covered all areas set forth in § 16-414 and that the new act changed the penalties imposed. The court then relied on the general proposition that a change of the elements of the offense or of the elements of the penalty, such as the change at issue, constituted a repeal of the prior statute.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's judgment.

 

404 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Pulliam v. Doe


No. 18357


Supreme Court of South Carolina


246 S.C. 106; 142 S.E.2d 861; 1965 S.C. LEXIS 187



June 9, 1965 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff insured challenged a judgment of a trial court (South Carolina), which sustained the demurrer of defendant insurance carrier, which was defending in the name of John Doe, to the insured's complaint in his action to establish liability for damages sustained in an automobile accident with a motorist whose identity was unknown, so as to entitle the insured to recover under an uninsured motorist endorsement of his automobile policy.


OVERVIEW: The insured sustained damages when another automobile ran him off the road. There was no contact between the vehicles. The insurance carrier alleged that S.C. Code § 47-750.34 (1964) (Supp.), which was enacted after the issuance of the policy, applied to the insured's cause of action and prohibited the establishment of liability because there was no contact between the vehicles. The trial court sustained the carrier's demurrer. The court reversed and held as follows: (1) the amendment in question did not have retroactive effect to bar the insured's pre-existent right to establish liability under his policy of insurance against the unknown motorist because there was nothing in its provisions to indicate a legislative intent that it operate retroactively so as to apply to policies issued prior to its adoption; (2) even if the statute had been remedial, it did not operate to destroy vested rights or the obligation of contracts which had accrued prior to its adoption; and (3) the remedy provided by the previous statute, which became a part of the insured's contract of insurance, did not require contact between the vehicles.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the trial court sustaining the insurance carrier's demurrer to the insured's complaint.

 

405 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Moorer v. MacDougall


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of South Carolina


245 S.C. 633; 142 S.E.2d 46; 1965 S.C. LEXIS 308



May 11, 1965 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] After a careful consideration of all of the contentions of the defendant, the motion is hereby denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner inmate filed a motion for a stay of execution pending a decision on his application for a writ of habeas corpus in a state trial court.


OVERVIEW: The inmate was sentenced to death after he was convicted of rape. He had been granted previous stays of execution in order to pursue appeals and habeas corpus relief. After the court directed that the inmate's sentence be carried out, he filed another application for a writ of habeas corpus and then he filed the instant motion for a stay of execution. The court denied the motion after it examined the grounds raised in the inmate's habeas corpus petition. It held that (1) § 16-71, 1962 Code of Laws, the statute under which the inmate was convicted, clearly defined the offense of rape and it was not unconstitutionally vague or uncertain despite the inmate's contention to the contrary; (2) the inmate's contention that his detention violated due process had already been decided adversely to him on appeal and that determination was binding in the instant proceeding; (3) the death sentence given to the inmate did not constitute cruel and unusual punishment because, even though the victim did not die, her life was endangered and threatened by the inmate's actions; and (4) there was no merit to any of the grounds asserted by the inmate and thus, he was not entitled to a stay of execution.


OUTCOME: The court denied the inmate's motion for a stay of execution.

 

406 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Bouchette v. International Ladies Garment Worker's Union


No. 18336


Supreme Court of South Carolina


245 S.C. 586; 141 S.E.2d 834; 1965 S.C. LEXIS 301; 51 Lab. Cas. (CCH) P51,310



April 20, 1965 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, local and national unions, sought review of the order of a circuit court (South Carolina). The circuit court overruled the unions' demurrers to suits brought by respondent employees. The employees alleged, among other things, that the unions interfered with their employment.


OVERVIEW: The employees sued the unions in separate suits for wrongful interference with employment relationship during a strike. The unions demurred, claiming that, because they were prevented from bringing suit as unincorporated associations under South Carolina law, it violated the federal Constitution's 14th Amendment to sue them. The trial court overruled the demurrers, and the court affirmed the trial court's actions. The court held that just because § 10-215, South Carolina Code of Laws, 1962 said that unincorporated associations could be sued in their own name but did not say that they could also bring suit, it did not mean that they lacked the authority to bring suit. The court found the right to bring suit arose by implication upon noting that such associations could be sued, could have agents to receive service of process, could have judgments entered and levied against them, and could register and defend trademarks. Further, their right to sue arose from the fact that if they could only be sued and could not sue, that would deny them equal protection. The court refused to pass on the issue of a demurrer to a cause of action, since the circuit judge had not passed on it.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the circuit court's order overruling the demurrers.

 

407 of 598 DOCUMENTS


State v. Solomon


No. 18330


Supreme Court of South Carolina


245 S.C. 550; 141 S.E.2d 818; 1965 S.C. LEXIS 299; 14 A.L.R.3d 1277



April 12, 1965 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] All exceptions are overruled and the judgment of the lower court affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed a judgment of a South Carolina trial court, which entered a jury's verdict convicting defendant of operating his business on Sunday in violation of Act No. 850 of the 1962 Acts of the General Assembly, specifically S.C. Code Ann. § 64-2 (1962).


OVERVIEW: Defendant, an Orthodox Jew, did not open his business on Saturday in accordance with his religious beliefs. Defendant was convicted of operating his business on Sunday in violation of Act No. 850 of the 1962 Acts of the General Assembly, specifically S.C. Code Ann. § 64-2 (1962). The court affirmed the conviction, holding that the indictment, which was phrased in substantially the language of § 64-2, was adequate to charge the offense with sufficient certainty and particularity to apprise defendant of the nature and cause of the accusation against him. The statute did not violate U.S. Const. amend. I or S.C. Const. art. I, § 4 respecting the establishment of religion or the free exercise thereof because its purpose and effect was not to aid religion but to set aside a uniform day of rest in furtherance of the state's legitimate concern for the well-being of its citizens. The statute was not void for vagueness as defendant was not left to guess as to the prohibited conduct where S.C. Code Ann. § 64-2 prohibited all Sunday labor except work of necessity and gave plain notice that all Sunday labor was prohibited unless it fell within that exception.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's conviction for operating his business on Sunday.

 

408 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Atlantic Coast Line R.R. Co. v. South Carolina PSC


No. 18293


Supreme Court of South Carolina


245 S.C. 229; 139 S.E.2d 911; 1965 S.C. LEXIS 258



January 13, 1965 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant railroad challenged the order of the trial court (South Carolina) affirming the actions of respondent South Carolina Public Service Commission in granting to applicant hazardous materials disposal company a "Class E Certificate of Public Convenience and Necessity" to transport by motor vehicle radioactive materials in intrastate commerce.


OVERVIEW: Application was made to the Commission and after two hearings it issued an order granting the requested certificate to the hazardous materials disposal company. The railroad Company protested. The trial court issued an order affirming the Commission. The railroad contended that the Motor Carrier Certification Law, S.C. Code Ann. § 58-1401 et seq., was unconstitutional in that it was an invalid delegation of legislative power since it did not outline specific elements of proof or standards for the Commission to follow in the exercise of its jurisdiction. The court disagreed and affirmed. The Commission could grant certificates "when the public convenience and necessity were not already being reasonably served." That requirement did not repose in the Commission an unregulated and undefined discretion in exercising the powers granted by the Law. Rather, the test sufficiently limited the Commission's discretion in administering the provisions of the Law. The railroad also alleged that the Commission failed to make sufficient findings of fact and that there was a lack of substantial evidence to support the order. The court found reasonable and ample evidence to support the order.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's order against the railroad, and in favor of the Commission.

 

409 of 598 DOCUMENTS


University of South Carolina v. Mehlman


No. 18280


Supreme Court of South Carolina


245 S.C. 180; 139 S.E.2d 771; 1964 S.C. LEXIS 51



December 7, 1964 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant university filed a condemnation proceeding against respondent corporation under the "Public Works Eminent Domain Law," Chapter 3 of Title 25, § 25-101 et seq. of the 1962 Code (South Carolina) to acquire title to a certain lot of land. It challenged a judgment of the Fifth Circuit Court (South Carolina), which ruled in favor of the corporation, finding that the Eminent Domain Law was void and unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The university sought to acquire title to the land for the purpose of erecting a dormitory to house its students. The corporation argued that the Eminent Domain Law was special legislation, in contravention of article III, § 34(9) of the 1895 Constitution of South Carolina. The lower court found that the Eminent Domain Law was void and unconstitutional. The court reversed, holding that the university's right and power of condemnation was delegated to it by § 22-104(8) of the Code rather than by the Eminent Domain Law. The Eminent Domain Law described the procedure for acquisition of property by condemnation for the purposes therein stated. Section 22-107 of the Code authorized the trustees of the university, in their discretion, to make use of the provisions of the Eminent Domain Law to acquire lands for which funds were provided by the general assembly. Section 22-107 of the Code provided, by reference, a method of procedure for the exercise of the power of eminent domain conferred upon trustees by § 22-104(8) of the Code. Only those parts of the Eminent Domain Law that were of a general nature were incorporated into the adopting statute.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the lower court and remanded the case for further proceedings in accordance with the views expressed in the opinion.

 

410 of 598 DOCUMENTS


State v. Hill


No. 18274


Supreme Court of South Carolina


245 S.C. 76; 138 S.E.2d 829; 1964 S.C. LEXIS 39



November 10, 1964 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was convicted and sentenced in a trial court (South Carolina) on a count charging her with possession of unlawful alcoholic liquor, from which conviction and sentence she appealed.


OVERVIEW: The only evidence against defendant sufficient to support a conviction was obtained by virtue of a search warrant issued solely on the basis of the following affidavit: "Personally comes J. L. Tabor, who being sworn, says that he is informed by Informer and has good reasons to believe The occupants of 303 Haynie Street has concealed on his or her premises, or in his, her dwelling or in a motor vehicle used by him or her at Has a quantity of illegal whiskey." On the instant appeal, the court held that the affidavit did not sufficiently comply with § 4-415 of the 1962 Code of Laws of South Carolina as to the affiant's source of information, the affidavit having been made strictly on information and belief. It held that the affidavit did not show probable cause within the meaning of the Fourth Amendment to the United States Constitution and Article I, § 16 of the Constitution of South Carolina. It noted that the affidavit did not disclose anything that the issuing officer could consider in arriving at a determination of whether there was probable cause, which left the determination of probable cause to the discretion of the police officer rather than to the issuing officer.


OUTCOME: The judgment was reversed and the cause remanded for entry of a judgment of acquittal in favor of defendant.

 

411 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Stone v. Salley


18251


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


244 S.C. 531; 137 S.E.2d 788; 1964 S.C. LEXIS 129



August 6, 1964, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Action by Dairy Commission under Uniform Declaratory Judgments Act to determine constitutionality of certain sections of Dairy Commission Act and to have Commission's order which fixed minimum price of milk and prohibited producers, distributors and retailers from selling below production cost declared valid and constitutional. From an order of the Common Pleas Court, Orangeburg County, Louis Rosen, J., holding that order of Commission was valid and that sections of Code were constitutional in giving Commission power to prevent sales of milk below production cost, retail grocer appealed. The Supreme Court, Moss, J., held that so much of Act as attempted to fix retail prices of milk violated the due process and equal protection clauses of the State Constitution.

Reversed.

BRAILSFORD and BUSSEY, JJ., dissented.



DISPOSITION: Reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent South Carolina State Dairy Commission filed suit to determine the constitutionality of sections of the 1961 Dairy Commission Act, §§ 32-1601 et seq. of the 1962 Code, and to have its order, fixing the minimum price of milk, declared constitutional. Appellant retail grocer challenged a judgment of the Common Pleas Court, Orangeburg County (South Carolina), which ruled that the sections were constitutional and the order was valid.


OVERVIEW: The Commission promulgated an order under the Act, fixing the minimum price of milk and prohibiting producers, distributors, and retailers from selling below the cost of production. Several actions were brought against it, claiming that sections of the Act violated the South Carolina Constitution and that the Commission's order amounted to taking of property without due process of law. The Commission filed suit against the grocer to determine the constitutionality of the sections and to have its order declared valid and constitutional. The lower court ruled in its favor. The court reversed, holding that so much of the Act that attempted to fix the price at which the grocer could sell milk at retail was violative of due process and the equal protection clauses of the Constitution. The business of selling milk at retail was not affected with a public interest, and the regulation of milk prices at the retail level exceeded the police power of the State. The purpose of the price-fixing was to protect the economy of the milk industry rather than the public health and welfare. That was not a proper basis for the exercise of the State's police power.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment.

 

412 of 598 DOCUMENTS


County Council of Charleston v. Felkel


18245


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


244 S.C. 480; 137 S.E.2d 577; 1964 S.C. LEXIS 115



July 23, 1964, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal from an order of the Court of Common Pleas of Charleston County, Clarence E. Singletary, J., temporarily restraining defendants from selling lots or parcels of land in a subdivision of which defendants had filed a plat without first securing approval of county council as required by statute. The Supreme Court, Taylor, C. J., held that trial judge did not abuse his discretion in issuing temporary restraining order.

Affirmed.



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant developers sought review of a decision of the Court of Common Pleas of Charleston County (South Carolina), which restrained further sales of lots in a subdivision that was unapproved by plaintiff county.


OVERVIEW: The developers filed a subdivison plat without first securing county approval for the project. The county brought suit against the developers and sought a restraining order to halt sales of lots in the subdivision. The trial court issued the restraining order and the developers sought review. On appeal, the court noted that temporary restraining orders were used to preserve the status quo pending a full and deliberate investigation. The court found that if the developers were permitted to continue to sell lots while the suit was pending, it was conceivable that irreparable damages might result. The court, therefore, held that the trial court did not abuse its discretion in issuing the restraining order.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the decision of the trial court to issue a restraining order halting further lot sales.

 

413 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Mercury Motor Express, Inc. v. South Carolina Tax Com.


18194


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


244 S.C. 134; 135 S.E.2d 756; 1964 S.C. LEXIS 68



April 9, 1964, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Interstate motor carrier's suit for recovery of income taxes. The Common Pleas Court of Richland County, Louis Rosen, J., rendered judgment for the tax commission and the taxpayer appealed. The Supreme Court, Bussey, J., held that interstate motor carrier failed to sustain its burden of proving that statutory formula, admittedly valid on its face, by which net income of interstate public service corporation is ascertained by taking gross operating revenues within state including equal mileage proportion within jurisdiction and deducting therefrom proportionate average expenses for whole business was, when applied to it, arbitrary, discriminatory or unconstitutional.

Affirmed.



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant interstate motor carrier sought review of a judgment from the Common Pleas Court of Richland County (South Carolina), which was in favor of respondent South Carolina Tax Commission in the carrier's action to recover income taxes that it had paid under protest.


OVERVIEW: Pursuant to the proportionate mileage formula under § 65-256 of the 1952 Code of Laws of South Carolina, the Commission assessed income taxes against the carrier for certain years. The carrier paid the taxes under protest and instituted an action against the Commission to recover the amount. The trial court dismissed the case. The carrier contended on appeal that the application of the statutory mileage formula had the effect of taxing net income that was earned beyond the borders of South Carolina and unrelated to any activities within the state. The court concluded that the carrier had failed to sustain the burden of proving that the application of the mileage formula to it produced an arbitrary, discriminatory, unreasonable or unconstitutional result. There was nothing in the record to even indicate that trucks did not contribute to the carrier's income when they traveled back and forth through South Carolina without picking up or delivering freight.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment.

 

414 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Moorer v. State


18190


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


244 S.C. 102; 135 S.E.2d 713; 1964 S.C. LEXIS 64



March 30, 1964, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Habeas corpus proceeding. From an order of the General Sessions Court, Richland County, John Grimball, J., denying the writ, the petitioner appealed. The Supreme Court, Taylor, C. J., held, inter alia, that evidence failed to show that there had been a systematic limitation or exclusion of Negroes from jury duty so as to deny defendant Negroe equal protection of the law.

Affirmed.



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner, an African-American prisoner, appealed an order from the General Sessions Court, Richland County (South Carolina), which denied his petition for a writ of habeas corpus. The prisoner claimed that he had been denied the equal protection of the law because there had been a systematic limitation or exclusion of African-Americans from jury duty in Dorchester County, where he had previously been convicted of rape.


OVERVIEW: The prisoner was convicted of rape. He later petitioned for a writ of habeas corpus, which was denied. On appeal, the court affirmed. The court found that African-Americans had not been systematically excluded by reason of their race from the grand and petit juries of Dorchester County in 1962, the year that the prisoner was convicted. All registered male electors were potential jurors. There was testimony that in 1962, 2,700 to 2,800 white males and 250 to 300 African-American males were registered. A minimum of two-thirds of the eligible male electors were selected for the jury list each year, and well over two-thirds of the eligible African-American voters were included. Thus, the evidence did not show a systematic limitation or exclusion of African-Americans from jury duty. The prisoner's second arraignment in the presence of his counsel cured any error that might have occurred when he was arraigned without counsel two days before. Although no attorney representing the prisoner was present at a preliminary hearing where the warrant was read and the seriousness of the charge explained, the preliminary hearing was not a critical stage of the proceedings.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the general sessions court's decision.

 

415 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Grey v. Vaigneur


18177


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


243 S.C. 604; 135 S.E.2d 229; 1964 S.C. LEXIS 162



March 9, 1964, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Action for declaratory judgment. The Common Pleas Court, Jasper County, W. L. Rhodes, Jr., J., rendered judgment and an appeal was taken. The Supreme Court, Lewis, J., held that the constitution permits a county to issue bonds to assist a coextensive school district in construction of public school facilities, and that the statute authorizing Jasper County to sell bonds of county in amount of $ 50,000.00 and turn proceeds over to coextensive school district for school improvement program is not unconstitutional on any theory that the bonded indebtedness of the school district will exceed its debt limitation.

Affirmed.



DISPOSITION: Exceptions overruled and judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant brought an action against respondents, the members of a County Board of Commissioners, seeking a declaratory judgment that Act No. 570 of the Acts of 1963 (South Carolina) violated the limit in S.C. Const. art. 10, §§ 5, 6 on a county's authority to issue bonds for educational purposes. The Common Pleas Court, Jasper County (South Carolina) rendered judgment for respondents, and appellant sought review.


OVERVIEW: The school district proposed an improvement program costing $ 800,000, but the eight-percent constitutional debt limitation restricted its authority to issue bonds to $ 300,000. Act No. 570 of the Acts of 1963 (South Carolina) authorized the county to sell bonds in the amount of $ 500,00 and turn the proceeds over to the school district. Because the duty of operating schools was vested in the district rather than the county, appellant argued that the legislation violated S.C. Const. Art. 10, § 5, which provided that a county could only assess and collect taxes for corporate purposes, and S.C. Const. art. 10, § 6, which restricted the purposes for which counties could issue bonds. In upholding the constitutionality of Act No. 570, the court ruled that the General Assembly could authorize a county to raise funds so long as they were spent on a proper purpose. Because both the school district and county could raise funds for educational purposes, the choice of governmental unit was a matter of legislative policy. As the county and school district were distinct corporate entities, the act did not transgress the school district's constitutional debt limit.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the trial court.

 

416 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Bob Jones University, Inc. v. Greenville


18139


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


243 S.C. 351; 133 S.E.2d 843; 1963 S.C. LEXIS 53



December 11, 1963, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Action attacking validity of zoning ordinance amendment which would permit retail use in former residential area near university. The Common Pleas Court, Greenville County, James Hugh McFaddin, J., denied relief, and university appealed. The Supreme Court, Moss, J., held that evidence supported finding that amendment was not unreasonable.

Affirmed.

BUSSEY, J., dissented.



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant university sought review of a decision by the Common Pleas Court, Greenville County (South Carolina), which denied relief to the university in the university's action against respondents, city, city manager, and building commissioner, attacking the validity of a zoning ordinance amendment, which would have permitted retail use in the former residential area near the university.


OVERVIEW: The university contended that the master erred in not having identified and separately reported the evidence he ruled incompetent from that which he ruled competent. The court concluded that the rezoning of the property was not spot zoning because the property immediately to the west had been rezoned so that a shopping center could be built thereon. The rezoning merely expanded an existing commercial area. The master and the trial court concurred that the general welfare of the community would be advanced by reclassifying the property from residential to commercial. The court found no merit in the contention of the university that the rezoning ordinance amounted to a taking of its property for a private or public use without compensation therefor, and that it had been deprived of due process and the equal protection of the laws in violation of the state and federal constitutions. The court determined that the university had not met the burden of establishing that it had been prejudiced by the master's failure to expressly rule on objections to the evidence. Thus, the court overruled all of the exceptions of the university and the affirmed the judgment of the trial court.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the trial court, which denied relief to the university in the university's action attacking validity of a zoning ordinance amendment, which would have permitted retail use in former residential area near the university.

 

417 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Miller v. Farr


18138


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


243 S.C. 342; 133 S.E.2d 838; 1963 S.C. LEXIS 52



December 10, 1963, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Declaratory judgment action by resident taxpayer and qualified elector against school officials and others to determine constitutionality of statute authorizing issuance of bonds by school district of Union County without first submitting question to electors. The Common Pleas Court, Union County, Bruce Littlejohn, J., entered judgment adverse to taxpayer-elector, and taxpayer-elector appealed. The Supreme Court, Moss, J., held that constitutional amendment increasing debt limitation and requiring voter approval for incurrence of bonded debt as to Union school district No. 11, Union County, did not perpetuate district No. 11 as an entity and was not applicable to school district of Union County, which was a consolidation of several districts including district No. 11, and, therefore, school district of Union County could issue bonds under statute authorizing issuance by district without an election.

Judgment affirmed.



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff taxpayer appealed an order of the Common Pleas Court of Union County (South Carolina), which granted judgment in favor of defendant school officials in an action to determine the constitutionality of a statute which authorized the issuance of bonds by the school district without first submitting the question to the voters.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayer filed an action against school officials to determine the constitutionality of Act No. 667, 53 Stat. 1497, of the Acts of the General Assembly for 1963. The act allowed the school board of district number 11 to issue general obligation bonds without submitting the question to the qualified electors of the school district number 11. The taxpayer contended that the Act violated the provisions of an amendment to S.C. Const. art. X, § 5(5). The county had been divided into a number of school districts. Under the Act, all of the districts were consolidated into one district. The taxpayer argued that under the amendment the electors were entitled to vote upon any bond issuance, and that the Act was subject to such amendment. The trial court granted judgment in favor of the school officials and the taxpayer appealed. The court affirmed and held that the constitution was not applicable to the school district and that it could, as authorized by the 1963 Act, issue bonds of said school district under the conditions and limitations imposed by that Act. Under the constitution the school districts had no permanent existence and the general assembly had plenary power to consolidate.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the trial court.

 

418 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Charleston v. Jenkins


18120


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


243 S.C. 205; 133 S.E.2d 242; 1963 S.C. LEXIS 29



November 11, 1963, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Prosecution of restaurant owner for violation of city ordinance by permitting consumption of beer in commercial establishments between 1:30 A.M. and 7:00 A.M. The General Sessions Court, Charleston County, W. L. Rhodes, Jr., J., sustained the conviction and the owner appealed. The Supreme Court, Moss, J., held that the city ordinance was not in conflict with the state law which only prohibited Sunday beer sales but was a reasonable, proper and valid exercise of municipality's police power and that evidence that beer was being consumed in restaurant at 2:15 A.M. in violation of the ordinance established the owner's criminal liability therefor.

Affirmed.



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of a judgment of the General Sessions Court, Charleston County (South Carolina), which sustained his conviction for violating § 3-11, 1952 Code of the City of Charleston, South Carolina. A municipal court had convicted defendant for violating § 3-11 by permitting consumption of beer in commercial establishments between 1:30 A.M. and 7:00 A.M.


OVERVIEW: Defendant filed motions to quash and dismiss the warrant charging him with violating § 3-11 because it was inconsistent with § 4-204 of the Code of Laws of South Carolina (1962), he had a right under § 4-204 to sell beer at all hours except between 12:00 o'clock on Saturday night and sunrise Monday morning, and because § 3-11 of the Charleston Code was an unreasonable exercise of the police power of the city because it diminished the privilege guaranteed to him by § 4-204 of the South Carolina Code. The municipal court refused the motions to quash and dismiss, and such was affirmed by the circuit court. Affirming, the court held that although § 3-11 of the Charleston Code was broader in scope and application than § 4-204 of the South Carolina Code because it prohibited the consumption of beer in a place of business engaged in the sale of beer between the stated hours, § 3-11 of the Charleston Code was not in conflict with § 4-204 of the South Carolina Code, as it was a reasonable, proper, and valid exercise of the municipality's police power. The court also ruled that evidence that beer was consumed at 2:15 A.M. at defendant's restaurant established his criminal liability.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed.

 

419 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Nolletti v. Nolletti


18096


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


243 S.C. 20; 132 S.E.2d 11; 1963 S.C. LEXIS 8



July 11, 1963, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Action by wife for divorce on ground of desertion ap-instituted approximately one month after alleged desertion. The County Court, Richland County, Legare Bates, County Judge, denied divorce and wife appealed. The Supreme Court, Lewis, J., held that statute authorizing divorce for desertion for period of one year requires proof of desertion for period of at least one year prior to commencement of action and relates to degree or extent of proof required and statute was not in violation of constitutional provision authorizing divorce on grounds of desertion on theory that statute prescribed condition to granting of divorce.

Affirmed.



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant wife sought review of a decision from the County Court of Richland County (South Carolina), which entered judgment in favor of respondent husband in the wife's action for divorce on the ground of desertion under § 20-101(2) of the 1962 Code of Laws (South Carolina).


OVERVIEW: The wife sought a divorce on the ground of desertion approximately one month after the desertion. The wife conceded that she was not entitled to a divorce under § 20-101(2) because the period of desertion had not continued for one year prior to the commencement of the action. The wife asserted that the legislature was without power to place a time limitation on the period of desertion in view of S.C. Const. art. 17, § 3. The trial court sustained the constitutionality of the statute and denied the divorce. On appeal, the court agreed with the trial court that § 20-101(2) of the 1962 code of Laws (South Carolina), in no way contravened, S.C. Const. art. 17, § 3, and was a valid exercise of legislative power. Because the legislature had plenary power in legislative matters it might enact any law relating to the subject of divorce not prohibited by the constitution. The statute was designed to safeguard the institution of marriage in furtherance of public policy. Art. 17, § 3 did not negative the exercise of the legislative power under attack. Under those circumstances the court would not hamper the legislative effort by resort to arbitrary rules of constitutional construction.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's judgment.

 

420 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Glens Falls Ins. Co. v. Columbia


18052


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


242 S.C. 237; 130 S.E.2d 573; 1963 S.C. LEXIS 85



April 10, 1963, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Action by insurance company against city to recover allegedly excessive business license taxes paid under protest. The Common Pleas Court, Richland County, John Grimball, J., granted motions to strike certain defenses and the city appealed. The Supreme Court, Lewis, J., held that construction placed by city upon the business license tax statute was contrary to clear and plain meaning of the statute and was irrelevant even though the taxpayers had in previous years acquiesced to the levy, and that the statutory classification differences and reasonably related to objects of the legislation.

Affirmed.



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant city sought review of the order of the Common Pleas Court, Richland County (South Carolina). The common pleas court ordered portions of the city's responsive pleadings struck. The case involved separate actions by plaintiff insurance companies to recover business license taxes paid, allegedly in excess of § 47-407 of the 1952 Code of Laws.


OVERVIEW: Two insurance companies each operated several agencies in the city. Under § 47-407 of the 1952 Code of Laws, the city could only levy a maximum of $ 2,500 in business license taxes against the companies. However, the city levied a greater sum against each on the theory that each agency was a separate company. The companies paid the taxes under protest, then sued to recover the excess. The common pleas court struck a portion of the city's defensive pleadings. The court affirmed. The court held that the common pleas court did not err in striking the city's allegation that the tax was imposed based on an agreement between the parties. The city tax ordinance was not ambiguous, so there was no ground for admitting evidence that the companies had agreed to pay more taxes in prior years. Also, § 47-407 was not unconstitutional. Its classification differences between towns based on population was reasonably related to its object. Finally, § 47-407 was not special legislation in violation of Article III, § 34, Subdivision IX of the South Carolina Constitution. Therefore, the common pleas court did not err in striking the pleading alleging the statute's unconstitutionality.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order of the common pleas court.

 

421 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Knight v. Hollings


18027


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


242 S.C. 1; 129 S.E.2d 746; 1963 S.C. LEXIS 60



February 12, 1963, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Action for declaration that statute was unconstitutional as special legislation. The Common Pleas Court, Dorchester County, Louis Rosen, J., entered an order overruling demurrer on ground that the complaint failed to state a cause of action and an appeal was taken. The Supreme Court, Legge, Acting J., held that statute providing that all roads designated for hard surfacing in state highway secondary construction program within specified county in any fiscal year were to be selected from a list submitted in writing by the county board of directors and the county road supervisor was not within protection of constitutional amendment permitting special laws concerning laying out, opening, altering or working roads or highways, and statute was unconstitutional within constitutional provision prohibiting special legislation where a general law could be made applicable.

Affirmed.



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant government officials sought review of a judgment of the Common Pleas Court, Dorchester County (South Carolina), which overruled their demurrer to respondent citizen's action for a declaration that certain special legislation was unconstitutional and prohibited under Article III, § 34, of the Constitution of 1895.


OVERVIEW: The citizen sought a declaration that a certain legislative enactment relating to the hard-surfacing of state highways was unconstitutional. He contended that the act was unconstitutional as special legislation and was thus prohibited under Article III, § 34, of the Constitution of 1895, which provided that where a general law could be made applicable, no special law was to be enacted. The trial court overruled the government officials' demurrer to the action and they appealed, contending that the citizen's complaint failed to set forth facts constituting a cause of action. The court held that (1) the clear intention of the framers of the state constitution was to prohibit the enactment of special laws in all cases where a general law could be made applicable; (2) the officials' contention that an amendment to the constitution enabled special legislation allowing county officials to control the hard-surfacing of state highways was without merit because the special legislation on the subject matter of the challenged act was not within the protection of the constitutional amendment; and (3) the challenged act was prohibited by the state constitution.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's judgment.

 

422 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Columbia v. Putnam


17970


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


241 S.C. 195; 127 S.E.2d 631; 1962 S.C. LEXIS 28



October 4, 1962, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] The state manager of a casualty company was convicted in the County Court of Richland County, John W. Crews, County Judge, of violating business and professional license ordinance of city, and the state manager appealed. The Supreme Court, Taylor, C. J. held that ordinance setting amount of license fees on percentage of gross premiums collected by casualty companies was valid, since one casualty company was treated equally with the others in the same class; fact that one class might pay more proportionately than others did not make license fee unreasonable arbitrary.

Affirmed.

BUSSEY, J., dissented.



DISPOSITION: Exceptions dismissed and order appealed from affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of an order of the County Court of Richland County (South Carolina), which convicted him of violating a business and professional license ordinance, Columbia's City Ordinance A69-3 (South Carolina).


OVERVIEW: Defendant was a state manager of a casualty insurance company. Ordinance 69-3 required defendant to pay a license fee based on gross premiums collected through offices or agents in the city or collected on policies written of city property. Defendant failed to procure such a license. Defendant claimed that the ordinance was discriminatory, arbitrary, and unreasonable as applied to the company because there was no maximum amount imposed by the ordinance as limited by § 47-407, Code of Laws of South Carolina, 1952, as amended. On appeal, the court held that no maximum amount had to be set forth as any ordinance passed under § 47-407 was controlled by the provisions set forth in the Code. The court further determined that an ordinance setting the amount of license fees on a percentage of gross premiums was not invalid, and the fact that one class could pay more proportionately than other classes did not of itself make the license fee unreasonable or arbitrary since this was largely within the discretion of City Council.As a result, defendant was properly convicted under Columbia's City Ordinance A69-3 (South Carolina).


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's order.

 

423 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Ellison v. Cass


17959


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


241 S.C. 96; 127 S.E.2d 206; 1962 S.C. LEXIS 16



September 4, 1962, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Action for determination of whether city council could validly grant permit for construction of proposed overhangs for parking facilities. The Common Pleas Court of Greenville County, J. Robert Martin, Jr., J., rendered judgment upon conclusion that the act purporting to convey permission for such was unconstitutional and an appeal was taken. The Supreme Court, Bussey, J., held that statute authorizing construction of parking facilities encroaching upon or projecting over public sidewalks, precluding encroachment upon or projection over state highway system except with respect to facilities constructed or in process of construction at time of passage of act, was, with respect to encroachment over state highways, unconstitutional as special legislation to allow construction of specific facility in one city, and as history of legislation led to conclusion that no part of act would have been passed except for purpose of allowing such construction, act was not severable but entire act was unconstitutional.

Affirmed.



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant permit applicant sought review of a judgment of the Common Pleas Court of Greenville (South Carolina), which found for respondents, a mayor and a city council, in ruling that Act No. 329 of the 1961 General Assembly of South Carolina (Act), 52 St. at Large, p. 553, was unconstitutional, so a permit could not be issued to the applicant to erect a building for parking vehicle where it would overhang a street in the state highway system.


OVERVIEW: This action was commenced for a determination of whether or not the city would be in violation of law if it allowed the applicant to proceed with the proposed building. The lower could found that the Act was unconstitutional under the provisions of Article IV, § 2, and the Fourteenth Amendment of the Constitution of the United States of America, as well as Article I, § 5 and Article III, § 34 (IX) of the Constitution of the State of South Carolina. The Act purported to give the municipality authority to grant permits for parking facilities although they might encroach on a public sidewalk. The parking facility for which the permit was sought was the only one is issue when the legislation was passed. On review, the court agreed with the analysis and affirmed. Because the Act was special legislation and it was unconstitutional, there was no change of condition which would allow the city to grant a permit to the applicant. There was no severable portion of the Act; it was entirely unconstitutional. It would be unlawful to allow the applicant to erect a parking facility that would encroach on a public highway.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment.

 

424 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Florence v. George


17955


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


241 S.C. 77; 127 S.E.2d 210; 1962 S.C. LEXIS 17



August 20, 1962, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] The defendants were convicted in the General Sessions Court of Florence County, G. Badger Baker, J., of violation of ordinance prohibiting staging of parade on public streets without obtaining permit from chief of police, and the defendants appealed. The Supreme Court, Bussey, J., held that ordinance violated First and Fourteenth Amendments to federal Constitution and provisions of State Constitution governing freedom of speech, privileges and immunities, and protection of laws, where ordinance contained no preamble, explanation, or qualifying words whatever.

Reversed and remanded.



DISPOSITION: Reversed and remanded.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants appealed the judgment of the General Sessions Court of Florence County (South Carolina), which convicted them of violation of a city ordinance prohibiting the staging of a parade on public streets without obtaining a permit from the city chief of police.


OVERVIEW: Defendants were found guilty of violating Article 5, § 47 of the Ordinances of the City of Florence, South Carolina, which prohibited the staging of any parade upon the public streets of the city without first obtaining a permit therefor from the chief of police. They appealed, arguing that the ordinance violated Article I, §§ 4 and 5, Constitution of the State of South Carolina, and the First and Fourteenth Amendments of the Constitution of the United States. Defendants contended that the ordinance made the peaceful enjoyment of the right of freedom of speech and assembly upon the public streets of the city contingent on the uncontrolled will or whim of the chief of police. The court agreed, finding no language in the ordinance that warranted it in drawing any implication therefrom in favor of the ordinance's constitutionality. Without any preamble, explanation, or qualifying words whatsoever, it vested the absolute control of parades in the chief of police. The court rejected the contention that defendants, not having applied for a permit, could not be heard to challenge the constitutionality of the ordinance.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the circuit court's judgment and remanded the case for entry of judgment in favor of defendants.

 

425 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Distin v. Bolding


17943


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


240 S.C. 545; 126 S.E.2d 649; 1962 S.C. LEXIS 129



July 17, 1962, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Declaratory judgment action to determine constitutionality of statute creating public service district to construct and operate sewage disposal facilities. The Common Pleas Court, Richland County, John Grimball, J., rendered judgment favorable to district and appeal was taken. The Supreme Court, Moss, J., held that under statute to effect that property owner must be given notice and provided with opportunity to be heard, before making any sewer connection charge or sewage disposal service charge which would become lien upon property, and providing that property owner, who is aggrieved by action taken by public service commission, may proceed by certiorari for court review, no property owner would be deprived of his property without due process of law.

Affirmed.



DISPOSITION: Exceptions overruled and order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant taxpayers sought review of the decision of the Common Pleas Court, Richland County (South Carolina), which found in favor of respondents, commissioners and state in the action brought under the Uniform Declaratory Judgments Act (Act), S.C. Code Ann. § 10-2001 et seq., (1952) challenging the constitutionality of 1960 S.C. Acts 2803.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayers argued that the Act creating the Public Service District (District) was unconstitutional. The taxpayers argued that the General Assembly could not delegate through the Act, police powers to the District enabling it to adopt regulations requiring all persons owning property within the District to connect that property to, and use the public sewer system, that the General Assembly did not have the power to authorize the District to impose a special charge or assessment on property owners utilizing the public sewer system which would constitute a lien upon their property, and that the Act did not provide for adequate public hearings prior to the imposition of the assessment for sewer services. The court concluded that: (1) the right to create special purpose districts by special acts included necessarily the incidental right to provide methods for financing projects committed to them, whether in the manner of an ad valorem tax or otherwise; and (2) the hearing provided for each property owner, after due notice, and before the imposition of any assessment, meets the requirement of due process under the state and federal Constitutions.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed in the challenge of the constitutionality of the Act.

 

426 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Hampton v. Dodson


17940


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


240 S.C. 532; 126 S.E.2d 564; 1962 S.C. LEXIS 126



July 5, 1962, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Action to enjoin county officials from proceeding with real estate assessment program in School District No. 1 of Richland County. The Common Pleas Court, Richland County, William L. Rhodes, Jr., J., affirmed findings of fact and conclusions of law, with certain modifications, on part of master and dismissed complaint and appeal was taken. The Supreme Court, Bussey, J., held that taxpayers failed to prove that they had been or were about to be injured as result of statutes providing for reassessment of property in District or as result of anything that was being done by officials pursuant to such statutes.

Affirmed as to result.



DISPOSITION: Affirmed as to result.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant taxpayers sought review of a decision of the Common Pleas Court, Richland County (South Carolina), which dismissed their action to enjoin respondent public officials from proceeding with a real estate tax assessment program in a school district.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayers sought an injunction prohibiting the public officials from proceeding with a real estate tax reassessment program. They challenged the constitutionality of Acts Nos. 952, 968, and 976 of the 1958 Acts of the General Assembly of South Carolina, which addressed inequities with respect to the assessment of real estate taxes within a school district. The action was referred to a master, who recommended dismissal. On exceptions to the master's report, the trial court affirmed the master's findings of facts and conclusions of law and dismissed the action. The taxpayers sought review, and the court affirmed the dismissal of the action. The taxpayers' exceptions challenged the constitutionality of the acts on every conceivable constitutional ground. However, the taxpayers failed to prove how they had been or were about to be injured as a result of any of the challenged legislative acts or anything that was being done by the public officials pursuant to those acts. One whose rights were not invaded and injuriously affected by an act could not question its constitutionality. Before the taxpayers could assail these laws as unconstitutional, they were required to show standing.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the dismissal of the taxpayers' action to enjoin the public officials from completing a real estate tax assessment.

 

427 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Ruggles v. Padgett


17936


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


240 S.C. 494; 126 S.E.2d 553; 1962 S.C. LEXIS 125



June 21, 1962, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Action under the Declaratory Judgments Act to determine the constitutionality of statutes intended to furnish a method for establishment and financing of a public sewage disposal system for the Hanahan Public Service District. From an adverse judgment in the Common Pleas Court of Berkeley County, Clarence E. Singletary, J., the plaintiffs appealed. The Supreme Court, Moss, J., held that the statutes are valid.

Judgment affirmed.



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff taxpayers brought an action under the Uniform Declaratory Judgments Act, S.C. Code § 10-2001 et seq., (1952) to determine the constitutionality of certain provisions of two statutes intended to furnish a method for the establishment and financing of a public sewage disposal system for defendant public service district, and appealed an order of the Common Pleas Court of Berkeley County (South Carolina) in favor of the district.


OVERVIEW: After the legislature passed legislation authorizing the district to construct a sewer system and to contract with a water commission for the joint collection of charges, the taxpayers sought a declaratory judgment that the legislation was unconstitutional. In affirming the dismissal of the taxpayers' declaratory judgment action, the court stated that it did not think that the effort to remove the unsanitary conditions prevailing in the territory by special legislation was obnoxious to S.C. Const. art. III, § 34(9). There was no attempt to delegate to any local agency the power to enact penal ordinances. The delegation of power was limited to the adoption of reasonable regulations which were enforceable by application to any court of competent jurisdiction for the exercise of mandatory injunctions or other remedial orders. If any regulation was adopted which was generally unreasonable the court would not enforce it. Since the sewer charge was for a service rendered, and did not constitute an assessment, no hearing had to be provided for property owners before the imposition of the charge. Water service could be disconnected if the sewer charge was not paid.


OUTCOME: The court overruled all exceptions noted by the taxpayers, and affirmed the order dismissing their declaratory judgment action seeking to declare the actions of the district to be in violation of the South Carolina Constitution.

 

428 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Young v. Wiggins


17934


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


240 S.C. 426; 126 S.E.2d 360; 1962 S.C. LEXIS 121



June 15, 1962, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Suit by property owners to enjoin directors of Watershed Conservation District from condemning certain lands. The Common Pleas Court, Florence County, G. Badger Baker, J., granted an injunction, and the officers and directors of the Watershed District and others appealed. The Supreme Court, Brailsford, J., held that impounding of water for agricultural benefit of those who owned lands bounding on a proposed lake which would be surrounded by privately owned property with no provision for access or other use by landowners in the watershed or by the public and which was conceived as a private project to be accomplished by a private treaty among neighboring landowners for their private benefit, did not constitute a "public use" and watershed district did not have authority to condemn land over objection of certain property owners.

Affirmed.



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In an action by appellee property owners to enjoin appellants, directors of the Watershed Conservation District (the Directors) from condemning certain lands, the Common Pleas Court of Florence County (South Carolina) granted an injunction preventing such action. The Directors appealed.


OVERVIEW: The Directors attempted to impound a certain area of water through condemnation proceedings and the property owner opposed such action. The Directors hoped to impound the land for the agricultural benefit of those few landowners who owned land bounding on the proposed lake (which would be accomplished if the land was obtained) and the trial court prevented the Directors from taking such action after finding that the reason set forth was not a "public use" as required under S.C. Const. art. I, § 17. On appeal, the court affirmed and found the injunctive relief granted was proper. Because the attempted taking involved in this case was for private use such action was therefore prohibited.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court ruling in favor of the property owners, enjoining any condemnation by the Directors of the land at issue.

 

429 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Tripp v. Tripp


17919.


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


240 S.C. 334; 126 S.E.2d 9; 1962 S.C. LEXIS 1; 93 Ohio L. Abs. 565



June 1, 1962 


PRIOR HISTORY:  [*1] APPEAL FROM AN ORDER OF THE COURT OF COMMON PLEAS OF SPARTANBURG COUNTY, AFFIRMING AN ORDER OF THE PROBATE COURT HOLDING THAT THE PRIOR PROBATE IN OHIO BARRED CONTEST OF THE WILL IN SOUTH CAROLINA. 240 S.C. 334, CERT. DEN., 371 U. S., 888, 83 S. Ct. 187, 9 L. Ed. 2d, 123. FOR FURTHER HISTORY SEE OMNIBUS INDEX IN BOUND VOLUME.



DISPOSITION: AFFIRMED.

 

430 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Tripp v. Tripp


17919


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


240 S.C. 334; 126 S.E.2d 9; 1962 S.C. LEXIS 111; 93 Ohio L. Abs. 565



June 1, 1962, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Proceeding by testator's son to compel widow to prove will, which had previously been probated in Ohio. The Common Pleas Court, Spartanburg County, Bruce Littlejohn, J., affirmed an order of the Probate Court which held that the prior probate was conclusive, and the son appealed. The Supreme Court, Legge, Acting J., held that under statute declaring that exemplification of will regularly proved in foreign court may be admitted to probate, but that parties interested should not be concluded by such probate if the will "be not proved in solemn from", Ohio probate was conclusive, although Ohio had no procedure for proof in solemn form.

Affirmed.



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant son of the testator sought review of an order of the Common Pleas Court, Spartanburg County (South Carolina). That order affirmed an adjudication of the probate court. The son had sought to have respondent widow prove the validity of the testator's will, but the common-pleas court ruled that the prior probating of the will by an Ohio court had preclusive effect.


OVERVIEW: The widow had the will probated in Ohio. The son sought to have the will proven under § 19-286 of the 1952 Code (S.C.), which stated that where a will had been regularly proven in any foreign court it could be admitted to probate in South Carolina but that where it was not proved in solemn form the interested parties against the will were not bound by such probating. Both parties agreed that the solemn-form requirement referred to a requirement in the foreign court. The court accepted the widow's argument that there could be no contest in South Carolina as there could no longer be any in Ohio. Per Ohio Revised Probate Code, § 2741.09, where there was an action to contest the probating of a will, it could not be sustained unless it was brought by six months after the probating of the will except where the contestant was under a disability. The probating was conclusive as the son did not contest the probating during the Ohio six-month period. Besides § 19-286, the court's decision was also based on comity. The court ruled that the son had no standing to attack Ohio Revised Probate Code § 2107.13 as a violation of due process as he had actual notice of the Ohio probate proceedings.


OUTCOME: Ruling against the son, the court affirmed the common-pleas court's judgment.

 

431 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Marshall v. Richardson


17916


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


240 S.C. 318; 125 S.E.2d 639; 1962 S.C. LEXIS 99



May 17, 1962, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Action to compel defendant to provide support for his illegitimate children. From a judgment of the Civil and Domestic Relations Court, Sumter County, L. E. Purdy, J., holding that court lacked jurisdiction, the plaintiff appealed. The Supreme Court, Moss, J., held that reversal of decision of lower court denying jurisdiction of court to try bastardy case was required regardless of whether trial judge erred at time of rendition of his decision when statutes under which decision had been rendered were repealed and there had been an amendment to another statute involved.

Reversed and remanded.



DISPOSITION: Reversed and remanded.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant mother sought review of a judgment from the Civil and Domestic Relations Court, Sumter County (South Carolina), which was in favor of respondent alleged father in the mother's action to compel him to provide support for certain illegitimate children.


OVERVIEW: The mother instituted an action against the alleged father to compel him to provide support for her illegitimate children. the alleged father, who denied paternity, objected to the jurisdiction of the civil and domestic relations court to hear a bastardy case. A jury rendered a verdict against the alleged father, but the civil and domestic relations court held that the act under which jurisdiction was conferred upon it to try bastardy cases was unconstitutional special legislation. The mother appealed the judgment. The court found that, because §§ 20-305 through 20-309 of the 1952 Code of Laws of South Carolina had been specifically repealed, those provisions of the general law could not be in conflict with the special law. The court also found that the civil and domestic relations court should consider the effect of an amendment to § 20-303 of the Code.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment and remanded the case.

 

432 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Sherbert v. Verner


17915


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


240 S.C. 286; 125 S.E.2d 737; 1962 S.C. LEXIS 102



May 17, 1962, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Proceeding on claim for unemployment compensation by textile mill employee who, because of her religious convictions, refused to work from sundown Friday until sundown Saturday. From a judgment of the Common Pleas Court, Spartanburg County, J. Woodrow Lewis, J., the employee appealed. The Supreme Court, Moss, J., held that by restricting her availability for employment, textile mill employee was not "available for work" within Unemployment Compensation Law.

Affirmed.

BUSSEY, J., dissented.



DISPOSITION: Exceptions overruled and judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant claimant, a fired textile mill employee, challenged a judgment from the Common Pleas Court, Spartanburg County (South Carolina), which affirmed a decision from respondent South Carolina Employment Security Commission that upheld a disqualification period for unemployment compensation that was imposed on claimant pursuant to the South Carolina Unemployment Compensation Law, S.C. Code Ann. § 68-114.


OVERVIEW: The claimant, a fired textile mill employee, challenged a trial court judgment that affirmed a decision from the state unemployment commission, which imposed an unemployment compensation disqualification period of five weeks on claimant because she was unavailable for work. The claimant refused to work Saturdays for religious reasons. She failed to report for work on six successive Saturdays and she was discharged. The claimant applied for work at other textile plants but was unable to find employment because the plants operated six days a week, including Saturday. The claimant argued that the statutory construction of the South Carolina Unemployment Compensation Law, S.C. Code Ann. § 68-1 et seq., violated her rights to religious freedom and to the equal protection of the laws. The appellate court disagreed and affirmed the judgment that imposed a disqualification period, holding that the unemployment compensation statute placed no restrictions upon the claimant's freedom of religion. The appellate court held that a claimant who limited or restricted his or her willingness to work was not available for work within the meaning of the unemployment compensation statute.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment that upheld the disqualification period because the claimant restricted her willingness to work to periods or conditions that fit her own personal circumstances, and she was not available for work within the meaning of the state unemployment compensation statute.

 

433 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Cole v. Manning


17909


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


240 S.C. 260; 125 S.E.2d 621; 1962 S.C. LEXIS 96



May 3, 1962, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Habeas corpus proceeding. The General Sessions Court of Richland County, John Grimball, J., entered order, and the petitioner appealed. The Supreme Court, Legge, Acting Associate Justice, held that the statute forbidding furnishing prisoners with any matter declared by director of prison system to be contraband does not delegate legislative authority to director.

Affirmed.

BUSSEY, J., dissented.



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioners sought review of an order from the General Sessions Court of Richland County (South Carolina), which was in favor of respondent penitentiary in petitioners' habeas corpus action to obtain their release from imprisonment.


OVERVIEW: An indictment charged petitioners with furnishing tablets of amphetamine, a drug that the Director of Prisons had declared to be contraband, to prisoners in a state penitentiary in violation of § 55-14 of the 1952 Code (Supplement). After petitioners entered pleas of guilty and were sentenced to imprisonment, they filed a habeas corpus action to obtain their release. The trial court issued a writ of habeas corpus but held that the confinement of petitioners was legal. Petitioners contended on appeal that § 55-14 was an unlawful delegation of legislative authority to an administrative officer. The court concluded that § 55-14 did not unlawfully delegate legislative power to the Director of Prisons. It was not a delegation of legislative power to give the Director authority to determine what things should and should not be furnished to the prisoners in his charge. The court determined that § 55-14 was a proper delegation to the Director of the power to make administrative regulations to effectuate the legislative purpose of the maintenance of a modern prison system with humane treatment of prisoners, attention to their welfare, and assistance toward their rehabilitation.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order.

 

434 of 598 DOCUMENTS


McElveen v. Stokes


17882


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


240 S.C. 1; 124 S.E.2d 592; 1962 S.C. LEXIS 70



March 9, 1962, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Action to have declared unconstitutional an act concerning appointment and terms of office of members of a county forestry board and for other relief. From an order of the Common Pleas Court, Lee County, James Hugh McFaddin, J., sustaining the constitutionality of the statute, the plaintiffs appealed. The Supreme Court, Bussey, J., held that statute providing for a uniform method of appointing county forestry board was a general law and statute providing for appointment of members to forestry board of a particular county was not justified as a special provision in a general law and was unconstitutional.

Order reserved and cause remanded.



DISPOSITION: Order reversed and cause remanded.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, county forestry board member claimants, sought review of the judgment from Common Pleas Court of Lee County (South Carolina), which held 1961 S.C. Acts 601, An Act to Provide for the Appointment and Terms of Office of the Members of the Lee County Forestry Board, to be constitutional in an action by the claimants against respondents, the appointed board members and the South Carolina Forestry Commission.


OVERVIEW: The trial court concluded that the Act in question was an amendment to the general law and constitutional as a special provision in a general law within the purview of S.C. Const. art. III, § 35, subdivision X. On appeal, the court declared that its only duty was to determine whether or not the Act in question was clearly unconstitutional, beyond a reasonable doubt. The court found that there was, in effect, an applicable general law and no showing in the present record before it of any sufficient distinction, need, or justification for the special legislation. The court, therefore, concluded that, beyond any reasonable doubt, that 1961 S.C. Acts 601 was unconstitutional and in violation of S.C. Const. art. III, § 34, subsection IX, and was not a special provision in a general law within the purview of S.C. Const. art. III, § 34, subsection X. The court opined that if, in the judgment of the legislature, the situation as it existed in Lee County under the general law required a change, then the legislature should enact a state-wide act that would be applicable to Lee County as well as to all other counties wherein a similar situation might arise.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the trial court, and remanded the cause.

 

435 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Columbia v. Bouie


17875


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


239 S.C. 570; 124 S.E.2d 332; 1962 S.C. LEXIS 155



February 13, 1962, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Defendants were convicted of trespass and one defendant was convicted of resisting arrest and from a judgment of the County Court of Richland County, John W. Crews, County Judge, the defendants appealed. The Supreme Court, Legge, J., held that the evidence sustained the conviction of trespass but did not sustain the conviction of resisting arrest.

Affirmed in part and reversed in part.



DISPOSITION: Affirmed in part and reversed in part.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants challenged the judgment of the County Court of Richland County (South Carolina), which affirmed defendants' conviction of trespass and affirmed the conviction of one of the defendants for resisting arrest.


OVERVIEW: Defendants, African-American college students, were arrested and charged with trespass and breach of peace for sitting in a drug store's luncheonette for a meal. The luncheonette had a policy not to serve African-Americans. One defendant was also charged with resisting arrest. Defendants were subsequently convicted. The court affirmed the judgment as to the conviction and sentence of each defendant on the charge of trespass. The court found ample evidence to support the charges of trespass against defendants. However, the charge of resisting arrest was reversed because the momentary delay in one of the defendant's response to an officer's command to stand up from the luncheonette booth did not amount to "resistance" within the intent of the law.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the county court, which affirmed defendants' conviction of trespassing. However, it reversed the conviction of one of the defendants for resisting arrest.

 

436 of 598 DOCUMENTS


State v. Worthy


17865


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


239 S.C. 449; 123 S.E.2d 835; 1962 S.C. LEXIS 139



January 30, 1962, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] The defendant was convicted in the General Sessions Court of Spartanburg County, James Hugh McFaddin, J., of rape, and he appealed. The Supreme Court held that the refusal of the defendant's requested instruction that if the jury found the defendant guilty, the jury could bring back a recommendation of mercy, without any reason at all, was reversible error.

Judgment reversed and case remanded for new trial.

Moss, J., and Lewis, J., dissented in part.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant challenged an order of the General Sessions Court of Spartanburg County (South Carolina), which found him guilty on a charge of rape. Defendant was sentenced to death under §§ 16-71, 16-72, of the 1952 Code of Laws of South Carolina.


OVERVIEW: The prosecutrix, a white woman, testified that defendant, a black man, raped her. Defendant's confessions were admitted at trial into evidence. Defendant moved for a directed verdict, arguing that police officers' testimony as to the confessions was inadmissible under the best evidence rule because there were tape recordings of the statements. The trial court overruled the motion, and instructed the jury under § 16-72 of the Code (South Carolina), which allowed a jury to reduce the sentence from death to imprisonment. Defendant was convicted, his motion for a new trial was overruled, and he was sentenced to death. On appeal, the court affirmed the judgment of the trial court, holding that it was not error to refuse to charge the jury, upon defendant's request, that they had the sole discretion as to the issue of a recommendation of mercy. Specifically, the court held that it was sufficient to charge a jury in the language of § 16-72 of the Code (South Carolina). Moreover, it was proper to refuse to hold that the tape recordings defendant's confessions were the best evidence, and proper to prove the confessions by the oral testimony of the officers who heard the statements.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the trial court.

 

437 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Charleston v. Mitchell


17856


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


239 S.C. 376; 123 S.E.2d 512; 1961 S.C. LEXIS 64



December 13, 1961, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Prosecution on charges of trespass and opposing and interfering with police in discharge of official duties.
