From an adverse judgment of the General Sessions Court, Charleston County, Thomas P. Bussey, J., the defendants appealed. The Supreme Court, Moss, J., held that arrest and conviction of Negro high school students for trespassing by refusing to leave lunch counter in store upon request of manager was not in furtherance of a custom of racial segregation in violation of Fourteenth Amendment to federal Constitution and did not constitute state action in the enforcement of segregation within meaning of Fourteenth Amendment, but students, who did "nothing" when manager of store requested them to leave the store and when chief of police requested them to leave, and who were not loud or boisterous in any way, were not guilty of violating city ordinance making it unlawful for any person to resist, hinder or oppose or interfere with any employee of police department in discharge of official duties.

Affirmed in part and reversed in part.



DISPOSITION: Affirmed in part and reversed in part.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant minority students sought review of an adverse judgment of the General Sessions Court, Charleston County (South Carolina) after they were convicted of trespass, under S.C. Code Ann. § 16-386 (1952), for refusing to leave a lunch counter where they were refused service, and opposing and interfering with the police chief in discharge of his official duties.


OVERVIEW: The students were convicted of trespassing following a sit-in at the corporation's lunch counter. On appeal, they contended that their Fourteenth Amendment right to due process and equal protection was violated in that the warrants were vague, indefinite, and uncertain; did not plainly and substantially set forth the offenses charged; the arrests and convictions were in furtherance of a custom of racial segregation; they were penalized for exercising freedom of expression; and that the convictions rested upon no evidence of an essential element of the crime. The court affirmed, concluding that: (1) the warrants were not unconstitutionally vague because the wording of the warrants apprised the students of the offenses with which they were charged, in accordance with S.C. Const. art. I, § 18 and S.C. Code Ann. § 43-111 (1952); (2) the students violated S.C. Code Ann. § 16-386 in that they unlawfully, knowingly and willfully trespassed the premises; however, (3) the conduct of the students in refusing to obey the orders of the police chief was merely inaction on their part and did not constitute interference with the police chief's discharge of his official duty.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the students' convictions for criminal trespass but reversed their convictions for opposing and interfering with the police chief in discharge of his official duties.

 

438 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Greenville v. Peterson


17845


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


239 S.C. 298; 122 S.E.2d 826; 1961 S.C. LEXIS 57



November 10, 1961, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Convicted of trespass after notice for refusing to leave closed lunch counter, in the General Sessions Court of Greenville, James H. Price, Special County Judge, the defendants appealed. The Supreme Court, Taylor, C. J., held that no constitutional rights of Negroes under Fourteenth Amendment were violated by their arrest on charge of trespass after notice, predicated upon their refusal to leave store lunch counter where they were seated after manager had closed counter and turned out lights, assertedly because of local custom to serve only white persons at counter.

Affirmed.



DISPOSITION: Judgment and sentences appealed from affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants, 10 blacks, were convicted of trespass after notice in violation of S.C. Code § 16-388 (1952) for sitting at a lunch counter in Greenville, South Carolina after they refused to leave. Defendants appealed their convictions and sentences.


OVERVIEW: On August 9, 1960, law enforcement officers were dispatched to a junior department store in Greenville, South Carolina. When they arrived, they found defendants and four others who were under 16 years of age, seated at the lunch counter. There was testimony that because of the local custom to serve white persons only at the lunch counter the manager of the store announced that the lunch counter was closed, the lights were extinguished, and all persons were asked to leave. The white persons left, but the blacks refused to leave; and those above the age of 16 were charged with trespass. S.C. Code §16-388 (1952) provided that any person who was on the premises or business of another and who did not leave without legal cause or excuse after he was asked to leave could be convicted and fined not more than $ 100 or imprisoned for not more than 30 days. Defendants argued that their arrest and conviction furthered a custom of racial segregation in violation of U.S. Const. amend. XIV. The court affirmed, holding that the operator of a privately owned business could accept some customers and reject others on purely personal grounds. The court concluded that defendants were trespassing.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the trial court and the sentences.

 

439 of 598 DOCUMENTS


WATSON v. PULLAM


17837


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


239 S.C. 186; 121 S.E.2d 910; 1961 S.C. LEXIS 42



September 20, 1961, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Action for a declaration as to the constitutionality of statutes relating to the Richland-Lexington Airport District. The Common Pleas Court of Richland County, John Grimball, J., upheld the validity of one act, held one provision of the other act unconstitutional but sustained the remaining portions as severable. An appeal was taken. The Supreme Court, Oxner, J., held that mandatory features of the acts whereby the City of Columbia would be required annually to levy ad valorem taxes sufficient to defray its share of operating deficit were violative of constitutional provision that no municipal corporation shall be subject to any restrictions not applicable to all corporations of same class and such provisions rendered both acts unconstitutional.

Reversed.



DISPOSITION: Acts under consideration invalid and order reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant taxpayers challenged an order of the Common Pleas Court of Richland County (South Carolina) entered in their suit against respondents, the Commissioners of the Richland-Lexington Airport District, seeking a declaration that Act No. 66, 52 St. at Large 53 (District Act), and Act No. 114, 52 St. at Large 119 (Operating Deficit Act), were unconstitutional. The order upheld the validity of the District Act but not the Operating Deficit Act.


OVERVIEW: The District Act authorized the District to issue general obligation bonds. It provided that Richland County, Lexington County, and the City of Columbia should deliver to the District their notes, obligating them to pay one-third of the principal amount of any bonds. The Operating Deficit Act directed that the counties and the city should levy annually an ad valorem tax sufficient to cover any operating deficit of the District. The court held the circuit court properly found that this requirement, with respect to the city, violated Article 2, § 13, and Article 8, § 7 of the Constitution, that such invalidity was inseparable from the requirement as to the counties, and that therefore the whole provision regarding the annual levy of taxes was unconstitutional. However, the District Act was also unconstitutional. It was mandatory upon the counties and the city to enter into the undertaking to pay one-third of the principal amount of any bonds. Article 8, § 1 of the Constitution prohibited the general assembly from imposing restrictions on one city that were not imposed on other cities of the same class. The mandatory provisions of both Acts violated this constitutional provision.


OUTCOME: The court adjudged both Acts to be invalid and reversed the order of the circuit court.

 

440 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Atkinson v. Carolina Power & Light Co.


17834


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


239 S.C. 150; 121 S.E.2d 743; 1961 S.C. LEXIS 41



September 14, 1961, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Action by electric company to condemn fee portion of land for purpose of impounding waters to form a lake to be used in conjunction with company's generating plant. The Common Pleas Court of Darlington County, J. Woodrow Lewis, J., entered a judgment in favor of the power company and the landowners appealed. The Supreme Court held that the record established that the land undertaken to be condemned in fee by electric company was reasonably necessary for construction and operation of generating plant and there was no bad faith or abuse of discretion on part of company in its proposal to condemn land.

Affirmed.



DISPOSITION: Temporary restraining order dissolved and complaint dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In consolidated appeals, appellant landowners sought review of a judgment by the Common Pleas Court of Darlington County (South Carolina) in favor of respondents electric companies in the landowners' action to enjoin the companies action to condemn fee portion of lands for purpose of impounding waters to form a lake to be used in conjunction with generating plants.


OVERVIEW: The power companies had previously instituted condemnation proceedings to condemn property owned by the landowners. The court issued a temporary retraining order restraining further proceedings in condemnation until the further order of the court. The court then found that the erection, maintenance, and operation of plants for generating electric energy and distributing it to the public was a public use for which private property may be appropriated under authority delegated by the legislature and was no longer open to question. The court further found that under S.C. Code Ann. § 24-12, the power companies had the express power of eminent domain and that the burden was on the landowners to have established bad faith and abuse of discretion. The court held that the landowners failed to carry that burden of proof and that the power companies established by uncontradicted evidence a need in good faith for the fee to the lands sought to be condemned. Thus, the court adjudged that the landowners were not entitled to enjoin the condemnation, dissolved the temporary restraining order, and dismissed the complaint.


OUTCOME: The court ordered and adjudged that the landowners were not entitled to enjoin the condemnation of the lands by the power companies, that the temporary restraining was dissolved, and the landowners' complaints were dissolved. The court further held the power companies were authorized and empowered to proceed with the condemnation of the lands.

 

441 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Florence v. Turbeville


17832


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


239 S.C. 126; 121 S.E.2d 437; 1961 S.C. LEXIS 38; 85 A.L.R.2d 1143



September 5, 1961, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Proceeding by a city to enjoin property owners from operating a dancing school in a one and two family residential district. The Civil Court of Florence, W. T. McGowan, Jr., J., permanently enjoined the operation of the school in the area, and the owners appealed. The Supreme Court, Ness, Acting J., held that the school with an enrollment of 220 pupils, carried on six days a week, although in small daily classes, was not a "customary home use or occupation" within the ordinance permitting customary home occupations in the zone in question.

Affirmed.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant owners sought review of a judgment of the Civil Court of Florence (South Carolina), which, in a proceeding instituted by appellee city, permanently enjoined the operation of the owners' dancing school in a one and two family residential district.


OVERVIEW: The owners operated a dancing school in their home, located in a residential zone. The school had an enrollment of 220 pupils, had small daily classes 6 days a week, and had employees. There were no signs advertising the school and there was no evidence that anyone in the neighborhood was disturbed by the noise. The owners filed exceptions to the trial court order enjoining the operation of their school. On appeal, the court affirmed. The court rejected the owners' contention that the zoning ordinance was not valid because the city had not been in existence at the time it was passed, finding that the owners could not collaterally attack the existence of the city. The court found that the owners were not entitled to a non-conforming use exemption for the operation of their school, nor were they entitled to a customary home occupation exemption. The court decided that the owners' use of their home as a school was purely commercial and bore no relation to any usual and ordinary home purpose. The court concluded that the ordinance applied equally to all within the zone and that the owners had not sustained their burden of proving that a dancing school fell within any exception.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the trial court that permanently enjoined the operation of the owners' dancing school.

 

442 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Darlington v. Stanley


17812


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


239 S.C. 139; 122 S.E.2d 207; 1961 S.C. LEXIS 45



July 28, 1961, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Prosecution for violation of municipal ordinance prohibiting staging of a parade or a procession on the streets without a permit. The Municipal Court of the City of Darlington entered judgments of conviction which were sustained by the General Sessions Court of Darlington County, J. Woodrow Lewis, J., and the defendants appealed. The Supreme Court, Oxner, J., held that the ordinance was not unconstitutional on ground that it denied guaranties of freedom of assembly and speech or that it failed to set definite standards.

Affirmed.



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants appealed a judgment of the Darlington County Circuit Court (South Carolina) that affirmed their convictions of staging a parade or procession on a city street without a permit in violation of a city ordinance, arguing that the city ordinance at issue was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: Defendants held a parade without obtaining a permit. They were charged with staging a parade without a permit in violation of a city ordinance. At trial before the municipal court, defendants were convicted as charged. They appealed, contending that the ordinance was unconstitutional because it deprived them of their right of freedom of speech and assembly as guaranteed by S.C. Const. art. 1, § 4, and the First Amendment to the Constitution of the United States. The circuit court affirmed their convictions, and defendants sought further review, again raising a constitutional challenge. In affirming, the court concluded that, while the right to engage in a parade was the exercise of the fundamental right of free speech and assembly, such a right was subject to reasonable regulation and limitation. The ordinance at issue was not unconstitutional because it was not designed to suppress any fundamental freedom but was intended to reasonably regulate the use of the streets in the public interest. It did not seek to control what was said but was applicable only to organized formations of people using the streets for a parade or procession.


OUTCOME: The judgment of the circuit court was affirmed.

 

443 of 598 DOCUMENTS


South Carolina State Highway Dep't v. Hammond


17783


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


238 S.C. 248; 120 S.E.2d 21; 1961 S.C. LEXIS 93



May 12, 1961, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] A proceeding by the State Highway Department against the owner and the lessees of certain land to acquire a right of way over the land for highway purposes. The Court of Common Pleas, Richland County, James Hugh McFaddin, J., denied the landowner's motions to dismiss the proceeding or to obtain a separate trial to determine her damages, and the landowner appealed. The Supreme Court, Lewis, J., held that the lessees had an interest in the land by virtue of the lease and, therefore, were properly made parties to the proceeding, and that the landowner was not entitled to a separate trial, in the absence of a showing of legal prejudice in the case of a joint trial.

Affirmed.



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant landowner challenged an order of the Court of Common Pleas, Richland County (South Carolina) denying her motions to dismiss the proceeding or to obtain a separate trial to determine her damages in connection with a complaint by respondent South Carolina State Highway Department to condemn her land for highway purposes. At issue, inter alia, was whether the landowner was entitled to a trial separate from that involving her lessees.


OVERVIEW: When the Department sought to obtain a right-of-way over the land in suit, both the landowner and her lessees were made parties to the suit. After the landowner and the lessees rejected an award made after an administrative hearing, a de novo trial in the common pleas court was ordered. When the case was called, however, the lessees failed to appear, and the landowner moved for a separate trial and for other relief. The common pleas court denied relief, and the landowner appealed. The court affirmed. First, it held that, pursuant to § 33-132 of the 1952 Code of Laws of South Carolina, the lessees were properly joined as parties to the condemnation proceeding because of their interest in the land by reason of the lease. Second, the ruling denying a separate trial on the landowner's damages was proper. That was because a common pleas court was not required in a condemnation proceeding to allow a separate trial to each owner of an estate or interest in the land condemned unless a landowner showed that legal prejudice would result by reason of a joint trial. Where, as here, no such showing was made, there was no basis for the granting of a separate trial on the issue of damages.


OUTCOME: The court held that the lessees were properly made parties to the proceeding, and that the landowner was not entitled to a separate trial in the absence of a showing of legal prejudice in the case of a joint trial, which showing the landowner failed to make. The court thereupon rendered judgment on the order denying the motions.

 

444 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Reese v. Talbert


17719


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


237 S.C. 356; 117 S.E.2d 375; 1960 S.C. LEXIS 109



December 6, 1960, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Action for judgment declaring that the act authorizing issuance of general obligation bonds of Richland County in amount not exceeding $ 350,000.00, the proceeds thereof to be used for improvement and renovation of existing public hospital facilities in the county is unconstitutional because it makes no provision for an election. From an adverse decree of the Common Pleas Court, Richland County, John Grimball, J., the plaintiff appealed. The Supreme Court, Legge, J., held that the Act is unconstitutional for failure to provide for such election as required by the constitutional amendment.

Reversed.



DISPOSITION: Reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff appealed from a judgment of the Common Pleas Court, Richland County (South Carolina), which found in favor of defendants, a county board of commissioners and a county supervisor, in plaintiff's action seeking a declaration that the Act of April 1, 1950, 51 Stat. at. Large, p 2799, was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The Act authorized the issuance of general obligation bonds of the county in an amount not exceeding a set limit, with the proceeds to be used for the improvement and renovation of existing public hospital facilities in the county. However, plaintiff argued that the Act was unconstitutional because it made no provision for an election, as required by a special amendment to the South Carolina Constitution, ratified February 21, 1921, relating to the bonded indebtedness of the county. On review, the court agreed and declared the Act unconstitutional. In reaching its conclusion, the court rejected respondents' claim that an election was not required because the debt would not exceed the constitutional limit for the county. The court held that no such condition was stated in the amendment and that there was nothing to show that the legislature intended such a condition to apply to trigger the amendment's election requirement. In support of its holding, the court noted a variety of past acts by the General Assembly that specifically required an election to approve the issuance of bonds to construct and improve hospital facilities in the county.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the trial court's judgment and declared the Act unconstitutional.

 

445 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Cox v. Bates


17704


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


237 S.C. 198; 116 S.E.2d 828; 1960 S.C. LEXIS 95



October 19, 1960, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Original proceeding brought by taxpayer on behalf of himself and all others similarly situated against state Treasurer and Comptroller General of state challenging constitutionality of law providing for creation and maintenance of state reserve fund and for distribution of surplus funds to counties for public school purposes. The Supreme Court, Stukes, C. J., held that under statute, no tax was levied and statute was not unconstitutional on ground that appropriation to counties did not sufficiently specify object and purposes of appropriation.

Judgment accordingly.

OXNER, J., dissented.



DISPOSITION: Temporary restraining order dissolved and complaint dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff taxpayer filed a lawsuit against defendants, state treasurer and comptroller challenging the constitutionality of a law allowing for the creation and maintenance of a state reserve fund and for the distribution of surplus funds to the counties for public schools.


OVERVIEW: The law at issue being challenged by the taxpayer was the State Appropriation Act of 1954 (Act). The taxpayer claimed that one part of the Act violated S.C. Const. art. I, § 14, which required the separation of the powers of the several branches of government and prohibited the exercise of the functions of one of the department of government by a member of another department. Defendants agreed with the taxpayer's assertion, but stated that only this specific part of the Act should be deleted. The court agreed with defendants and ruled that even if this part of the Act was deleted that it was still a complete and valid law. The court rejected defendants claim that the Act violated S.C. Const. art. X, §§ 2, 3 by inappropriately levying a tax except in pursuance of a law which specifically stated the object to which the tax would be applied. The court ruled that the Act did not levy a tax, and instead simply dealt with a surplus if in fact a surplus existed at the end of the fiscal year. The court stated that where a surplus remained after payment of appropriations, it could be appropriated to other purposes such as to counties for public schools usage, as in this case.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the taxpayer's lawsuit against the state treasurer and comptroller and ruled that the law challenged by the taxpayer was constitutional.

 

446 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Williams v. Jacobs


17703


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


237 S.C. 183; 116 S.E.2d 157; 1960 S.C. LEXIS 92



September 13, 1960, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Action to have declared null and void all proceedings in election held for purpose of annexing town to city. The Common Pleas Court, York County, James Hugh McFaddin, J., entered order approving annexation, and citizens and taxpayers of town appealed. The Supreme Court, Taylor, J., held that under statute providing that, to effect extension of boundaries of municipality, petition shall be first submitted to council by majority of freeholders of territory to be annexed, names on petition, when filed and acted upon by annexing body, could not thereafter be ratified.

Order reversed; proposed annexation declared null and void.



DISPOSITION: Order appealed from reversed and proposed annexation declared null and void.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Action by plaintiffs, citizens and taxpayers of a town, against defendants, officers of the town and a city, in the Common Pleas Court, York County (South Carolina) to have declared null and void all proceedings in an election held for the purpose of annexing the town to the city. An order was entered approving the annexation, and plaintiffs appealed.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiffs contended, first, that the statutes did not authorize the annexation of an incorporated town, second, that the petition for election was not signed by a majority of the freeholders, and, third, that the election was invalid. Defendants presented the sustaining ground that the action should have been dismissed for plaintiffs' failure to give bond. The court reversed. It found that the first question had to be resolved against the contention of plaintiffs. The court noted that no obligation attached to those signing the petition and, therefore, there was no obligation to ratify. It found, however, that a certain amount of responsibility did attach; responsibility to give the matter at hand due consideration and responsibility to one's co-signer and other residents of the area affected. The court found that the names on the petition when filed and acted upon by the annexing body could not be thereafter ratified. The court concluded that it was evident that, unless the questioned names were counted, the petition was deficient in that it was not by a majority of the freeholders of the territory to be annexed.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the order, and declared the proposed annexation null and void.

 

447 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Southern R. Co. v. South Carolina State Highway Dep't


17692


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


237 S.C. 75; 115 S.E.2d 685; 1960 S.C. LEXIS 85



August 3, 1960, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Action by railroad in nature of appeal from decision of State Highway Department determining that railway should contribute to cost of reconstruction of highway bridge. The Supreme Court adopted opinion of E. W. Mullins, Special Referee, to effect that reconstruction of highway bridge built to span cut in which there was a railroad track was not a grade separation structure within statute providing scheme for apportionment of costs between Highway Department and railroad for reconstructing, changing or altering a grade separation structure and railroad which owned tracks in cut was not liable for any portion of cost of reconstruction of bridge.

Judgment for railway.



DISPOSITION: Relief sought by Petitioner granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner railway company filed an original action in the nature of an appeal of a decision of appellants, the State Highway Department, its commissioner, and the state highway engineer, that the company should contribute to the cost of reconstructing a highway bridge pursuant to § 58-831 et seq., of the 1952 South Carolina Code. A special referee found in favor of the company. The Department filed exceptions to the referee's report.


OVERVIEW: The Department had relocated a highway, which crossed a cut in which lay a track of the company. A bridge was built to span the cut. Years later, the Department determined that it was necessary to reconstruct the bridge and assessed the company a portion of the cost. The company stated that it did not contribute to the cost of constructing the original bridge and had derived no benefits therefrom, so it would not pay for any part of the bridge's reconstruction. The court held that the referee's order of nonsuit was affirmed because the Department's claim was time-barred and because the statutory basis for the Department's charge to the company did not apply where no grade crossing was being eliminated. Consequently, the company was not liable for the costs sought to be imposed by the Department, and the Department had exceeded its authority.


OUTCOME: The court granted the relief sought by petitioner and the referee's report was adopted as the court's judgment.

 

448 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Gwynette v. Myers


17687


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


237 S.C. 17; 115 S.E.2d 673; 1960 S.C. LEXIS 84



July 26, 1960, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Action by State Dairy Commission to enjoin retail grocer from selling Grade-A milk at price below minimum price fixed by Commission for area as a controlled market. The County Court, Greenville County. W. B. McGowan, J., sustained demurrer to complaint, and Commission appealed. The Supreme Court, Legge, J., held that the business of selling milk was not affected with the public interest, regulation of milk prices was beyond state's police power, and statute which purported to give State Dairy Commission power to regulate retail prices was to that extent unconstitutional.

Affirmed.

OXNER, J., dissented.



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant State Dairy Commission instituted an action seeking to enjoin respondent retail grocer from selling Grade-A milk at a price below minimum price fixed by the Commission for an area as a controlled market. The Commission appealed from a decision of the County Court, Greenville County (South Carolina) sustaining a demurrer to complaint.


OVERVIEW: The Commission issued an order declaring the Greenville-Spartanburg market area a "controlled market" and fixing minimum prices to be charged for milk by producers, distributors, and retailers in that area. The primary ground of the demurrer was that the price-fixing provisions of The Act of May 11, 1955, 49 Stat. at L. 496, and of the Commission's orders issued by virtue thereof denied the retail grocer the due process and equal protection guaranteed by Article 1, Section 5 of the Constitution of South Carolina. The issue presented was whether the State could fix the price at which a retail grocer could sell milk. The court noted that the right of the State to regulate and control the production and distribution of milk with regard to sanitation and purity was not in question. The court further noted that the only provision of the Act that was challenged was that which purported to empower the Commission to dictate to a retail grocer the minimum price at which he could sell wholesome milk that he had purchased from a distributor at the latter's price. The court concluded, in its affirmance, that the police power of the State did not extend so far.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's decision.

 

449 of 598 DOCUMENTS


State v. Langley


17679


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


236 S.C. 583; 115 S.E.2d 308; 1960 S.C. LEXIS 73



July 8, 1960, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Defendant was convicted for permitting a minor under the age of 18 to play and operate a pinball machine and from a judgment of the General Sessions Court, Chester County, J. Woodrow Lewis, J., the defendant appealed. The Supreme Court, Taylor, J., held that the Act making it unlawful for the operator of any pinball machine to permit a minor under the age of 18 to play or operate the machine is not unconstitutional.

Affirmed.



DISPOSITION: Order appealed from affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of a decision from the General Sessions Court, Chester County (South Carolina), which affirmed a judgment convicting defendant of permitting a minor under the age of 18 to play and operate a pinball machine, in violation of South Carolina Code § 5-624.2 (1952) (Supp.). Defendant contended that the statute under which he was convicted was violative of South Carolina Const. art. I, § 5, and U.S. Const. amend. XIV.


OVERVIEW: It was admitted that defendant was an operator of a pinball machine as referred to in South Carolina Code § 5-624.2 (1952) (Supp.) and that at the time of his arrest a minor of the age of 17 years was playing a pinball machine in defendant's place of business. Defendant's motion to dismiss was overruled and he was sentenced to pay a fine or serve 30 days in jail. The court noted that the very nature of a pinball machine was conducive to wagering or gaming. The legislature had a right to regulate through licensing the operation of such machines under its police power. The legislature could require the operation of pinball machines to be conducted in such a way as not to be obnoxious to public health, manners, or morals. The court concluded that South Carolina Code § 5-624.2 (1952) (Supp.) did not prohibit the carrying on of a legal business but was instead a permissible regulation of such business under the police power of the state; such police power could be exercised for the benefit of the public safety, health, peace, morals, or general welfare. Defendant's conviction was accordingly upheld.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment convicting defendant of permitting a minor under the age of 18 to play and operate a pinball machine.

 

450 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Carolina Amusement Co. v. Martin


17678


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


236 S.C. 558; 115 S.E.2d 273; 1960 S.C. LEXIS 66; 42 Lab. Cas. (CCH) P50,223



July 7, 1960, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Action for declaratory judgment that statute prohibiting public sports or pastimes on Sunday was inapplicable to the orderly showing of motion pictures on Sunday or that statute was invalid because it was in conflict with the Constitutions of the United States and of South Carolina. The Common Pleas Court of Greenville County, T. B. Greneker, J., entered adverse judgment and plaintiffs appealed. The Supreme Court, Stukes, C. J., held that statute prohibiting showing of motion pictures on Sunday was not violative of constitutional provisions respecting equal protection and due process of law and did not constitute an abridgement of free speech or violation of constitutional prohibition against the establishment of a religion or the free exercise thereof.

Affirmed.



DISPOSITION: Exceptions overruled and judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant theater owners and companies (theater owners) sought review of a decision of the Common Pleas Court of Greenville County (South Carolina), which denied an injunction and declaratory relief. The theater owners' claims challenged the application and the constitutionality of a state statute banning public sports and pastimes on Sunday.


OVERVIEW: The theater owners challenged the application of a state statute, S.C. Code § 64-1, which prohibited public sports or pastimes on Sundays, to the showing of motion pictures. The plaintiffs argued that the statute was an invalid restraint upon free speech and in conflict with the First Amendment and the Fourteenth Amendment of the United States Constitution and with S.C. Const. art I, §§ 4, 6. The lower court denied the motion, and plaintiffs appealed. The court affirmed, holding that the statute's prohibition of "plays" and "interludes" encompassed the showing of motion pictures. According to the court, the statute was a legitimate exercise of the police power based on promoting the general welfare by having a day of rest from customary labor. The court also found the statute to be constitutional. If good and sufficient police reasons underlay the statute, and substantial police purposes were involved, these reasons and purposes constituted its civil and legal justification, whether they were or not the direct and immediate motives. Further, in the exercise of the police power of the state there was no invasion of the theater owners' constitutional rights of free speech.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the lower court's finding that the statute applied to prohibit the showing of motion pictures on Sundays and that the statute was constitutional and not violative of the equal protection and First Amendment rights of the theater owners.

 

451 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Case v. Hermitage Cotton Mills


17673


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


236 S.C. 515; 115 S.E.2d 57; 1960 S.C. LEXIS 2



June 23, 1960, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Proceedings to review Industrial Commission's award in favor of workmen's compensation claimant. The Common Pleas Court, Kershaw County, G. Duncan Bellinger, J., affirmed Commission's award, but entered orders staying execution in claimant's favor pending determination of an appeal by employer and its carrier. Claimant appealed from order staying execution. The Supreme Court, Legge, J., held that under statute providing that in case of an appeal on questions of law from decision of Industrial Commission, such appeal shall operate as a supersedeas for 30 days only and thereafter employer shall be required to make payment until questions shall have been fully determined, order staying execution was improper, but that error was harmless where on appeal Supreme Court claim was barred.

Appeal dismissed.



DISPOSITION: Appeal dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Claimant employee appealed the judgment of the Common Pleas Court, Kershaw County (South Carolina), which affirmed the Industrial Commission's award in her favor but entered orders staying execution in her favor pending determination of an appeal by respondents, an employer and a carrier.


OVERVIEW: The Commissioner of the Industrial Commission made an award to the employee. The Industrial Commission affirmed. The award was also affirmed by the circuit court. The employer and its carrier appealed and sought a stay of execution of the order to pay the employee. The circuit judge issued his stay order, conditioned upon the filing of a supersedeas bond, which was done. The employee appealed. The court found that the circuit court judge's order was erroneous to the extent that it purported to stay payment of weekly compensation from the date of the Commission's award until the determination by this court of the employer's appeal on the merits. However, the employee could derive no benefit from that error because the court determined that her claim was barred by the statutory limitation and therefore not compensable. Reversal of the order under appeal, for such error, would be a futile gesture, because although on the one hand the employer would be obligated to make such payment, on the other, the employee would be simultaneously obligated to make restitution of the amount so received. In these circumstances the error was harmless, and the appeal was therefore dismissed.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the employee's appeal because the trial court's error was harmless in light of the fact that the court found that her claim was barred by the statute of limitations.

 

452 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Moseley v. South Carolina Highway Dep't


17670


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


236 S.C. 499; 115 S.E.2d 172; 1960 S.C. LEXIS 63



June 14, 1960, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Action by hotel owner against state highway department, which allegedly had raised state highway located within municipal boundary and had thus caused surface water to be cast on hotel property after each heavy rainfall, for compensation for taking of private property for public use, wherein department moved to dismiss on ground that it was not subject to suit for damages arising out of construction of state highway within limits of municipality. The Common Pleas Court, Chesterfield County, J. B. Ness, J., entered order denying the motion, and the department appealed. The Supreme Court, Oxner, J., held that statutes giving municipality right to review and approve plans for improvement by department of state highways within municipal boundaries and providing that such approval means that municipality assumes liability for damage to private property from such improvements and that department shall not be liable for such damage did not relieve department of liability to hotel owner for the alleged taking, but only fixed liability of municipality and department inter sese.

Order affirmed.



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant, South Carolina Highway Department, appealed from a decision of the Common Pleas Court, Chesterfield County (South Carolina), which denied the Department's motion to dismiss plaintiff hotel owner's action that sought to recover compensation for the taking of private property for public use.


OVERVIEW: The Department and a town entered into an agreement under which the former agreed to improve and pave certain streets within the town. The owner alleged that in making these improvements, the streets in front of his hotel were elevated, causing surface water to be cast upon his property after each heavy rainfall. In affirming, the court held that §§ 33-173, 174, and 234 of the 1952 Code (South Carolina) only fixed the liability of the town and the Department inter sese. The Department was not exempt from liability for compensation after private property was taken for public use in the construction or improvement of a state highway within the town. The town was not solely liable to the owner.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed.

 

453 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Plenge v. Russell


17665


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


236 S.C. 473; 115 S.E.2d 177; 1960 S.C. LEXIS 64



June 7, 1960, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Actions by radiologists against hospital officials for declaratory and coercive relief with respect to hospital regulations affecting radiologists' earnings and fees. The Common Pleas Court, Spartanburg County, Bruce Littlejohn, J., sustained demurrers, and plaintiffs appealed. The Supreme Court, Legge, J., held that the complaint stated a justiciable controversy.

Judgment reversed.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff radiologists sought review of a decision of the Common Pleas Court, Spartanburg County (South Carolina), which sustained the demurrers of defendants, members of a hospital board of trustees and an administrator, in the action of the radiologists for declaratory and coercive relief with respect to hospital regulations affecting the radiologists' earnings and fees.


OVERVIEW: The radiologists filed an action against the members of the hospital board of trustees and the administrator for declaratory and coercive relief with respect to hospital regulations affecting the radiologists' earnings and fees. The trial court sustained defendants' demurrers. On appeal, the court reversed. The court held that the issues suggested did not appear to be foreclosed. They involved the construction and constitutionality of certain legislative enactments that had not been judicially construed, the validity of certain regulations of the hospital contended by the radiologists to be discriminatory and invalid, and the propriety of the computation of charges to charity in the calculation of the cost of operating the hospital's radiological department. Thus, the complaint stated a justiciable controversy requiring for its determination a hearing on the merits.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the trial court's decision to sustain the demurrers.

 

454 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Davis v. Davis


17645


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


236 S.C. 277; 113 S.E.2d 819; 1960 S.C. LEXIS 35



April 14, 1960, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Husband brought action for divorce, and default judgment for divorce was rendered. The Common Pleas Court of Lee County, James Hugh McFaddin, J., rendered an order vacating default judgment for divorce and permitting wife to amend answer or otherwise plead to complaint, and the husband appealed. The Supreme Court, Stukes, C. J., held that Common Pleas Court properly vacated default judgment of divorce in favor of husband, on ground that divorce suit was fatally irregular for lack of notice to wife, who had answered, of application for order of reference, and of application for the judgment.

Affirmed.



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant husband challenged a decision of the Common Pleas Court of Lee County (South Carolina), which vacated default judgment for divorce and permitted respondent wfie to amend her answer or otherwise plead to the complaint.


OVERVIEW: The husband sought a divorce based on desertion. In the office of the husband's attorney, the wfie signed an answer to the complaint in which she admitted the allegations contained in the divorce petition. This answer was not filed in the trial court. A default judgment was then entered against the wife. In affirming, the court held that the divorce proceedings were fatally irregular for lack of notice to the wife. The wife answered, of application for the order of reference, notice of the reference and application for the decree. The court noted that defaults in divorce actions were more readily opened than in other cases based on society's concerns with the purity and preservation of the marriage relation.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed.

 

455 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Ex parte Stone


17643


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


236 S.C. 263; 113 S.E.2d 786; 1960 S.C. LEXIS 1



April 13, 1960, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Action to enjoin the maintenance of an alleged liquor nuisance. From an order of the General Sessions Court, Chester County, George T. Gregory, Jr., J., the defendant appeals. The Supreme Court, Oxner, J., held that if the order was invalid because too general defendant must obey the portion that was valid, until it was set aside or revoked and that punishment was properly imposed under section 4-406 rather than section 15-231.1.

Judgment affirmed.



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant challenged a decision of the General Sessions Court, Chester County (South Carolina), which enjoined the maintenance of an alleged liquor nuisance and imposed punishment under § 4-406 of the 1952 Code (South Carolina).


OVERVIEW: The action was brought under §§ 4-401 to 4-408 of the 1952 Code (South Carolina) to enjoin the maintenance of the alleged liquor nuisance. Defendant was charged with running a canteen in which alcoholic liquors were unlawfully sold. The canteen was allegedly a menace to the community at large. In affirming, the court held that even if the order was invalid because it was too general, defendant should have obeyed the portion that was valid. The trial court had jurisdiction over the subject matter and the parties. The most that could be said was not the order was too broad. Punishment was properly imposed under § 4-406 of the 1952 Code (South Carolina) rather than § 15-231.1 of the 1952 Code (South Carolina) because defendant was charged with violating a restraining order.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed.

 

456 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Johnson v. Thomason


17632


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


236 S.C. 135; 113 S.E.2d 417; 1960 S.C. LEXIS 19



March 29, 1960, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Action for judgment declaring 1959 statute, which purported to authorize issuance by county of general obligation bonds without requiring election as condition precedent, unconstitutional. The Common Pleas Court, Laurens County, George T. Gregory, Jr., J., entered judgment declaring act to be valid, and plaintiff appealed. The Supreme Court, Legge, J., held that where legislature, immediately after ratification of 1921 constitutional amendment authorizing county to vote bonds, had interpreted the amendment as requiring an election as condition precedent to issuance of bonds, the statute was unconstitutional.

Reversed.



DISPOSITION: Reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant sought review after the Common Pleas Court, Laurens County (South Carolina), rendered a judgment in his case to declare Act No. 462 of the 1959 Acts of the General Assembly unconstitutional. Ruling in favor of respondents, the common-pleas court decided that the statute was constitutional. Appellant claimed that the statute did not require an election for bond issuance and thus was invalid.


OVERVIEW: Act No. 462 of the 1959 Acts of the General Assembly authorized for Laurens County the issuance of bonds for permanent improvements to in part county roads. The 1921 amendment to Article X, § 5 of the South Carolina Constitution spoke of authorizing Laurens County to vote bonds. Appellant argued that under the Constitution, an election was required because Act No. 4632 authorized bond issuance without an election. Respondents argued that the word "vote" in the constitutional amendment meant issue. The court disagreed. Part of the court's rationale was based on legislation that followed the constitutional amendment. The legislature interpreted the constitutional amendment as requiring elections. The court cited Act No. 355 (XXXII Stat. at L. 679), Act No. 354 (XXXII Stat. at L. 677), and Act No. 356 (XXXII Stat. at L. 681). The latter two authorized the issuance of county bonds, but the issuance had to be submitted to qualified electors of the respective counties. The court also relied on the language of the Act of the Legislature approved March 23, 1926 (XXXIV Stat. at L. 1594) even though it had decided that the language in that law provided for an insufficient election.


OUTCOME: Ruling in favor of appellant, the court reversed the judgment.

 

457 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Sossamon v. Greater Gaffney Metropolitan Utilities Area


17631


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


236 S.C. 173; 113 S.E.2d 534; 1960 S.C. LEXIS 21



March 23, 1960, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Action to determine constitutionality of statute creating Metropolitan Utilities Area to supply water and sewer facilities to whole of county lying outside city limits and providing that all facilities of Area be tied together and connected with existing facilities of city and that city after paying its own cost of construction, maintenance and service charges, shall pay the balance of revenues over to county treasurer. From an order of Court of Common Pleas, Cherokee County, G. Duncan Bellinger, J., upholding the statute, taxpayers appealed. The Supreme Court, Oxner, J., held that the rights of cities and towns to acquire and operate waterworks systems and to furnish water could not be restricted in the manner proposed by the legislation and that the statute, applying as it did to but one city of the state, violated constitutional provision that no municipal corporation shall be subject to any restrictions other than all corporations of the same class.

Reversed.



DISPOSITION: Decree reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, taxpayers of a county, brought an action to determine the constitutionality of Act No. 1042 of the 1958 Acts of the South Carolina General Assembly, Aug. 27, 1957, 50 St. at L. 2195, as amended in 1959. The Court of Common Pleas, Cherokee County (South Carolina), rendered an order upholding the constitutionality of the legislation. The taxpayers appealed, and a city's commissioners of public works intervened as appellants.


OVERVIEW: The Act imposed on the City of Gaffney, South Carolina, the duty of furnishing water to those outside its corporate limits. Other municipalities could choose not to do so. The obligation placed on Gaffney had to be discharged without profit. All other municipalities could charge reasonable compensation and make a profit on utility service outside their corporate limits. Under the Act, the right to contract with outside customers given by § 59-531 of the 1952 South Carolina Code to all municipalities was denied to Gaffney. It had no voice in fixing the rates to be charged to such customers. The court held that the Act, as amended by Act No. 373 of the 1959 Acts of the South Carolina General Assembly, May 28, 1959, 51 St. at L. 741, violated Article 8, §§ 1 and 5 of the South Carolina Constitution, which provided that no municipal corporation could be subject to any restrictions other than all corporations of the same class and which granted to all municipalities within the state the right to acquire and operate a waterworks system. The court rejected the contention that the constitutionality of a special purpose district of the instant kind had been uniformly upheld.


OUTCOME: The court reversed.

 

458 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Board of Bank Control v. Thomason


17630


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


236 S.C. 158; 113 S.E.2d 544; 1960 S.C. LEXIS 23



March 22, 1960, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Proceeding on application to the State Board of Bank Control for a license to conduct a small loan business. The Board denied the application. The County Court, Spartanburg County, Charles W. Pace, J., reversed the order of the Board and the Board appealed. The Supreme Court, Oxner, J., held, inter alia, that the conclusion of Board that issuance of additional license to conduct a small loan business in City of Spartanburg would not promote the convenience and advantage of the community, was supported by substantial evidence including showing that city was served by three banks, ten unlicensed large finance companies and twenty-nine small loan companies and that each licensee would be serving some 1269 persons.

Reversed and decision of Board reinstated.

TAYLOR, J., dissented.



DISPOSITION: Order reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant State Board of Bank Control sought review of a decision from the County Court of Spartanburg County (South Carolina), which held that it had erred in denying respondent applicants' request for a license to conduct a small loan business and directing the Board to issue to the applicants a license to engage in such business.


OVERVIEW: Under S.C. Code §§ 8-794 to 8-794.166 (1959 Cum. Supp.), the Board was authorized to issue licenses to applicants to engage in the small loan business, but to do so it was required to find that the applicants were of good character and had available adequate funds, and that granting the application would promote the convenience of the community. The Board determined that the additional license would not promote the convenience of the community based on the population of the area, and it denied the application. The county court reversed because it found the Board had relied on old population statistics. On review, the court determined that the licensing and regulation of small loan companies was an exercise of the police power and essentially a legislative and administrative function. Thus, although S.C. Code § 8-794.163 gave the court the authority to set aside a decision of the Board, the constitutional requirement as to separation of powers limited the court's review. Whether small loan companies served the public interest and, if so, whether experience justified a restriction on the number licensed were not considerations for the courts.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the decision and ordered that the decision of the Board be reinstated.

 

459 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Williams v. Marion County Board of Education


17517


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


234 S.C. 273; 107 S.E.2d 640; 1959 S.C. LEXIS 75



March 12, 1959, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Action to enjoin county board of education from interfering with children attending schools located in town within county school district. The Common Pleas Court, Marion County, G. Badger Baker, J., denied the relief sought, and plaintiffs appealed. The Supreme Court, Taylor, J., held that even after a consolidation had previously been effected and a valid school district had been created, county board of education had authority to divide district; and held that where adequate facilities for children of elementary age existed in new district thus created and provision was made for pupils of high school age to transfer to district where adequate facilities did exist until such time as modern facilities could be provided in new district, there was no deprivation of equal protection of laws.

Affirmed.



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff parents challenged an order of the Common Pleas Court, Marion County (South Carolina), which entered judgment for defendant county board of education in the parents' action to enjoin the board from interfering with children attending schools located in a town within the county school district.


OVERVIEW: The parents had children in both elementary and high schools. They contended that the board improperly divided the school district such as to require their children to attend different schools. The parents filed an action to enjoin the board from requiring their children to attend such other schools. The trial court did not grant an injunction but ordered the high school children to attend their old school until the new school had adequate facilities. The court affirmed. The school district was properly divided by one of the methods set forth in § 21-112, Code of Laws of South Carolina (1952), which was the authorization by the board with the written approval of the senator and the entire house legislative delegation.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's judgment.

 

460 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Bellamy v. Johnson


17504


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


234 S.C. 172; 107 S.E.2d 33; 1959 S.C. LEXIS 63



February 16, 1959, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Action to determine validity of proceedings by municipality to annex adjoining territory. The County Court, Horry County, Claude M. Epps, J., rendered judgment upholding the proceedings, and plaintiffs appealed. The Supreme Court, Stukes, C. J., held that where stipulation set forth on ballots stated that if annexation was approved, municipality would pass ordinance exempting from taxation all annexed undeveloped parcels in excess of 10 acres, in absence of evidence that the governing body had taken implemental action, the stipulation was misleading and election approving annexation was void.

Reversed and annexation proceedings voided.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed and annexation proceedings voided.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants sought review of a judgment from the County Court, Horry County (South Carolina), which upheld proceedings for the annexation of adjoining territory to respondent municipality. The required election resulted favorably in both the municipality and the area proposed to be annexed.


OVERVIEW: Appellants contended that the annexation was unnecessary, unreasonable, and without benefit and, therefore, invalid. The court found that the evidence did not support their contention. However, it did find that there was a fatal irregularity in the proceedings. The ballot contained a stipulation that exempted all parcels of undeveloped real estate in the area to be annexed in excess of 10 acres owned by any person from taxation until the property was developed or divided into lots. While the trial court based its decree on Act No. 886 of the General Assembly of 1956, 49 Stat. 2140 (South Carolina), the court observed that there was no evidence that a governing body took any implemental action. Thus, the court did not need to express an opinion on the constitutionality of such action. The court found that the ballot was misleading. It was unfairly calculated to induce favorable votes by freeholders who were residents of the area proposed to be annexed. The trial court erroneously held that even if the stipulation was unconstitutional, such an exemption did not cause the annexation to fail because it was otherwise valid. The court voided the annexation proceedings.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment and voided the annexation proceedings.

 

461 of 598 DOCUMENTS


De Pass v. Spartanburg


17499


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


234 S.C. 198; 107 S.E.2d 350; 1959 S.C. LEXIS 71



February 9, 1959, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Action by landowner to enjoin proceedings against her under Spartanburg ordinance respecting substandard housing rehabilitation. The Common Pleas Court of Spartanburg County, J. B. Pruitt, J., sustained city's demurrer to complaint which was dismissed and landlord appealed. The Supreme Court, Stukes, C. J., held that landowner aggrieved by application of ordinance could not resort to courts before he had invoked and exhausted administrative remedies provided by ordinance.

Affirmed.



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant landowner sought review of a judgment of the Common Pleas Court of Spartanburg County (South Carolina), which sustained a demurrer filed by respondents, a city and others, in the landowner's action to enjoin proceedings against her under a city ordinance respecting substandard housing rehabilitation.


OVERVIEW: The landowner claimed that an order of the city's rehabilitation director requiring rehabilitation of eleven of her houses by a certain date and notifying her of her right to a hearing, was void because she was in compliance with the ordinance, the city was in default in its obligations, the order was unreasonable and was not served personally or by registered mail, and the order constituted an attempt to take her property without due process of law. On appeal, the court affirmed the judgment, which sustained the city's demurrer to the landowner's action to enjoin the proceedings against her. The court held that a party aggrieved by the application of an ordinance was required to invoke and exhaust the administrative remedies provided thereby before she could resort to the courts for relief. Thus, the trial court of equity properly denied jurisdiction of the controversy at this stage, before the landowner had availed herself of the administrative remedies under the ordinance.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed.

 

462 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Redfearn v. Board of State Canvassers


17497


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


234 S.C. 113; 107 S.E.2d 10; 1959 S.C. LEXIS 61



February 6, 1959, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Election contest. A defeated candidate for office of judge of probate of the county petitioned the Supreme Court for a writ of certiorari to review action of the board of state canvassers in certifying a write-in candidate for the office. The Supreme Court, Legge, J., held, inter alia, that where a voter scratched out the name of a party nominee and wrote on the ballot, opposite the name of the office, the name of the candidate for that office other than the party nominee, fact that the voter also put a cross or check mark in the party circle did not render the ballot invalid.

Petition dismissed.



DISPOSITION: Petition dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner, a losing candidate for probate judge, sought review of the results after respondent, a write-in candidate, won the general election. The County Board of Canvassers held that the write-in candidate was the winner. The losing candidate sought review with respondent Board of State Canvassers of South Carolina. The State Board ruled in the write-in candidate's favor. The losing candidate sought judicial review.


OVERVIEW: The losing candidate won the primary election against the write-in candidate. The court found that the write-in candidate possessed the qualifications for county probate judge under S.C. Const. art. I, § 10 (1895). The court held that assuming such voters could be identified, voters who did not support the losing candidate were not disqualified under S.C. Code Ann. § 23-379 (1952) for failing to support him in the general election. The court held that the election was to express voters' will, and the original ballots were the best evidence to show voters' intent. The court held that the statute that controlled marking a general election ballot, N.C. Code Ann. § 23-357, was directory only, and failure to follow it to the letter did not invalidate a ballot. The court held that voters who marked the party circle were still entitled to write in a candidate and did not have to scratch out the party nominee to make their vote valid. In dismissing the petition and affirming the result, the court found that the State Board's determining of voter intent regarding the write-in ballots was conclusive and amply sustained by the evidence.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the State Board's determination that the write-in candidate won the election for a county probate judgeship. The court dismissed the petition.

 

463 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Dean v. Timmerman


17490


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


234 S.C. 35; 106 S.E.2d 665; 1959 S.C. LEXIS 51



January 13, 1959, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Original petition for declaratory judgment regarding constitutionality of the 1958 State Appropriation Bill. The Supreme Court, Taylor, J., held, inter alia, that the provision that all roads designated for hard surfacing in state secondary highway system in any fiscal year "shall be selected from a list submitted during such year in writing by the Senator and at least one-half of the House Legislative Delegation of the county in which such roads may be located" is unconstitutional as encroaching upon powers of executive branch of the state government, but that the unconstitutionality of such provision did not render unconstitutional the remaining provisions of the act in view of legislative intent that State Highway Department should assume an increasing portion of burden of maintaining and operating secondary roads.

Judgment in accordance with opinion.



DISPOSITION: Judgment in accordance with opinion.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner taxpayer filed an original proceeding with the court (South Carolina), for a declaratory judgment regarding the constitutionality of a 1958 state appropriation bill regarding the improvement of the state highway system. The taxpayer contended that the use of a gas tax to fund the implementation of the bill encroached upon the powers of the executive branch of the state government.


OVERVIEW: The general assembly enacted a the 1958 session a state appropriation bill which provided for a gasoline tax. Some of the revenue was appropriated to the program for enlarging and improving the state secondary highway system under section seven of the act. The taxpayer petitioned the court for a declaratory judgment that the act was unconstitutional because it was in contravention of S.C. Const. art. I, § 14 by encroaching upon the powers of the state executive branch. The court granted the injunction and found under prior precedent the general assembly took discretionary acts in deciding what road would be constructed or improved and how they would be financed, which were clear violations of the state constitution. The court further held that the unconstitutionality of section seven did not render the remaining sections of the act unconstitutional.


OUTCOME: The court granted the injunction but held that the unconstitutionality of the provision did not render the remaining provisions of the act unconstitutional.

 

464 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Mullins Hospital v. Squires


17439


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


233 S.C. 186; 104 S.E.2d 161; 1958 S.C. LEXIS 64



June 11, 1958, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Action by a hospital for services rendered a deceased patient. From an order overruling a demurrer in the Common Pleas Court, Dillon County, J. Woodrow Lewis, J., the hospital appeals. The Supreme Court, Legge, J., held that the defendant was not entitled to amend his answer by adding thereto a proposed counterclaim in tort for negligence of the hospital's agents in view of the hospital's governmental immunity in tort but that the administrator was entitled to file a plea of recoupment in order to reduce the hospital's demand because of its alleged negligent failure to perform its contractual duty to the deceased as its patient.

Affirmed in part and reversed in part.



DISPOSITION: Affirmed in part and reversed in part.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant hospital sought review of the judgment of the Common Pleas Court, Dillon County (South Carolina), which overruled the hospital's demurrer to the answer of respondent administrator and granted the administrator's motion to amend his answer and counterclaim in tort against the hospital in the hospital's action that sought to recover fees for her treatment.


OVERVIEW: The hospital, a municipal corporation, commenced an action against the patient to recover fees for her treatment, but the patient died, so that the action was continued against the administrator of her estate. The hospital demurred to the administrator's answer, which was overruled, and the administrator moved to amend his answer and counterclaim in tort, which was granted. On appeal, the court reversed the order allowing the administrator to counterclaim in tort because the hospital had governmental immunity from negligence suits. However, the court affirmed the overruling of the hospital's demurrer because the administrator had clearly denied the obligation of the patient for the bill. Also, it was not error to overrule the demurrer as to the administrator's affirmative defense that claimed that the patient's bill arose because her stay was lengthened by the hospital's own negligence because, though immune form suit, the hospital voluntarily submitted itself to the trial court's jurisdiction and rendered available as a defense whatever claim the administrator had available that grew out of the same transaction as the hospital's suit.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the trial court, which overruled the hospital's demurrer to the answer of the administrator in the hospital's action that sought to recover fees for her treatment. The court reversed that part of the trial court's judgment that granted the administrator's motion to amend his answer and counterclaim in tort against the hospital.

 

465 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Elliott v. Sligh


17435


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


233 S.C. 161; 103 S.E.2d 923; 1958 S.C. LEXIS 61



June 4, 1958, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Action respecting constitutionality of statute which by its terms was applicable to only two counties in state and made it a criminal offense to sell or possess fireworks and declared such property to be contraband subject to confiscation. The Common Pleas Court, Richland County, Legare Bates, J., declared statute constitutional and there was an appeal. The Supreme Court, Oxner, J., held that statute which was an attempt to cope with problem which was state-wide in area, was a violation of constitutional prohibition against enactment by legislature of a special law in cases where a general law could be made applicable.

Reversed, act declared unconstitutional and respondents enjoined.



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, act declared unconstitutional and respondents enjoined.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant merchants sought review of an order of the Common Pleas Court, Richland County (South Carolina), which held that a statute making it a criminal offense in two counties to sell of possess fireworks and declaring such property to be contraband subject to confiscation, Act No. 190 of the 1957 Acts of the General Assembly of South Carolina, was special legislation in contravention of S.C. Const. art. III, § 34, subd. IX.


OVERVIEW: Act No. 190 of the 1957 Acts of the General Assembly, 50 St. at Large 204, made it a criminal offense to use, sell or possess fireworks in any county containing a municipality having a population of over 65,000 inhabitants. Only two counties had populations in excess of 65,000, and the merchants contended that the population limitation caused the statute to be special legislation in contravention of S.C. Const. art. III, § 34, subd. IX. The court reversed a trial court judgment that had declared the statute to be constitutional. It found that the conditions in the two counties that allegedly justified the legislation existed in all thickly settled areas. If the Legislature intended to remedy a condition peculiar to large, congested, unincorporated areas, there was no good reason for not extending the act to similar areas in other sections of the state. Moreover, the act was not confined to major cities but extended to rural sections in both counties, and there was no difference between conditions in those sections and conditions in adjoining counties. If there was need for further restriction on fireworks, it existed throughout the state and not just in the two largest counties.


OUTCOME: The order appealed from was reversed, Act No. 190 of the 1957 Acts of the General Assembly was declared unconstitutional, and its enforcement was enjoined.

 

466 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Colonial Life & Acci. Ins. Co. v. South Carolina Tax Com.


17428


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


233 S.C. 129; 103 S.E.2d 908; 1958 S.C. LEXIS 59



May 20, 1958, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] As Amended June 15, 1958.


PRIOR HISTORY: Action to recover taxes paid under protest. Judgment for the plaintiff in the Common Pleas Court, Richland County, William H. Grimball, J., and the tax commission appeals. The Supreme Court, Legge, J., held that though the act imposing a license tax on insurance companies was invalid due to a defect in title, where the Act was duly incorporated into the 1952 code, the deficiency became immaterial; that the act included in the term "personal property" shares or deposits in building and loan associations and municipal bonds; that the term "situated" as used in the statute had the same meaning as "situs", and that income received by the company from the ownership of deposits and shares in building and loan associations was not exempt as arising from "mortgage loans" within the statute.

Affirmed in part and reversed in part.



DISPOSITION: Affirmed in part and reversed in part.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant South Carolina Tax Commission appealed a judgment from the Common Pleas Court, Richland County (South Carolina), which ruled in favor of plaintiff taxpayer in an action to recover taxes paid by the taxpayer under protest.


OVERVIEW: The Commission assessed additional license taxes against the taxpayer, an insurance company, on the income received from its investments, which included deposits and shares in building and loan associations and municipal bonds. The taxpayer paid the assessed taxes under protest and brought an action pursuant to S.C. Code § 65-2662 (1952) to recover the taxes paid, alleging that the investments were not taxable personal property. The trial court ruled in favor of the taxpayer finding that the investments were not subject to taxation under S.C. Code § 65-932 (1952). The Commission appealed. On appeal, the court ruled that tangible property as well as intangible property, such as the taxpayer's municipal bonds and deposits and shares were all considered personal property under § 65-932. Thus, the taxpayer was liable for the tax assessments imposed upon the income derived from its intangible investments for the years 1950, 1952, and 1953. However, the court concluded that the taxpayer was not liable for the tax assessment for the year 1951 because the act under which it was assessed was not valid until is was incorporated into the 1952 South Carolina Code of Laws.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the part the trial court's judgment, which held that the tax assessment imposed for 1951 was invalid. The court reversed the part of the trial court's judgment, which ruled that the taxpayer's income from intangible property was not subject to the tax assessments imposed for the years 1950, 1952, and 1953.

 

467 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Crawford v. South Carolina Tax Com.


17363


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


232 S.C. 113; 101 S.E.2d 267; 1957 S.C. LEXIS 18



December 10, 1957, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] The South Carolina Tax Commission assessed inheritance taxes, and executors and beneficiaries of decedent's gifts appealed. The Supreme Court, Stukes, C. J., held that the statute providing that transfers of property by gift or deed between parties related by blood or marriage, made and completed within three years prior to death and without an adequate, valuable consideration, shall be considered as taxable transfers made in contemplation of death is unconstitutional as requiring assessment of gifts as a portion of estate, regardless of motivation of gifts and regardless of whether they were in fact made in contemplation of death.

Reversed and remanded with directions.



DISPOSITION: Reversed and remanded.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant executors and beneficiaries sought review of the decision of respondent South Carolina Tax Commission that assessed inheritance taxes on gifts given to them prior to the decedent's death.


OVERVIEW: The tax commission assessed taxes against the gifts given by the decedent up to three years prior to his death. The gifts were given to the executors and beneficiaries who appealed. The court reversed because it found that Section 65-464 of the Code of 1952, as amended in 1955 (South Carolina) that allowed the assessment was invalid. The statute was invalid because it made definitely conclusive that any gift within three years of death was made in contemplation of death, incapable of being overcome by proof. The court set aside the assessment and the tax commission was ordered to make a re-assessment of the estate for inheritance tax purposes without including the gifts which were previously taxed.


OUTCOME: The court reversed and remanded.

 

468 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Rogers-Kent, Inc. v. General Electric Co.


17341


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


231 S.C. 636; 99 S.E.2d 665; 1957 S.C. LEXIS 103



August 26, 1957, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] ction by retailer under the Uniform Declaratory Judgment Act to determine Constitutionality of State Fair Trade Act. The County Court, Richland County, Legare Bates, County Judge, held the act unconstitutional, and manufacturer appealed. The Supreme Court, Oxner, J., held that Fair Trade Act, as it applies to nonsigners, is unconstitutional as constituting a deprivation of property without due process of law.

Affirmed.



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant manufacturer appealed from a decision of the County Court, Richland County (South Carolina), which entered judgment in favor of plaintiff retailer in its action for a declaratory judgment seeking to have the Fair Trade Act, S.C. Code Ann. §§ 66-91 to 66-95 (1952) declared unconstitutional for depriving the manufacturer of property without due process of law under S.C. Const. art. 1, § 5.


OVERVIEW: The manufacturer contended that the Fair Trade Act, S.C. Code Ann. §§ 66-91 to 66-95 (1952) represented a reasonable and well considered exercise of the police power. The court affirmed the judgment. The court noted that the legislation could be justified only upon the theory that it constituted a reasonable and proper exercise of the inherent police power of the state, and pointed out that such power could only be exercised where it was reasonably necessary in the interests of the public order, health, safety, morals, or general welfare. The court held that that there was no justification for the legislation based upon considerations of the public health, safety, morals, and general welfare. The court concluded that the Fair Trade Act, id., insofar as it applied to the retailer, was unconstitutional upon the grounds that the Fair Trade Act, id., constituted a deprivation of property without due process of law in violation of S.C. Const. art. 1, § 5.
