OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the trial court in favor of the retailer in its action against the manufacturer seeking a declaration that the Fair Trade Act was unconstitutional.

 

469 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Mills Mill v. Hawkins


17312


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


232 S.C. 515; 103 S.E.2d 14; 1957 S.C. LEXIS 28



June 19, 1957, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Taxpayers brought actions against the members of the Una Water District Commission to have the act, which created a public corporation to be known as the "Una Water District," embracing a certain area in Spartanburg County adjacent to the City of Spartanburg, for purpose of having the territory served by publicly operated water and sewer systems, declared unconstitutional, on ground that it was special legislation in contravention of constitutional provision that no special law shall be enacted where a general law can be made applicable, and on ground that the act deprived the taxpayers of their property without due process of law and it denied them equal protection of the laws, in violation of state and federal constitutions. The Common Pleas Court, Spartanburg County, C. Bruce Littlejohn, J., entered an order upholding the constitutionality of the act, and the taxpayers appealed. The Supreme Court, Oxner, J., held that the act is not unconstitutional.

Exceptions overruled and order affirmed.

LEGGE, J. and G. DUNCAN BELLINGER, Acting Associate Justice, dissented.



DISPOSITION: Exceptions overruled and order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, taxpayers, sought review of an order from the Common Pleas Court, Spartanburg County (South Carolina), which entered an order upholding the constitutionality of 1955 S.C. Acts 582 that created a public corporation for the establishment of a publicly operated water and sewer system.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayers initiated complaints against respondents, members of the Water District Commission, to have 1955 S.C. Acts 582 declared unconstitutional on the ground that it was special legislation in contravention of S.C. Const. art. III, § 34(IX), the constitutional provision provided that no special law was to be enacted where a general law could be made applicable. The lower court entered an order upholding the constitutionality of 1955 S.C. Acts 582 and the taxpayers appealed. The court affirmed the lower court order because it found that the legislative effort to remove the unsanitary conditions that prevailed in the locale by the special legislation was obnoxious to S.C. Const. art. III, § 34(IX.) There was no general law applicable to the specific location concerning the development of a water district to remove the unsanitary conditions. The court concluded that the right of the sovereign to improve water and sewer facilities was paramount and was not a flagrant abuse of legislative discretion.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the lower court order which upheld the constitutionality of a statute that created a special district for the development of a water and sewer system.

 

470 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Boykin v. Camden


17304


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


231 S.C. 325; 98 S.E.2d 755; 1957 S.C. LEXIS 66



June 5, 1957, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Suit for injunctive relief. The Common Pleas Court, Kershaw County, T. B. Greneker, J., sustained a demurrer to the complaint, and the petitioners appealed. The Supreme Court, Taylor, J., held that complaint, to enjoin condemnation of petitioners' property for purpose of establishing off-street municipal parking lot, had been insufficient to raise issues beyond scope of procedural act.

Affirmed.



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.

 

471 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Stevenson v. Board of Adjustment


17249


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


230 S.C. 440; 96 S.E.2d 456; 1957 S.C. LEXIS 114



January 17, 1957, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Proceeding in review of decision of Municipal Zoning Board of Adjustment. The Common Pleas Court of Charleston County, E. H. Henderson, J., entered judgment, and all parties appealed. The Supreme Court, Moss, J., held, in part, that granting of variance by Zoning Board of Adjustment to church for construction and occupancy of addition for Sunday school was not abuse of discretion, where literal enforcement of provisions of zoning ordinance against church would cause singular disadvantage to church, which required enlargement to accommodate increased membership, and added occupancy would not exceed the fifty percent of lot area limitation imposed by ordinance, but that limitation by board of use of building as day school to 270 students was reasonable and would be upheld.

Judgment modified and affirmed and case remanded.



DISPOSITION: Judgment modified and affirmed. Case remanded.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant property owners challenged a decision of the Common Pleas Court of Charleston County (South Carolina), which upheld the action of respondent Municipal Zoning Board of Adjustment (board) in granting the building and occupancy permit applied for by respondent church and struck out the condition which limited the occupancy of the educational building to 270 day students.


OVERVIEW: In a proceeding to review a decision of the board, the lower court entered a judgment upholding the granting of a variance to the church for the construction and occupancy of an addition and striking down the condition which limited the occupancy of the addition. The property owners appealed. The court held that the board's granting of the variance to the church for construction and occupancy of an addition for Sunday school was not an abuse of discretion where literal enforcement of the provisions of the zoning ordinance against the church would cause singular disadvantage to the church, which required enlargement to accommodate increased membership, and the added occupancy would not exceed the fifty percent of lot area limitation imposed by the ordinance. The court found that the limitation by the board of use of the building as a day school to 270 students was reasonable and would be upheld. The judgment was modified and affirmed and the case remanded.


OUTCOME: On appeal by the property owners, the court modified the lower court's judgment and affirmed and remanded, holding that the lower court properly upheld the board's granting of a variance to the church for the construction and occupancy of an addition, but that the lower court erred in striking down the reasonable condition which limited the occupancy of the building.

 

472 of 598 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Thompson v. Seigler


17203


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


230 S.C. 115; 94 S.E.2d 231; 1956 S.C. LEXIS 101



August 23, 1956, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Original proceeding to determine validity of Governor's order suspending sheriff from office until sheriff was acquitted of charges against him contained in federal indictment. The Supreme Court, Taylor, J., held that act providing for removal of any state or county officer from office who is indicted in any court for any crime is not unconstitutional as a denial of due process and equal protection of laws or on ground that act is a delegation of legislative power to federal government or that of a sister state, and consequently executive order of Governor issued pursuant to provisions of the act was valid.

Order accordingly.

OXNER, J., dissented.



DISPOSITION: Complaint dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff suspended sheriff (sheriff) filed an action against defendants, State of South Carolina and temporary sheriff, to determine the validity of an order issued by the Governor of South Carolina suspending the sheriff until he was acquitted of charges against him contained in a federal indictment.


OVERVIEW: The Governor suspended the sheriff after he was indicted by a federal grand jury for interfering with a federal grand juror and with a violation of the federal Internal Revenue Liquor Laws. Upon review, the court determined that the South Carolina Constitution provided no mode for removal of sheriffs for incapacity, misconduct or neglect of duty. Therefore, such removal could be provided by the legislature, which was done pursuant to 49 St. at Large, p. 1841 (S.C.). In addition, the court determined that although the Governor did not have unlimited power of removal or the power of arbitrary and indefinite suspension, because the suspension was within the contemplation of art. 3, § 27 of the South Carolina Constitution, as to incapacity, misconduct, or neglect of duty as authorized by 49 St. at Large, p. 1841 (S.C.), and because the suspension was neither arbitrary nor indefinite, it was proper as a provision was made for the exercise of the power in the interim. Finally, the court concluded that 49 St. at Large, p. 1841 (S.C.) was not unconstitutional, did not deny due process or equal protection of the laws, and was not a delegation of legislative power.


OUTCOME: The court issued an order declaring that the suspension order was valid.

 

473 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Dantzler v. Callison


17200


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


230 S.C. 75; 94 S.E.2d 177; 1956 S.C. LEXIS 99



August 20, 1956, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Original action was brought in the Supreme Court by Naturopaths against the Attorney General of South Carolina for a declaratory judgment as to their rights and to have act making it unlawful for any person, whether previously licensed or not, to practice Naturopathy in the State, unless he meets prescribed qualifications, declared unconstitutional. The Supreme Court, T. B. Greneker, Acting Associate Justice, held that act does not deprive Naturopaths of their property rights without due process of law, or deny them equal protection of the law.

Act declared constitutional.

COMPLAINT

Plaintiffs complaining of the defendant allege:

1. Plaintiffs are citizens of the United States of America and the State of South Carolina and are officers and members of the South Carolian Naturopathic Association, Inc., a Corporation created under the laws of the State of South Carolina. This action is brought by plaintiffs in their official capacity, and also individually for the benefit of themselves and all members of the Association and all duly licensees who are practicing in the State under a duly issued and lawful license. Membership in the Association is confined solely and [***2] exclusively to regularly licensed Naturopathic Practitioners in South Carolina. Doctors M. S. Dantzler and J. B. Branyon and W. T. Bidwell are the Board of Examiners. All of the plaintiffs as individuals have been naturopathic physicians under the law of South Carolina since 1937. All of the licensed Naturopathic Physicians in South Carolina, except the last ten licensees, were admitted to practice in compliance with the law prior to June, 1946. The last ten practitioners were admitted under the amended Naturopathy Act of 1949, which greatly increased the education and professional qualification of applicants.

2. The defendant, Honorable T. C. Callison, is Attorney General of South Carolina, and is made a party defendant in pursuance of Section 10-2008 of the South Carolina Code of 1952, as this is an action seeking a declaratory judgment as to the rights of the plaintiffs and to declare unconstitutional the Act of the General Assembly of South Carolina as follows:

"An Act To Repeal Sections 56-901 Through 56-919, Code Of Laws Of South Carolina, 1952, Relating To The Practice of Naturopathy; To Make It Unlawful For Certain Persons To Practice Naturopathy In This State; And [***3] To Provide Penalties For Violating The Provisions Of This Act."

The body of the Act reads as follows:

"Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of South Carolina:

"Section 1. Sections 56-901 through 56-919, Code of Laws of South Carolina, 1952, are hereby repealed.

"Section 2. It shall be unlawful for any person whether heretofore licensed or not under the laws of this or any other state to practice naturopathy in this State; Provided, however, that any person now authorized to practice naturopathy in South Carolina who is a graduate of an accredited college for pre-medical training and who has, in addition thereto, graduated from a medical college recognized at the time of his graduation by the state in which it was located, and who has heretofore for a period in excess of five years engaged in the practice of medicine in the State of South Carolina under the supervision of a licensed medical doctor by special request or by special permission of the State Board of Medical Examiners, or agents thereof, shall be examined by the State Board of Medical Examiners on the same basis as other applicants to the Board are examined, and upon the making of a passing [***4] grade on this examination, shall be licensed to practice medicine in this State.

"Section 3. Any person violating the provisions of Section 2 of this act shall, upon conviction, be guilty of a misdemeanor and be fined not exceeding five hundred dollars or be imprisoned for a period of not exceeding one year or both in the discretion of the court.

"Section 4. All acts or parts of acts inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed.

"Section 5. This act shall take effect upon its approval by the Governor. [In the Senate House the 23rd day of February In the Year of Our Lord One Thousand Nine Hundred and Fifty-six.]

3. Plaintiffs allege that the act in question is in violation of their rights as citizens of the United States of America and of South Carolina as provided in the Fifth and Fourteenth Amendments of the United States Constitution in that it deprives the plaintiffs of their property and property rights without due process of law, and denies them of the equal protection of the laws and is arbitrary and discriminatory in that it singles out naturopathy, one of a number of special practitioners in the art of healing and abolishes their profession only.

4.  [***5] Plaintiffs further allege that the Act in question violates the following provisions of the Constitution of the State of South Carolina: Article 1, Section 5; Article 1, Section 17, and Section 17, Article 3 in that said Act deprives plaintiffs of their property and property rights without due process of law and denies them of the equal protection of the laws and is arbitrary and discriminatory in that it singles out naturopathy, one of a number of special practitioners in the art of healing and abolishes their profession only. With reference to Section 17, Article 3 of the Constitution of South Carolina of 1895 plaintiffs allege that the Act violates this Section in that it relates to more than one subject which is not expressed in the title. The proviso in the Act deals with a specific provision for the licensing of medical doctors, which in no way has any connection with the title of the Act and such proviso discriminates within the Naturopathic Practitioners.

5. Plaintiffs further allege that all of the Naturopathic Physicians in South Caarolina entered the practice as a means of livelihood for themselves and to support their families. They have invested much time and great [***6] sums of money, more or less, in perfecting themselves for the practice of their profession. Section 56-901 of the South Carolina Code of 1952 defines Naturopathy as follows:

"'Naturopathy' is hereby defined to mean the use and practice of phychological, mechanical and material health sciences to aid in purifying, cleaning and normalizing human tissues for preservation or restoration of health according to the fundamental principles of anatomy, physiology and applied psychology, as may be required. Naturopathic practice employs, among other agencies, heat, light, water, electricity, psychology, diet, massage and other manipulative methods."

Naturopathy has been recognized by the Legislative Law of South Carolina since the Medical Practice Act of March 10, 1920, and to do the things permitted under the Act of necessity requires the use of equipment for the employment of such agencies as heat, light, water, electricity, psychology, diet, massage and other manipulative methods and all of the plaintiffs and those whom they represent have spent large amounts of money, more or less, in the purchase of necessary equipment, which they use in the practice of their profession.

6.  [***7] Plaintiffs recognize the right of the Legislature to regulate their profession by the passage of any regulatory methods within the constitutional limits. Plaintiffs allege, however, that the above entitled Act destroys their profession and means of livelihood and would make acts which are perfectly lawful to become criminal acts subject to punishment by the court upon conviction. The Act in question is prohibitory and not regulatory in a field of Medical practice and/or art of healing that could be and can be properly regulated.

7. That plaintiffs are entitled to have the Supreme Court declare their rights and to pass upon the constitutionality of the above statute and to further declare the same null and void because of its violation of plaintiffs' constitutional rights.

Wherefore, plaintiffs pray for relief as follows:

(1) A judgment of this Court declaring the aforesaid Act to be unconstitutional and therefore null and void;

(2) For a judgment by the Court declaring the rights of the plaintiffs and to order and command the Attorney General and all law enforcement officers in the State of South Carolina not to in any manner interfere with the plaintiffs in the [***8] practice of their lawful profession;

(3) For such other and further relief as the plaintiffs may be entitled to under the circumstances of this case.

ANSWER

The Defendant, T. C. Callison, Attorney General of the State of South Carolina, answering the Complaint herein, respectfully shows to the Court:

1. That he denies all allegations of the Complaint not hereinafter admitted, qualified or explained.

2. That, upon information and belief, he admits the allegations of Paragraph 1 of the Complaint.

3. That he admits the allegations of Paragraph 2 of the Complaint.

4. That he denies the allegations of Paragraphs 3 and 4 of the Complaint.

5. Answering Paragraph 5 of the Complaint upon information and belief, this defendant admits that the plaintiffs are claiming to be Naturopathic physicians practicing in South Carolina as a means of livelihood and as a means of support to their families. The defendant admits that Sec. 56-901 of the 1952 Code of the State as amended, reads as set out and that Naturopathy has been recognized in various forms in the State since 1920; further, upon information and belief, this defendant admits the use of [***9] such equipment, as is referred to in Paragraph 5 of the Complaint, is employed by Naturopaths but has no knowledge of the sums invested therein.

6. This defendant admits so much of Paragraph 6 of the Complaint as alleges that the Act in question destroys the practice of Naturopathy as a separate cult, branch or profession of the healing art, and admits that it makes unlawful certain acts by plaintiffs, otherwise lawful, but lawful only to those qualified as general medical practitioners, or those qualified in specialized branches of the healing arts under the requirements of our laws, but the defendant alleges that the provisions of the said Act, the purpose of which is to protect the public's health and welfare, are within the police power of the State, are a valid exercise of said police power, and are neither arbitrary nor discriminatory.

7. Further answering the Complaint, this defendant alleges that the State has a vital concern in the health of everyone within its borders, the practice of medicine and healing being one of the fields peculiarly subject to control and regulation under the police powers of this and every other government. That the practice of medicine [***10] and of the healing arts can be lawfully prohibited by the State except upon the conditions imposed by it, which said conditions are subject to change from time to time to keep pace with the advance of educational and scientific progress, the plaintiffs and no other persons having any fundamental or property rights to engage in any form of the healing arts free from regulation, such as is true of those employments and trades not peculiarly within the concern of the police power.

8. That the plaintiffs have no contractual or property right granted to them by any pre-existing laws of this State allowing the practice of Naturopathy or granting licenses to them which are not subject to modification or denial in the proper exercise of the police power of the State in its promotion of the public health, plaintiffs' licenses creating in them no permanent or vested interest, such licenses not being within the inhibition against impairment of contract, and being revocable under the police power at the discretion of the sovereignty.

9. That the mere fact that the plaintiffs may suffer pecuniary injury because of the proper exercise of the police power of the State in forbidding the [***11] practice of Naturopathy in South Carolina, does not render the Act unconstitutional, because all private property is held and all callings are exercised in this State subject to the proper exercise of the police power of the State.

10. That the prohibition of the practice of Naturopathy as a separate branch of the healing art is a proper application of the police power of the State to a particular class practicing arts peculiar to themselves, there being no means of any practical regulation due to the close and confidential nature of the relationship between the Naturopath and patient with the consequent impossibility of supervising and confining such practice within lawful bounds.

11. That the Act in question does not prevent plaintiffs from practicing any lawful branch or type of healing formerly open to them as Naturopaths, as they may still, upon qualifying as medical doctors under the laws of this State, practice all lawful forms of healing and treatment, the Act making special provisions for those who have had proper medical training to take the examinations provided for medical doctors, with other laws leaving open the taking of these examinations by those who qualify [***12] themselves therefor hereafter.

12. That the Act attacked by the plaintiffs applies equally to all persons now practicing Naturopathy and that said classification is reasonable, operating alike on all within its provisions. That the Act is not discriminatory and does not deny the equal protection of the law to those within the class upon which it operates, there being no duty upon the State to recognize all peculiar schools and groups of those seeking to practice healing arts.

13. That the practice of medicine is not a Federal privilege or immunity within the purview of the Fourteenth Amendment to the Constitution of the United States, and is peculiarly within the control of the State and not of the United States.

14. That the title of the Act clearly shows its purpose and discloses to anyone interested that it is prohibiting the practice of Naturopathy in this State, relating to that one subject or matters fully germane thereto, in accordance with the provisions of Article III, Section 17 of the Constitution of this State.

Wherefore, this defendant prays that the Honorable Court do adjudge and decree that the Act in question is constitutional and valid in all respects [***13] and binding upon the plaintiffs and all others seeking to practice any form of the so-called Naturopathic Profession.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, an association of naturopathic physicians and its president, sought a declaration to defendant Attorney General that "An Act To Repeal §§ 56-901-56-919, Code Of Laws Of South Carolina, 1952, Relating To The Practice Of Naturopathy; To Make It Unlawful For Certain Persons To Practice Naturopathy In This State; And To Provide Penalties For Violating The Provisions Of This Act" was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiffs alleged that they represented licensed naturopathic physicians who were admitted to practice in compliance with the law prior to June, 1946. They sought a declaratory judgment as to their rights, contending that the Act to repeal the prior law was in violation of the Fifth and Fourteenth Amendments of the Constitution of the United States in that it deprived them of their property rights without due process of law and denied equal protection of the law. They asserted that the Act in dispute was arbitrary and discriminatory in singling out naturopathy. The court found no merit to the claims. The court concluded that the State had an interest in regulating and licensing health practitioners. The new law repealed prior provisions pertaining to the profession, and it put in place new and additional licensing requirements needed to protect the public. The disputed law was a valid exercise of the State's police powers. The court noted that naturopathy was of comparatively recent recognition and that the State has the right to control the practice in the field.


OUTCOME: The court denied relief to plaintiffs upon finding that the Act was constitutional.

 

474 of 598 DOCUMENTS


State v. Jiles


17190


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


230 S.C. 148; 94 S.E.2d 891; 1956 S.C. LEXIS 110



July 17, 1956, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Defendants were convicted, in the Court of General Sessions of Georgetown County, G. Duncan Bellinger, J., of illegal possession of intoxicating liquor in their place of business, and they appealed. The Supreme Court, Legge, J., held that admission of deputy sheriff's testimony as to attack made on him by defendants when liquor was discovered, and comment thereon in argument, were proper.

Affirmed.



DISPOSITION: Exceptions overruled and judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants, who were husband and wife, were tried and convicted in the Court of General Sessions for Georgetown County (South Carolina) upon an indictment charging possession of alcoholic liquor in their place of business, which was not a licensed liquor store, a violation of South Carolina Code 1952, § 4-95. The husband was sentenced to serve two years in jail and the wife one. They appealed.


OVERVIEW: A police officer, while checking defendants' store, went behind the counter and found whiskey. He then walked into an adjacent room, and he testified that he found there a bag on the floor with whiskey in it. He testified that the husband then attacked him; his pistol fell to the floor; the wife grabbed the pistol and ran; when he freed himself, he went and called for help; and when a second officer arrived, they found neither the husband nor the liquor. Defendants disputed the officer's testimony as to what took place in the room. On the instant appeal, the court held that the trial judge did not abuse his discretion in refusing a motion for continuance made on the ground that publication of indictments against defendants for assault and battery and grand larceny, presumably within the jury panel's hearing, was prejudicial. It held that the trial judge did not err in overruling defendants' objections to the officer's testimony as to the attack and as to the disappearance of the liquor. The court found no merit in exceptions that charged that the trial judge erred in charging the jury the rule of law as to aiders and abettors and that charged that the sentences were excessive.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed.

 

475 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Douglas v. Hall


17180


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


229 S.C. 550; 93 S.E.2d 891; 1956 S.C. LEXIS 83



July 5, 1956, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Habeas corpus proceeding by one who had been adjudged insane and committed to custody of superintendent of state hospital. The County Court of Richland County, Legare Bates, County Judge, ordered release of petitioner and the superintendent of the state hospital appealed. The Supreme Court, Legge, J., held that fact issue of petitioner's sanity could not be considered in habeas corpus proceeding.

Reversed.

TAYLOR, J., dissented.



DISPOSITION: Reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant, the superintendent of the South Carolina State Hospital, sought review of a judgment from the County Court of Richland County (South Carolina) that ordered the release of respondent, a state hospital patient, in the patient's habeas corpus proceeding.


OVERVIEW: The patient's wife filed an application to adjudge the patient insane. The patient was examined by two physicians, and the Probate Court issued an order adjudging him insane and committing him to the State Hospital. Less than three months later, the patient filed an application with the trial court for a writ of habeas corpus. He claimed that he had been illegally committed to the State Hospital and that he was not insane and could establish his sanity upon a fair and impartial hearing. The superintendent asserted that the writ should be discharged because respondent had not exhausted the remedy available to him under § 32-930 of the 1952 Code, 1955 Supplement (S.C.). The trial court overruled that contention and adjudged the patient sane and ordered his release. The superintendent appealed, and the court reversed the trial court's judgment. A writ of habeas corpus could not be converted into an inquisition of lunacy if by statute an adequate remedy was provided whereby one that had been adjudged insane could litigate the issue of his return to sanity. Such a remedy was available in the Act of March 7, 1952, 1955 Code Supplement, §§ 32-909 through 32-932 (S.C.).


OUTCOME: The court reversed the trial court's judgment.

 

476 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Wright v. Florence


17170


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


229 S.C. 419; 93 S.E.2d 215; 1956 S.C. LEXIS 70



June 5, 1956, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Action by two members of Civil Service Commission against city and chiefs of police and fire departments for declaratory judgments of invalidity of ordinance repealing ordinance whereby Civil Service Commission was established and for injunction. The Common Pleas Court, Florence County, G. Badger Baker, J., entered judgment adverse to city and city appealed. The Supreme Court, Stukes, C. J., held that where statute provided that municipality may by ordinance provide for Civil Service Commission, power of city to establish Civil Service Commission was permissive, statute did not prevent council from repealing its ordinance creating commission and power of repeal was implied.

Judgment reversed and injunction dissolved.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed and injunction dissolved.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant city sought review of a judgment of the Common Pleas Court, Florence County (South Carolina), which found that respondents, members of the Civil Service Commission, were entitled to an injunction on the basis that a city ordinance repealing the Civil Service Commission was invalid.


OVERVIEW: Under § 7546 of the Code of 1942, as amended, the city council had adopted a 1950 ordinance whereby a Civil Service Commission was established. In 1955, however, the city council enacted an ordinance whereby the civil service ordinance of 1950 was expressly repealed. The members' terms of office had not expired, and they sought to prevent the city from enforcing the repeal. On review, the court found that the city should have prevailed because it had the power to repeal such an ordinance. The members had no vested constitutional, contractual rights preventing such a repeal, nor was there any statutory bar to the repeal. The city's authorization under its charter to establish the Civil Service Commission was permissive. Under Article 2, § 47-721 et seq., Code of 1952, the city could by ordinance provide for a Civil Service Commission. Neither the charter nor the statute prevented the city from repealing its former ordinance. The city could terminate the members' jobs as part of the Commission.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment and dissolved the injunction.

 

477 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Watson v. Orangeburg


17163


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


229 S.C. 367; 93 S.E.2d 20; 1956 S.C. LEXIS 62



May 17, 1956, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Action by private citizen against city and certain other persons who were allegedly illegally made exempt from taxes due city by allegedly unconstitutional ordinance, for judgment compelling city to collect taxes from such persons, and for certain ancillary relief. The Common Pleas Court, Orangeburg County, T. B. Greneker, J., entered decree favorable to plaintiff, and defendants appealed. The Supreme Court, Legge, J., held that private citizen, whose taxes were allegedly illegally increased by adoption by city of unconstitutional ordinance exempting certain other persons from taxes due city, could not maintain action against city and such persons to compel city to collect taxes from such persons.

Reversed and remanded for dismissal.



DISPOSITION: Reversed and remanded.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, a city and private citizens, sought review of a decree of the Common Pleas Court, Orangeburg County (South Carolina), which held that certain ordinances granting a tax exemption to the citizens were unconstitutional, null and void, and which directed the city to collect from the citizens all unpaid taxes exempt under the ordinances. Respondent taxpayer brought the action on behalf of the city.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayer claimed that the citizens were illegally made exempt from taxes due to the city by unconstitutional ordinances. He brought an action in equity seeking to have the ordinances declared unconstitutional and to have the city be required to collect such taxes from the citizens. On appeal, the court held that the taxpayer's case was predicated upon the theory that because the city failed to assess and collect taxes from the citizens, the taxpayer himself had the right, for the benefit of the city and its other taxpayers, to collect them individually, and, if necessary, to enforce the city's tax lien through the medium of a receiver to be appointed by the court at his instance. In addition, the power to collect taxes due to the city from its citizens could not be delegated by the city without express statutory authority, and a fortiori the power to collect taxes could not be exercised by a private citizen. As a result, the taxpayer could not maintain an action against the city and the citizens to compel the collection of taxes from the citizens.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the trial court's decree and remanded the matter for the entry of orders of dismissal.

 

478 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Dunham v. Davis


17121


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


229 S.C. 29; 91 S.E.2d 716; 1956 S.C. LEXIS 23



February 20, 1956, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Action to recover possession of realty from defendant and to obtain damages resulting from defendant's alleged unlawful entry and continued trespass thereon. Defendant claimed title under tax deed and by adverse possession and sought foreclosure of mortgage held by him on the realty, together with reimbursement for tax payments made by him. The Common Pleas Court, Marion County, Steve C. Griffith, J., ruled that defendant's claim of title under tax deed was invalid, but submitted to jury issue of adverse possession, and then granted plaintiffs' motion for judgment notwithstanding verdict for defendant on issue of adverse possession, and defendant appealed. The Supreme Court, Legge, J., held that evidence upon issue of adverse possession was sufficient for jury as to certain plaintiffs but was fully lacking as to other plaintiffs.

Judgment affirmed and cause remanded for further proceedings consistent with opinion.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed and cause remanded.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent decedent's heirs filed an action against appellant mortgagee to recover real property from the mortgagee and for damages for unlawful entry and trespass. The mortgagee sought review of the order of the Common Pleas Court, Marion County (South Carolina), which granted the heirs' motion for judgment notwithstanding the verdict.


OVERVIEW: The decedent owned a tract of land at the time of his death. The heirs executed a promissory note and mortgage on behalf of the mortgagee. The mortgagee obtained a tax deed to the property. The heirs claimed that the mortgagee unlawfully entered and trespassed on the property. The mortgagee claimed title under the tax deed, the mortgage, and by adverse possession. The trial court found that the tax deed was invalid and that the mortgagee was not entitled to adverse possession. The court affirmed the trial court's judgment. The court held that the tax collector levied on the property against the decedent's estate, that there was no estate, that the tax sale in the name of the estate was void, that the two-year statute of limitations under S.C. Code § 65-2779 (1952) was not applicable, and that the mortgagee did not acquire title under the tax deed. The court also held that the mortgagee was required to give notice of adverse possession as an owner and not as a mortgagee, that the evidence was lacking on the issue of adverse possession as to all but three heirs, and that remand was required for a trial on the issues relating to the note and mortgage.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's judgment as to the mortgagee's claims under the tax deed and by adverse possession. The court remanded to the trial court for a trial on the issues relating to the mortgagee's claims under the note and mortgage.

 

479 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Edens v. Columbia


17111


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


228 S.C. 563; 91 S.E.2d 280; 1956 S.C. LEXIS 14



January 30, 1956, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Action under Uniform Declaratory Judgments Act to test constitutionality of certain features of the Redevelopment Law. The Common Pleas Court, Richland County, T. K. McDonald, Special Judge, entered judgment for the housing authority and plaintiffs appealed. The Supreme Court, Stukes, J., held that where purpose of proceedings under the Redevelopment Law was not to provide better low-cost housing to occupants of area but to transform it from low class residential area to commercial and industrial area, exercise of power of eminent domain for execution of redevelopment plan would be unconstitutional.

Judgment reversed in part and affirmed in part; and case remanded with directions.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed, affirmed and case remanded.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant landowners sought review of an order from the Common Pleas Court, Richland County (South Carolina) that granted respondent Housing Authority of the City of Columbia (city) judgment in an action to test constitutionality of certain features of the Redevelopment Act (Act), S.C. Code Ann. § .36-401 et seq. (1952).


OVERVIEW: The city proceeded under the exercise of power of eminent domain to transform a low class residential area into a commercial and industrial area. The landowners filed an action against the city seeking declaratory judgment to test constitutionality of certain features of the Act. The trial court entered a judgment for the city. The landowners appealed. The court reversed in part and affirmed in part. The judgment was reversed except insofar as it affected the land that would be conveyed to the university, as to which it was affirmed. The court held that where the purpose of proceedings under the Act was not to provide better low-cost housing to occupants of area but to transform it from low class residential area to commercial and industrial area, exercise of power of eminent domain for execution of redevelopment plan would be unconstitutional. Congress did not in the Act confer power to seize property beyond the reasonable necessities of slum clearance and prevention, which were injurious to the public health, safety, morals and welfare.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed in part and reversed in part the order of the trial court that granted the city judgment in an action filed by the landowners to test constitutionality of certain features of the Act.

 

480 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Raggio v. Woodmen of World Life Ins. Soc.


17088


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


228 S.C. 340; 90 S.E.2d 212; 1955 S.C. LEXIS 108



November 17, 1955, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Action to recover under life insurance certificate issued by fraternal benefit association. The Common Pleas Court, York County, Joseph R. Moss, J., overruled plaintiff's demurrer to answer, and plaintiff appealed. The Supreme Court, Legge, J., held that statute providing that insurers, after two years from date of issuance of policy or certificate of insurance, are deemed to have waived right to dispute truth of representations in application was applicable to and binding on fraternal benefit association.

Reversed.

TAYLOR, J., and BAKER, C. J., dissented.

The following is the order of Judge Moss:

This action was brought by the plaintiff under a Summons and Complaint bearing date July 22, 1952. The complaint sets up a cause of action for recovery by the plaintiff against the defendant on a policy of life insurance in the face amount of Three Thousand and no/100 Dollars ($ 3,000.00) upon the life of William S. Pursley, the husband at that time of the plaintiff.

Following issuance of the policy William S. Pursley died in less than six months or on the 14th day of July, 1950. Thereafter proof of death was furnished to the defendant along with the original certificate [***2] of insurance, and demand was made for the face amount of the said policy in the sum of $ 3,000.00 to the plaintiff, as the beneficiary named in the said policy. On January 4, 1951, the defendant rejected the claim on the ground that material misrepresentations were made in the application for the benefit certificate and upon all other grounds on which this association was entitled to deny liability thereunder, and tendered to plaintiff a return of premiums paid in the amount of $ 49.02, which the plaintiff refused to accept.

The defendant by its Answer admitted it was a fraternal benefit society incorporated under the laws of the State of Nebraska, with a lodge system, a ritualistic form of work, and a representative form of government; without capital stock, and transacts its business without profit for the sole benefit of its members and their beneficiaries. The Answer alleges that such fraternal benefit societies are governed by specific statutes applying to them, and exempting it from the general insurance laws of the State of South Carolina; that the Woodmen of the World Life Insurance Society is authorized and licensed to transact business in South Carolina as a fraternal [***3] benefit association.

The Answer admits that benefit certificate No. 2104736, a preferred risk whole life certificate, in the principal sum of $ 3,000.00, was issued to William S. Pursley on January 27, 1950, and admits that the plaintiff Vera Hall Pursley, was named beneficiary in the said certificate.

The Answer admits that William S. Pursley departed this life on July 14, 1950, but specifically denied that the certificate issued to the said William S. Pursley was in force at the time of his death, and the defendant further alleges that certain material misrepresentations were made by William S. Pursley on January 16, 1950, in the application for such certificate, and in accordance with the terms thereof, the said certificate issued was null and void, and the defendant has, therefore, refused to pay the same.

The Answer further alleges that in the written application for membership in the defendant society, and for the issuance to him of a preferred risk whole life certificate in the sum of $ 3,000.00 there appeared a number of questions and answers, including whether the applicant had ever used alcoholic liquors to excess, or taken treatment for liquor habit; had ever [***4] been under the observation, care or treatment in any hospital, sanitorium, or similar institution; whether the applicant in the past ten years had any mental or bodily disease or infirmity, or had consulted, been attended, or examined by any physician; whether the applicant had, or had ever, had high blood pressure, paralysis, tuberculosis, diabetes, or other chronic disease; or any other disease, and whether the applicant was then in good health, all of which questions were answered "No", and that the applicant further declared in writing in the said application that he had read the foregoing questions and answers thereto, and represented that each of the said answers is full, complete, and true. That upon receipt and acceptance of the said written application the Society, relying upon the statements and representations, including the answers under the heading of "Personal History" as made by the said William S. Pursley, issued to him its preferred risk whole life certificate No. 2104736 under date of January 27, 1950, in the amount of $ 3,000.00. That under the terms of the benefit certificate, the constitution, laws and by-laws of the Society constitute a part thereof, and it is [***5] expressly provided in the said certificate that "this certificate is issued in consideration of the application therefor, including the statement of insurability, a copy of which is attached hereto and made a part hereof."

The defendant further alleged upon information and belief that the answers to the questions set out in the application were untrue; that the applicant, William S. Pursley, prior to January 16, 1950, had used alcoholic liquors to excess, had suffered from hypertension or hypertensive cardiovascular disease, cirrhosis of the liver, had consulted physicians, and had been under their care and treatment in and out of hospitals, suffered from high blood pressure, and was not in good health at the time of making the said application.

That the said certificate upon which the plaintiff's claim was issued by the defendant in reliance upon the truth of the material representations, which were untrue, and that in accordance with the terms of the application, the benefit certificate, the constitution, laws, and by-laws, the certificate was null and void, and asked that the Complaint be dismissed.

To this Answer the plaintiff demurred to the Answer upon the following [***6] grounds:

1. That the Answer of the defendant sets up and alleges as a sole defense to the cause of action stated in the Complaint an averment that material misrepresentations affecting the risk and hazard assumed by the defendant society was made by the insured in his application for insurance and that as a result thereof the policy admittedly issued is null and void.

2. That such defense is not available to the Defendant society under the provisions of Section 37-161 of the Code of Laws of South Carolina for 1952, other applicable laws and decisions and the terms of the policy as modified thereby, as more than two years have elapsed from the date of issuance of the Certificate of insurance on the 27th day of January, 1950, no proceeding has been instituted to vacate said Certificate on such grounds and the right to interpose any such defense is therefore deemed and taken to have been waived by operation of law.

The hearing on the Demurrer was had before me on July 8, 1953, at which plaintiff's and defendants' attorneys appeared and made full argument.

In order to pass upon the validity of the grounds of the Demurrer it is necessary and enlightening to review the [***7] history of Section 37-161 of the Code of Laws of South Carolina for 1952, commencing with Section 7986 of the Code of Laws of South Carolina for 1942, which is as follows:

"When may dispute truth of application and representations for life insurance, disability, etc.--All life insurance companies, fraternal benefit associations or any other company, corporation or association by whatever name known, who issues a policy or certificate of insurance on the life of a person shall, after a period of two (2) years from the date of such policy or certificate of insurance, be deemed and taken to have waived any right they may have had to dispute the truth of the application for insurance, or that the assured person had made false representations shall be deemed and taken to be true; provided, that where any such policy shall contain, in addition to life insurance, agreements for indemnity or benefits for disability, or any other coverage, the provisions of this section shall apply to such agreements with the same force and effect as to the life insurance coverage of such policy."

This Section was repealed by Act No. 232, page 322, of the Acts and Joint Resolutions of 1947, and replaced [***8] by Section 51 of Article I, on page 344 of the Acts of 1947, which reads as follows:

"When May Dispute Truth of Application and Represensations for Life Insurance, Disability, Etc.--misstatement of age.--All companies, which issue a policy or certificate of insurance on the life of a person shall, after a period of two (2) years from the date of such policy or certificate of insurance, be deemed and taken to have waived any right they may have had to dispute the truth of the application for insurance, or that the assured person had made false representations and the said application and representations shall be deemed and taken to be true: Provided, that this Section shall not apply to the misstatement of age by the insured: Provided, Further, that where any such policy shall contain, in addition to life insurance, agreements for indemnity or benefits for disability, or any other coverage, the provisions of this Section shall apply to such agreements with the same force and effect as to the life insurance coverage of such policy."

Thereafter a further amendment of Section 7986 of the 1942 Code was made by Act No. 838 appearing on page 2041 of the Acts of 1950, which amendment [***9] left the Section exactly as provided in the Acts of 1947 except a change was made in the proviso with reference to misstatement of age. This Section 7986 of the Code of 1942 as amended by the Acts of 1947 and 1950, supra, was re-enacted and incorporated as Section 37-161 of the 1952 Code, upon which the plaintiff's Demurrer is based. It will be noted that the wording of Section 7986, Code of Laws of 1942, is much clearer, stronger and more implicit, because it contains the words "all life insurance companies, fraternal benefit associations or any other company, corporation or association by whatever name known." While in Section 37-161 of the Code of Laws of 1952 the words "life insurance companies, fraternal benefit associations or any other company, corporation or association by whatever name known" are omitted, and that in title 37-161 of the 1952 Code of Laws all references to fraternal benefit associations or societies are omitted.

In paragraph entitled 37-857, Code of Laws of 1952, at page 398; in Chapter entitled "Fraternal Benefit Associations" which defines fraternal benefit associations, a class under which the defendant admittedly comes, the following provision is found:

 [***10] "General insurance law inapplicable. Fraternal benefit associations as defined in this chapter shall be governed by the provisions hereof and the general insurance laws of this State shall not apply to such associations unless express provision therefor is made in any such law."

A reading of Title 37-161, Code of Laws of 1952, will clearly show that no express provision in such Statute or general insurance law is made for fraternal benefit associations, such as the defendant herein admittedly is, and, therefore, I find and hold that the provisions of Title 37-161, 1952 Code of Laws, which is the general insurance law, is not applicable to the defendant in this case, a fraternal benefit association or society, and the Demurrer of the plaintiff to the Answer of the Defendant is hereby overruled and dismissed. See Stewart v. Woodmen of the World Life Insurance Society, 195 S.C. 365, 11 S.E.2d 449; Robertson v. Fraternal Union of America, 85 S.C. 221, 67 S.E. 247; Powell v. Gary, 200 S.C. 154, 20 S.E.2d 391; Murray v. Sovereign Camp, Woodmen of the World, 192 S.C. 101, 5 S.E.2d 560. All of which is duly ordered.



DISPOSITION: Reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In plaintiff beneficiary's action to recover under a life insurance certificate issued by defendant fraternal benefit association, the Common Pleas Court, York County (South Carolina), overruled the beneficiary's demurrer to the association's answer that the certificate was void because of untrue representations made in the application.


OVERVIEW: The benefit association rejected the beneficiary's claim under the life insurance certificate on the ground that the holder of the certificate had made material misrepresentations concerning the state of his health. The beneficiary argued that the association was estopped from pleading the bar by § 37-161 of the 1952 Code of Laws, which stated that any company issuing a life insurance policy was deemed to have waived any right to dispute the truth of the application if it had not done so within two years of its issuance. The lower court overruled the beneficiary's demurrer to the association's answer, but the court reversed. The court found that § 37-161 was applicable to the association. Although the statute was originally applicable only to life insurance companies, it was expressly made applicable to fraternal benefit associations. No change of legislative intent was made evident when the early acts were codified and no substantial change of language occurred in the process of codification. The court held that the history of the legislation left no doubt that the association was bound by the statute.


OUTCOME: The court reversed.

 

481 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Hopkins v. Sun Crest Bottling Co.


17076


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


228 S.C. 287; 89 S.E.2d 755; 1955 S.C. LEXIS 99



October 26, 1955, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Action was brought for damages resulting from collision of trucks. The Common Pleas Court of Darlington County, J. Woodrow Lewis, J., entered an order refusing motion of defendant bottling company to transfer the action to Florence County, and the bottling company appealed. The Supreme Court, Baker, C. J., held that bottling company, which had its principal place of business in Florence County, and which sold crates of bottled soft drinks in Darlington County, under arrangement whereby customers made deposits on bottles and crates and received their deposits back when crates and bottles were returned about three days later to Florence County, did not "own property" in Darlington County within meaning of statute providing that service on a domestic corporation in any county where it shall "own property" and transact business, shall be effective and confer jurisdiction over the corporation.

Reversed.

TAYLOR and STUKES, JJ., dissented.



DISPOSITION: Order refusing appellant's motion to transfer reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant bottling company challenged an order of the Common Pleas Court of Darlington County (South Carolina) that refused its motion to transfer an action for damages brought by appellee to another county.


OVERVIEW: An action was brought for damages resulting from collision of trucks. The bottling company had been held subject to the jurisdiction of the county on the ground that it owned property and transacted business there. It was a domestic corporation with its principal place of business in another county and a resident of that county within the meaning of S.C. Code Ann. § 10-303 (1952). The bottling company argued that it did not own property in the county where the suit was brought within the meaning of S.C. Code Ann. § 10-421 (1952). It claimed that the whole purpose of its deposit arrangement was for the speedy rotation of bottles from plant to customer and back to plant and to make their stay in any county, other than where its plant was located, as brief and transitory as possible. The court reversed the order of the trial court that denied the motion for transfer and held that property so transitory in a county was not ownership of the property within the meaning of § 10-421. It was far-fetched to say that a domestic corporation was subject to suit in every county of the state wherein an empty soft drink bottle or crate came to rest briefly, pending return to the bottler for reuse.


OUTCOME: The order of the trial court, refusing the bottling company's motion to transfer the action for damages brought by plaintiff to the county of the bottling company's residence, was reversed.

 

482 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Richards v. Columbia


17032


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


227 S.C. 538; 88 S.E.2d 683; 1955 S.C. LEXIS 67



July 18, 1955, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Action by rental property owners against city to enjoin enforcement of city ordinance requiring the alteration, repair or destruction of houses deemed unfit for human habitation and containing a list of specific standards required to be in all houses. The County Court, Richland County, Legare Bates, J., held that ordinance was valid and owners appealed. The Supreme Court, Stukes, J., held that ordinance was not an arbitrary or unreasonable exercise of police power and except for portion of ordinance providing for determination by Rehabilitation Director or Commission for Rehabilitation of houses unfit for human habitation, ordinance was valid.

Judgment modified and affirmed.

LEGGE and OXNER, JJ., dissented.



DISPOSITION: Judgment modified and affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff property owners appealed a decision of the Richland County Court (South Carolina), which held valid and constitutional a municipal ordinance enacted by defendant city requiring that all dwelling units have indoor plumbing, glass windows, heating, ventilation, proper electrical wiring, and weather tight exteriors. The trial court found no violations of U.S. Const. amend. V, XIV, or S.C. Const. art. 1, § 25.


OVERVIEW: Two property owners, one of whom owned over 100 rental units and one of whom lived in his own property, challenged an ordinance of the City of Columbia after they were cited for violations. The property owners contended that complying with the new ordinance would cost them from $ 575 to $ 750 per dwelling. The court upheld the ordinance, stating that the cost did not constitute a taking of property because the city's policy power allowed it to insist upon reasonable standards for the public health and safety. The court further found that the hearings provided by the ordinance could properly employ relaxed rules of evidence and the court held that no jury trial was required by S.C. Const. art. 1, § 25. The court, however, struck down the general portions of Section 9 of the ordinance, finding that the specific health and safety requirements were proper but that the general, expansive language granting permission to the city to demolish a structure for vague safety concerns was unenforceable. As modified, the court found the ordinance constitutional.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment in favor of the city on the property owners' challenge to the housing ordinance, but modified the judgment to reflect that the vague, general powers given to the city in Section 9 could not be enforced.

 

483 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Fairey v. Orangeburg


17028


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


227 S.C. 458; 88 S.E.2d 617; 1955 S.C. LEXIS 59



July 12, 1955, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Action by farmer against city for loss of hogs from disease which had been contracted from city hogs which had been fed by city on uncooked garbage without permit from state or county authorities to do so. From order of the Common Pleas Court, Orangeburg County, J. M. Brailsford. Jr., J., sustaining city's demurrer to the complaint, the farmer appealed. The Supreme Court, Legge, J., held that statute declaring that any city of over 5,000 inhabitants shall be liable for all damages done to property of any citizen thereof, or property holder therein, by any of its officers, agents or servants did not deprive a farmer, who was not a citizen, of any right of action against city since he had no such right prior to enactment of statute, and even if classification prescribed by statute were unreasonable or arbitrary farmer would be in no better position since constitutionality of statute would leave him without any right of action.

Affirmed.



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant farmer sought review of an order of the Common Pleas Court, Orangeburg County (South Carolina), which sustained respondent city's demurrer to the farmer's complaint against the city for the loss of his hogs from a disease which they had contracted from the city's hogs.


OVERVIEW: The farmer was not a resident or property holder of the city. The farmer argued § 47-379 of the 1952 Code created two separable provisions, one lawful which gave persons the right to sue the city for all damages done to property by any of its officers or agents, and one unlawful that denied that right to persons who were neither citizens or property holders of the city. The trial court sustained the city's demurrer because the complaint failed to allege that the farmer belonged to either of the two classes to whom a right of action was given under § 47-379. Section 47-379 expressed a single legislative purpose, and the limitation imposed by the words "thereof" and "therein" could not be construed as a separable provision. Because the provisions of the statute were not separable, it was unnecessary to determine whether the statute violated the equal protection provisions of the state and federal constitutions. Upon review, the court found that the trial court correctly disposed of the farmer's contention of separability. The statute did not deprive the farmer of any right of action against the city because no such right existed in his favor prior to its enactment.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment.

 

484 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Bynum v. Barron


17024


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


227 S.C. 339; 88 S.E.2d 67; 1955 S.C. LEXIS 40



June 30, 1955, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Action by taxpayer, on behalf of himself and other taxpayers who should join as plaintiffs, against county treasurer, and others, to have county supply act declared invalid and to obtain money judgment against defendants. The Common Pleas Court, York County, J. Woodrow Lewis, J., dismissed complaint after sustaining demurrers, and taxpayer appealed. The Supreme Court, Stukes, J., held that settlement of pending litigation affecting fiscal affairs of county was clearly a proper subject to be dealt with in a county supply act, and, therefore, reference thereto was properly made in title of such act.

Judgment affirmed.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant taxpayer, on behalf of himself and other taxpayers, filed an action against respondents, a county treasurer and others, to have the York County Supply Act of 1954, 48 Stat. 2640 (South Carolina) declared invalid and to obtain a money judgment against respondents. From a judgment of the Common Pleas Court, York County (South Carolina) which sustained the appellees' demurrers and dismissed the complaint, the taxpayer appealed.


OVERVIEW: The treasurer was formerly compensated solely by salary and the fees authorized by the general law for the issuance of tax executions were directed to be paid into the county treasury. S.C. Code of 1942, § 4906. Beginning with the County Supply Act of 1946, the annual supply acts through 1949 contained a provision after the appropriation of the salary that allowed him execution fees he collected since his term of office began in July 1, 1941. The circuit court held that the annual provision in the supply acts that related to the compensation of the treasurer was invalid in its retroactive aspect because it attempted to provide compensation of a public officer after services were rendered, but it was valid prospectively. In other words, the fees on executions issued prior to July 1, 1946, accrued to the county, but thereafter to the treasurer as compensation in addition to his salary. The funds authorized to be paid to the treasurer were not public funds. Section 16-A of 1954 supply act (S.C.) was a valid compromise and settlement of the pending litigation by the General Assembly upon pertinent factual findings by it. The treasurer accepted the settlement.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment.

 

485 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Bagwell v. Ernest Burwell, Inc.


16997


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


227 S.C. 168; 87 S.E.2d 583; 1955 S.C. LEXIS 24



May 9, 1955, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Proceeding for workmen's compensation benefits for death of employee, wherein Hearing Commissioner denied compensation, but Full Industrial Commission reversed and ordered payment of award. Employer and insurer served notice and grounds of appeal to Court of Common Pleas, Spartanburg County, and appeal was argued therein before Bruce Littlejohn, J., who took matter under advisement. Following expiration of supersedeas effected by appeal, but prior to decision on appeal, the Court of Common Pleas, Spartanburg County, E. H. Henderson, J., granted claimant's motion for order requiring payment of all accrued compensation under award from date of death up to date, and employer and insurer appealed. The Supreme Court, Taylor, J., held that claimant was entitled to payment of compensation as ordered.

Order affirmed.



DISPOSITION: Exceptions dismissed, order appealed from affirmed and stay order revoked.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, an employer of a deceased employee and the employer's workers' compensation insurer, challenged a judgment of the Court of Common Pleas, Spartanburg County (South Carolina), which granted respondent widow's motion for an order requiring payment of all accrued compensation after the expiration of a supersedeas bond but prior to the lower court's determination of the challenge to the merits of the award.


OVERVIEW: Appellants had obtained a supersedeas bond and served notice to appeal subsequent to an award by the industrial commission in favor of the widow. However, after the expiration of 30 days and the supersedeas bond, the lower court ordered the payments brought up to date and appellants argued that the order was erroneous. On review, the court affirmed the trial court's judgment. In reaching its conclusion, the court held that § 72-356 of the 1952 Code of Laws for South Carolina provided that an appeal acted as a supersedeas for 30 days only. The court held that the legislature was explicit in this requirement and thus payments were required to be brought current despite the fact that the merits had not been reached by the lower court.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's judgment.

 

486 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Forest Lake v. Forest Acres


16995


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


227 S.C. 163; 87 S.E.2d 587; 1955 S.C. LEXIS 25



May 2, 1955, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Action challenging validity of city ordinance imposing a license fee of 50 cents on each $ 1,000.00 sales or receipts of each and every merchant doing business within city limits except certain businesses upon which a flat fee was imposed. From adverse order of the County Court, Richland County, Legare Bates, County Judge, the town appealed. The Supreme Court, Taylor, J., held that that portion of city ordinance which imposed a flat fee for doing business within municipality did not meet constitutional and statutory requirements that such a license be graduated and it was therefore void.

Order affirmed in part and reversed in part.



DISPOSITION: Affirmed in part; reversed in part.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant town sought review of a judgment of the County Court, Richland County (South Carolina) invalidating part of an ordinance imposing license fees on sales or receipts of all merchants doing business within city limits except for certain businesses which paid a flat fee. Respondent merchants had challenged the ordinance as void under Article 8, § 6 of the South Carolina Constitution and § 47-271 of the 1952 Code of Laws for South Carolina.


OVERVIEW: When the county court agreed with the merchants that the ordinance was invalid in its entirety by reason of the fact that it imposed a flat fee on certain businesses while other businesses had to pay a graduated tax, the town appealed. The court affirmed in part and reversed in part. First, it approved of the county court's finding that the part of the ordinance that imposed a flat fee on certain businesses was improper under the state constitution and § 47-172, noting that such fees were required to be graduated as to the affected classifications. Thus, to the extent that the ordinance imposed a flat fee, it was void. However, the court held that the presence of the invalid section did not require the entire ordinance to be struck down. That was because § 15 thereof specifically provided for severability. Thus, since the portion imposing the graduated fees was severable and independent, it was enforceable despite the invalidity of the other section, and it was properly allowed to stand. The court thereupon affirmed the county court to the extent it invalidated the flat fee provisions in the ordinance but reversed it as to the issue of the validity of the balance of the ordinance.


OUTCOME: The court held that the portion of the ordinance that imposed a flat fee for doing business within the town did not satisfy constitutional and statutory requirements and were void. However, it held that other portions of the ordinance were severable and thus were not invalidated by reason of the invalidity of the flat fee portion.

 

487 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Hunt v. General Ins. Co.


16994


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


227 S.C. 125; 87 S.E.2d 34; 1955 S.C. LEXIS 13



April 19, 1955, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Action by life tenants against insurer on fire policy covering building. From adverse order of the County Court, Greenville County, W. B. McGowan, County Judge, the insurer appealed. The Supreme Court, Baker, C. J., held that where insurer issued owner of building a fire policy with knowledge that a fire policy had been issued to life tenants, and owner refused to permit insurer to repair damage caused by fire, insurer was liable to life tenants for amount of damage, even though interest of life tenant had been over valued and insurer had paid owner nearly full amount of damage.

Order affirmed.

OXNER, J., dissented.



DISPOSITION: Order appealed from affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant insurer sought review of the decision of the County Court of Greenville County (South Carolina), which granted judgment in favor of respondent administrators of the insured in their action to recover the full value of the fire insurance policy that covered the burnt building. The insurer's interpleader to pay the full amount of the loss into the trial court was denied.


OVERVIEW: The insurer over-insured the building that burned. When it offered to pay to repair the building the insured refused the offer. There were several person who sought to recover under two policies. The insurer contended that it should only be liable for the amount of the actual loss rather than the amounts actually insured for because if it were to pay all the individuals their full amount, it would exceed the limits of the policies. The court ruled in favor of the administrators. The court found that the insurer by accepting the excessive premiums opened itself up to the liability of paying the full amount each insured was insured for in their on right. Under the Valued Policy Statutes the insured could recover the full value insured even though she had a limited interest worth less than the amount of the insurance. Because the insurer was under no duty to issue insurance to the insured for any greater amount than the value of the leasehold, it entered into the insurance contract with its eyes open and received the premium from the insured with full knowledge of the situation, such that it as liable under the policies.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the trial court.

 

488 of 598 DOCUMENTS


South Carolina State Highway Dep't v. Harbin


16977


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


226 S.C. 585; 86 S.E.2d 466; 1955 S.C. LEXIS 150



March 15, 1955, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Proceeding for a writ of certiorari to review an order of the Circuit Court setting aside and declaring void a suspension by the highway department of a driver's license of the offending driver. J. Robert Martin, Jr., J., held that the department was without authority to adopt the regulation and the case is before the Supreme Court on an appeal by the State Highway Department. The Supreme Court, Oxner, J., held that the provision of the statute authorizing the highway department to suspend or revoke a driver's license for cause satisfactory to it was not a constitutional delegation of legislative power.

Order affirmed.



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff South Carolina State Highway Department (Department) sought review of an order of the Circuit Court (South Carolina), which set aside and declared void a suspension by the department of defendant driver's license to operate a motor vehicle.


OVERVIEW: The department issued a regulation known as the "point system" which sought to regulate driver's licenses by granting the department the power to give points for certain driving infractions and when the points totalled a certain number, the department would then have discretion to suspend the offender's driver's license. The driver fell subject to this system and his license was suspended. The trial court found that the department was without power to effect the "point system" and revoked the department's action of suspending the driver's license. On appeal, the court affirmed the order of the trial court. The court found that the "point system" was unconstitutional upon the ground that suspension or revocation was left to the absolute, unregulated, and undefined discretion of the department. The court noted that the regulation set up no standard and contained no limitations. The court concluded that the authority granted to the department was an unconstitutional delegation of legislative power and that the department was without authority to adopt the "point system."


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order of the trial court in favor of the driver and declared that the department was not empowered to adopt the "point system" as a method to regulate driver's licenses.

 

489 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Forest Acres v. Forest Lake


16942


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


226 S.C. 349; 85 S.E.2d 192; 1954 S.C. LEXIS 107



December 15, 1954, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Original action seeking declaration of unconstitutionality of act under which portion of town was purportedly annexed to an adjacent town. The Supreme Court, Oxner, J., held that statute pertaining to territory annexation within state, even though expressed in general terms, which because of population limitation could only refer to one county within state and which was radical departure from general law on same subject, in that it authorized annexation to any municipality in such county, of property owned by corporation in another municipality without consent of qualified electors of municipality being reduced, was violative of constitutional inhibition against special legislation and was invalid.

Act declared unconstitutional and annexation held invalid.



DISPOSITION: Act declared unconstitutional and annexation held invalid.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioners, a town, a freeholder, residents, and electors, filed an original action against respondent neighboring town seeking a declaration that § 4719.2 of the 1952 Code (1954) (South Carolina) was unconstitutional and that an annexation attempted by respondent under the act was invalid.


OVERVIEW: Respondent sought to annex a portion of land that was within the corporate boundaries of petitioner. Having previously failed to make a valid annexation, respondent approached the South Carolina Legislature, which enacted § 4719.2. The new act allowed a town in any county having a city with a population greater than 85,000 to annex territory without a vote of the residents of the area to be annexed. Petitioners sought to annul the act. The court granted the requested relief, holding that § 4719.2 was special legislation, passed in violation of Article 3, § 34 of the Constitution. The court found that only one county had a city with a population greater than 85,000 and that to create new procedures applying only to towns in that county was purely arbitrary. There was no reasonable basis for a distinction between the towns in that county and the towns across the state. No reason had been advanced as to why electors in that county should be deprived of a vote in deciding questions of annexation. On another point, the freeholder, the residents, and the electors were held to be proper parties.


OUTCOME: The court held that the questioned legislation was unconstitutional and that the purported annexation by respondent was invalid.

 

490 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Leonard v. Talbert


16902


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


225 S.C. 559; 83 S.E.2d 201; 1954 S.C. LEXIS 69



August 9, 1954, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Action for declaratory judgment upon validity of general obligation bonds proposed to be issued by county. From judgment of Common Pleas Court, Richland County, J. M. Brailsford, Jr., J., holding the projected bond issue valid, an appeal was taken. The Supreme Court, Stukes, J., held that statute which authorized the issuance of bonds by county to promote a system of physical education for the public school system and which provided for public use of recreational facilities during school vacation periods, was invalid since issuance of bonds was not for an educational purpose or an ordinary county purpose as required by the Constitution.

Judgment reversed.



DISPOSITION: Reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In appellant's suit for a declaratory judgment upon the validity of a county's general obligation bonds proposed to be issued pursuant to 48 Stat. 475, appellant challenged a judgment of the Common Pleas Court, Richland County (South Carolina), which found for respondents.


OVERVIEW: The county proposed to issue the subject bonds, and appellant sued for a declaratory judgment upon their validity. The trial court found for respondents. The court held that 48 Stat. 475, which authorized the issuance of bonds by a county to promote a system of physical education for the public school system and which provided for public use of recreational facilities during school vacation periods, was invalid because the issuance of the bonds was not for an educational or ordinary county purpose as required by § 6 of art. X of the Constitution of 1895.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the trial court.

 

491 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Bolt v. Cobb


16883


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


225 S.C. 408; 82 S.E.2d 789; 1954 S.C. LEXIS 54
