June 23, 1954, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Action to enjoin issuance of general obligation bonds for hospital facilities and execution of other terms of the Act providing for such issuance. The Common Pleas Court, Anderson County, Bruce Littlejohn, J., rendered judgment for defendants and plaintiffs appealed. The Supreme Court, Stukes, J., held that defects in published notice of election and in form of ballot were not substantial, could not have affected result and did not therefore invalidate election, by which issuance of bonds for hospital facilities was authorized.

Exceptions overruled and judgment affirmed.



DISPOSITION: Exceptions overruled and judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants sought review of a judgment of the Common Pleas Court, Anderson County (South Carolina), rendered in their action brought to enjoin respondent County Board of Commissioners of Anderson County from issuing bonds under Act No. 390 of 1953, 48 Stat. 692. A hospital association was also a respondent. An issue was whether or not defects in the bond-election process were substantial.


OVERVIEW: Act No. 390 of 1953, 48 Stat. 692, provided for a special election to allow the County to issue general obligation bonds for hospital facilities. An election was held. Section 1 of Act No. 390 of 1953, 48 Stat. 692, allowed the leasing of the new building to the association, which was already running not-for-profit hospital facilities. Appellants claimed that the authorization to lease the new hospital building to the association was unconstitutional, under Article X of the South Carolina Constitution, as it would convert the property to a private rather than a public purpose. The court rejected the argument. The court said that its decision was controlled by a precedent, and it wrote that the County by leasing would be providing for the performance of a public, corporate function via the association. Regarding defects in the election procedure, the court found that they were not substantial and determinative of the outcome, and, hence, they did not invalidate the election. One defect was that the ballots stated, for vote designation by marking, "In favor of the issue" and "Opposed to the issue," whereas, § 2 of Title 23 of the 1952 Code directed the use of "Yes" and "No."


OUTCOME: The court overruled exceptions, and, ruling in favor of the county board of commissioners, the court affirmed the judgment.

 

492 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Asmer v. Livingston


16867


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


225 S.C. 341; 82 S.E.2d 465; 1954 S.C. LEXIS 43



May 11, 1954, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Suit by retail liquor dealer for refund of cost of tax stamps affixed to alcoholic beverages which were destroyed and damaged by fire. The County Court, Richland County, Legare Bates, J., overruled demurrer to complaint, and the tax commission appealed. The Supreme Court, Oxner, J., held that in view of fact that it is contemplated by Alcoholic Beverage Tax Statute that the tax shall be paid by the wholesaler, statute authorizing a refund to a licensee of cost of stamp affixed to goods which have been damaged and are unfit for sale, referred only to the holder of a wholesaler's license to the exclusion of a retailer, since the word "refund" indicated that repayment was to be made only to the one who had originally paid the tax.

Order reversed, demurrer sustained, and complaint dismissed.



DISPOSITION: Order appealed from reversed, demurrer sustained and complaint dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant Tax Commission sought review of an order of the County Court, Richland County (South Carolina), which overruled a demurer to respondent retail liquor dealer's action for a refund of the cost of tax stamps affixed to alcoholic beverages that were destroyed and damaged by fire. The statute dealing with the stamps was § 65-1268 of the 1952 Code (South Carolina).


OVERVIEW: The retail liquor dealer sought an adjudication that he was entitled to a refund representing the amount of tax stamps affixed to certain alcoholic beverages that were destroyed. The Tax Commission demurred to the complaint upon the ground that a refund could only have been made to the holder of a valid wholesaler's license. The court below concluded that the word "licensee" included a retail as well as a wholesale licensee, and overruled the demurrer. The narrow question presented was whether the refund provision applied to the holder of a retailer's license. The court held that the word "licensee" referred to a holder of a wholesaler's license mentioned in the preceding sentence. A retail licensee could not purchase goods from a manufacturer or such jobber. He could only purchase from one who held a valid wholesaler's license. As the tax was paid by the wholesaler to the Tax Commission, it was intended that such refund should have been to him alone and not to a retail licensee. If the Legislature intended to make provision for a refund of such tax to a person other than the one from whom it had been collected, it would have so expressed itself.


OUTCOME: The order appealed from was reversed, the demurrer was sustained, and the complaint dismissed.

 

493 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Miller v. Springs Cotton Mills


16860


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


225 S.C. 326; 82 S.E.2d 458; 1954 S.C. LEXIS 42



April 15, 1954, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Proceeding for compensation for knee injury allegedly suffered as result of claimant's near-fall as she got up from her chair in employer's cafeteria. From an order of the Common Pleas Court, Chester County, Joseph R. Moss, J., reversing an award by the Industrial Commission, claimant appealed. The Supreme Court, Oxner, J., held that evidence indicated the near-fall was a result of failure of claimant's knee to function normally and not the cause of an injury by accident, and further held that claimant was not entitled to accrued payment of temporary total disability under the award.

Affirmed.

TAYLOR, J., and BAKER, C. J., dissented in part.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Claimant employee sought review of the judgment from the Circuit Court (South Carolina), which reversed an award of compensation made by the Industrial Commission for a knee injury allegedly sustained by the employee in defendant employer's cafeteria.


OVERVIEW: The employee allegedly suffered a knee injury resulting from a near-fall as she arose from a table in the cafeteria. On appeal, the major issue was whether the employee sustained an accidental injury that arose out of and in the course of her employment. The court found no evidence that the employed suffered an injury by accident. From the employee's testimony at the hearing before the Commission at which she stated that her knee twisted as she arose, the court found that the failure of the employee's knee to function normally was the cause of her near-fall. Thus, because there was no accidental injury, the employee failed to satisfy the first prerequisite for compensation. The second issue addressed by the court was whether the employee was entitled to the temporary total disability for the period between the date of the alleged accident and the date of the hearing. The court held that because the Commission's award was reversed on appeal, the award was neither an unappealed award nor an affirmed award under S.C. Code Ann. § 72-357. Thus, the award could not be enforced by entry of judgment, and the employer could not be forced to pay benefits that had accrued during the appeal.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the circuit court's judgment, which had reversed an award of compensation to the employee.

 

494 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Lee v. Clark


16779


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


224 S.C. 138; 77 S.E.2d 485; 1953 S.C. LEXIS 78



September 10, 1953, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Action for declaratory judgment adjudicating the constitutionality of a statute. The Common Pleas Court, Chesterfield County, J. Woodrow Lewis, J., held statute to be unconstitutional, and defendants appealed. The Supreme Court, Oxner, J., held that the statute providing for Board of nine trustees of school district, not less than three of whom shall be women, to be elected by qualified voters of district, and providing that the three women candidates receiving largest number of votes cast for women candidates shall be elected, and that the six other candidates receiving highest number of votes cast in elections, whether men or women, shall be elected, is unconstitutional as granting, unreasonably, a preferential status to women in running for office of school trustee.

Affirmed.



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant trustees sought review of the decision of the Common Pleas Court, Chesterfield County, (South Carolina), which overruled a demurrer to the complaint and held that 1952 S.C. Acts 2111 (Act) was unconstitutional in a declaratory action brought pursuant to Uniform Declaratory Judgments Act, S.C. Code Ann. § 10-2003 (1952) by respondent taxpayer.


OVERVIEW: 1952 S.C. Acts 2111 provided that not less than three of the nine members of the board of trustees were to be women, and provided that the three women candidates who received the largest number of votes cast for women candidates were to be elected. The taxpayer argued that the Act violated S.C. Const. art. I, § 1, and S.C. Const. art. II, § 2, and that it denied the equality of rights and privileges guaranteed by the Constitution. The court concluded that: (1) notwithstanding the provisions of S.C. Const. art. II, § 2, and S.C. Const. art. I, § 10, of the Constitution that every qualified elector was eligible for public office, it was intended by S.C. Const. art. XI, § 3, that the General Assembly should be vested with the power to prescribe other qualifications for the office of school trustee; (2) the qualifications fixed could not be arbitrary, but had to be reasonable and based upon substantial grounds; and (3) the Act went beyond equality between the sexes and enlarged the rights of women by giving them a preferential status in running for the office of school trustee.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed in the challenge to the constitutionality of the legislation.

 

495 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Arthur v. Byrnes


16774


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


224 S.C. 51; 77 S.E.2d 311; 1953 S.C. LEXIS 75



August 18, 1953, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Taxpayer's suit brought in original jurisdiction of Supreme Court for purpose of determining validity of bonds proposed to be issued. The Supreme Court, Oxner, J., held that enrollment and tuition statistics for state institutions of higher learning, together with forecasts of future tuition income, and other matters, disclosed that the special tuition fund for payment of proposed bonds for such institutions should have a coverage of 150 per cent of principal and interest requirements rather than 110 per cent coverage required by Act authorizing bonds or 125 per cent coverage determined by State Budget and Control Board.

Decision in accordance.



DISPOSITION: Enrollment and tuition statistics for state institutions of higher learning, together with forecasts of future tuition income, and other matters, disclosed that the special tuition fund for payment of proposed bonds for such institutions should have a coverage of 150 per cent of principal and interest requirements rather than 110 per cent coverage required by Act authorizing bonds or 125 per cent coverage determined by State Budget and Control Board.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner taxpayer filed a suit against respondents, a governor and others, to determine the validity of certain bonds proposed to be issued under an act of the General Assembly to provide for the issuance by the State of South Carolina of state institution bonds.


OVERVIEW: The act in question authorized the issuance of bonds for improvements at certain institutions of higher learning. It contemplated that the principal and interest of the bonds were to be paid from the tuition fees, but there was also pledged the full faith, credit, and taxing power of the State of South Carolina. The taxpayer attacked the issuance for the Clemson Agricultural College of South Carolina and the University of South Carolina upon the grounds that the issuance would constitute an increase in the public debt of South Carolina without first submitting the question to the electors and that the fees from tuition were not sufficient. The court held that the bonds could not be issued for Clemson College in the amount requested because the income pledged to pay the bonds was insufficient, but that the bonds could be issued for the University of South Carolina because the current and future tuition fees for that institution were sufficient to meet the principal and interest requirements of the bonds. It was noted that the special tuition fund for payment of the proposed bonds was to constitute a coverage of 150 percent of the principal and interest requirements.


OUTCOME: The court held that the proposed bonds could be issued for the University of South Carolina, but not the Clemson Agricultural College of South Carolina.

 

496 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Radio Cab Co. v. Bagby


16768


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


224 S.C. 28; 77 S.E.2d 264; 1953 S.C. LEXIS 71



July 29, 1953, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Suit for judgment of invalidity of ordinance and injunction against enforcement of it. The Common Pleas Court, Chester County, held the ordinance to be invalid, and the defendants appealed. The Supreme Court, Stukes, J., held that ordinance forbidding parking by taxicabs other than at their regular stands, except when actually engaged in answering calls or transporting passengers, was valid as against contentions that it discriminated against taxicab owners, deprived them of their property without due process of law, and resulted in undue hardship to such owners.

Reversed.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In a suit commenced by respondents, owners and operators of taxicabs, to have declared invalid a city ordinance that prohibited taxicabs from parking in parking spaces unless they were taking on or discharging customers, and to have an injunction against the enforcement thereof, appellants, a mayor and city officials, challenged a judgment of the Common Pleas Court, Chester County (South Carolina) that held the ordinance invalid.


OVERVIEW: The ordinance plainly stated that its intent and purpose was to require taxicabs to park at their regular stands except when engaged in answering calls or transporting passengers. There was nothing in the ordinance prohibiting the taxicabs from parking in parking spaces while waiting for a passenger that it had transported to come out of a physician's office or other place. The taxicab owners and operators alleged that the ordinance was discriminatory against them as citizens and taxpayers and violative of U.S. Const. amend. XIV because it deprived them of the use of their property upon the streets of the city without due process of law, and that it was arbitrary and would result in undue hardship, inconvenience, financial loss, and irreparable injury to them. Upon review, the court reversed the judgment of the common pleas court that held the ordinance invalid, stating that the ordinance was valid as against the contentions that it discriminated against taxicab owners because the ordinance involved the use of the streets as a place of business, and it was not unreasonable as all taxicabs were treated alike under the terms thereof.


OUTCOME: The judgment under review was reversed.

 

497 of 598 DOCUMENTS


State v. Taylor


16763


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


223 S.C. 526; 77 S.E.2d 195; 1953 S.C. LEXIS 62



July 13, 1953, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Defendant was convicted of operating public livestock market without first obtaining a permit from State Veterinarian. The General Sessions Court, of Anderson County, J. B. Pruitt, J., affirmed judgment of magistrate, and defendant appealed. The Supreme Court, Per Curiam, held that under statute providing that technical livestock committee, which was empowered to promulgate and enforce rules and regulations pertaining to supervision of livestock markets, stockyards, and livestock dealers to prevent spread of livestock diseases, was to be composed of four men appointed by college board of trustees and certain officers of certain livestock dealers' association, power granted trustees and officers did not constitute invalid delegation of legislative power.

Exceptions overruled and judgment affirmed.



DISPOSITION: Exceptions overruled and judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed from a judgment of the General Sessions Court of Anderson County (South Carolina) that affirmed the decision of a magistrate that convicted him of operating a public livestock market without first obtaining a permit from the state veterinarian.


OVERVIEW: Defendant sought reversal on the ground that the general sessions court erred in not holding unconstitutional the Act to Regulate and Supervise Livestock Markets, Stockyards, and Dealers in Livestock in Order to Prevent the Spread of Contagious and Infectious Diseases of Livestock in South Carolina, §§ 6-331 to 6-347of the 1952 Code (South Carolina) upon the ground that it violated S.C. Const. art. 3, § 1 by unlawfully attempting to delegate the law making authority of the legislature and by the invalid delegation of the legislative authority because of the incompleteness of said Act when it left the hands of the legislature. Upon review, the court overruled defendant's exceptions and affirmed the judgment of conviction, holding that the manner in which the Livestock Committee was appointed under the Act did not constitute an invalid delegation of legislative power. The court stated that although the language of the Act was rather loosely drawn and not entirely free from ambiguity, the Livestock Dealers Association was not given the power of appointment, but that the legislature merely made certain designated officers of the Association members by virtue of their office.


OUTCOME: Defendant's exceptions were overruled, and the judgment appealed from was affirmed.

 

498 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Wagener v. Johnson


16757


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


223 S.C. 470; 76 S.E.2d 611; 1953 S.C. LEXIS 55



June 30, 1953, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Action involving issue as to validity of act empowering Board of Township Commissioners of Folly Island to issue waterworks revenue bonds of township to defray all costs of constructing waterworks system for township, and committing to the board the function of constructing, operating and maintaining waterworks system for the territory. The Common Pleas Court, Charleston County, William H. Grimball, J., held the enactment to be valid, and plaintiff appealed. The Supreme Court, Stukes, J., held that the enactment was valid, irrespective of whether the status of the board of township commissioners, under the legislation incorporating the township, was de jure, de facto or null and void, and revenue bonds, if and when issued in accord with act and sections of code to which it makes reference, would be valid and binding obligations of the district.

Judgment affirmed.



DISPOSITION: Exceptions overruled and judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff resident challenged a judgment of the Common Pleas Court, Charleston County, South Carolina, which ruled that an act was valid which empowered defendant members of a Board of Township Commissioners to issue waterworks revenue bonds of a township to defray all costs of constructing a waterworks system for township, and gave the Board the function of constructing, operating and maintaining a waterworks system for the territory.


OVERVIEW: The resident sought a judgment that all of the code sections relating to the government of the township were invalid for violation of specified provisions of the South Carolina Constitution of 1895. The resident also asserted that the commissioners had no legal status and could not proceed with the issuance of the proposed bonds. The gravamen of the complaint was that because of the alleged unconstitutionality of the code sections which related to the township, there would be uncertainty and confusion as to the validity of the proposed bonds and the right of the commissioners to construct, operate and maintain the waterworks. Affirming, the court ruled that there would be no such uncertainty or confusion. The revenue bonds, if and when issued, would be valid and binding obligations of the district, of the tenor and terms prescribed in the authorizing statutes. The court noted that there had been no need for the trial court to address the constitutionality of § 14-1261 et seq. of the Code of 1952.


OUTCOME: The court overruled the exceptions and affirmed the judgment of the trial court, except that it refused to express an opinion regarding the constitutionality of a South Carolina code section.

 

499 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Fordham v. Fordham


16748


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


223 S.C. 401; 76 S.E.2d 299; 1953 S.C. LEXIS 51



June 1, 1953, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Proceeding by wife against husband to enforce the support of their children, wherein husband was served with process while he was temporarily in county of wife's residence. Defendant appeared specially to contest jurisdiction of court. The Common Pleas Court, Charleston County, affirmed decision that husband was subject to trial in such county, and husband appealed. The Supreme Court, Stukes, J., held that the section of Domestic Relations Court Act, which Act is applicable to counties containing a city with population of 70,000, providing that the court shall have jurisdiction over a defaulting husband and father if, at time of filing petition for support, husband is not residing or domiciled in county but is found therein, and wife is so residing or domiciled at such time, substitutes residence of petitioner for the residence of defendant which is requisite under general law, and is invalid for contravention of constitutional provision forbidding special laws where a general law can be made applicable.

Reversed.



DISPOSITION: Reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant husband sought review of a decision from the Common Pleas Court of Charleston County (South Carolina), which affirmed a judgment that the husband was subject to trial in the county where plaintiff wife resided in the wife's action to enforce support of their children.


OVERVIEW: The wife resided in Charleston County and the husband resided in another county. The wife brought an action to enforce support of their children. The husband was served with process while temporarily in Charleston County. The husband appeared to specially contest jurisdiction. It was found that the husband was subject to trial in that county and the common pleas court affirmed. On appeal, the husband challenged the constitutionality of § 15-1233(2), 1952 Code (South Carolina). That section provided that the trial court had jurisdiction over a defaulting husband and father if at the time of the filing of a petition for support he was not residing or domiciled in the county but was found therein at such time. The court stated that a resident had a right to be sued in his own county. The court stated that if it granted without deciding the premise that the case was a special proceeding rather than an action although the husband was brought into court by service of a summons it did not follow that the general venue statute, § 10-303, 1952 Code (South Carolina) was inapplicable. The court found that § 15-1233(2), 1952 Code (South Carolina) was invalid.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the trial court's judgment.

 

500 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Hodge v. Pollock


16740


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


223 S.C. 342; 75 S.E.2d 752; 1953 S.C. LEXIS 41



May 4, 1953, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] The Board of Adjustment for City of Spartanburg granted variance in application of zoning regulation providing, that no building shall be constructed closer to side line of a lot, than six feet, so as to permit radiologists to construct an office building within three and one-half feet of the lot line, and an adjoining property owner filed petition for writ of certiorari. The Common Pleas Court, Spartanburg County, affirmed Board's decision, and the property owner appealed. The Supreme Court, Oxner, J., held that evidence was insufficient to justify variance, in absence of showing that the side yard requirement, when applied to radiologists' property, became arbitrary, confiscatory, or unduly oppressive because of conditions of the property distinguishing it from other properties similarly restricted, or that plans for proposed buildings could not be satisfactorily rearranged so as to conform to zoning regulation.

Board's action set aside, and order reversed.



DISPOSITION: Action set aside and order reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant sought review of an order of the Common Pleas Court, Spartanburg County (South Carolina), which affirmed an action of a board of adjustment granting a variance to respondents in connection with a zoning regulation requiring that no building be closer than six feet to the side line of a lot.


OVERVIEW: Respondents sought a variance in order to construct a building that would be located three and one-half feet from the eastern side line of the subject lot instead of the six feet required by a local zoning ordinance. The board voted unanimously in favor of granting the requested variance but stated no reasons therefor. Appellant, the owner of the building next to respondents' lot, sought review of the decision, and the trial court affirmed the board's order. Appellant again sought review, and the court reversed. First, no expert testified that the building plans could not be rearranged so as to conform to the zoning requirements. Further, appellant offered several witnesses to the effect that by making the longer dimensions of the rooms run perpendicular to instead of parallel with the street, a building with the same facilities could be erected without the necessity of violating the ordinance. Finally, the court held that the board failed to comply with the rule that variances were only to be granted in the event that the zoning regulation would cause an "undue hardship." In fact, one respondent testified that conforming to the zoning ordinance would constitute an "inconvenience."


OUTCOME: The action of the board was set aside, and the order appealed from was reversed.

 

501 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Purdy v. Moise


16734


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


223 S.C. 298; 75 S.E.2d 605; 1953 S.C. LEXIS 38



April 14, 1953, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Proceeding to determine validity of action of city council, which affirmed findings of Zoning Board, in denying permit to construct tourist court or motor court on certain property. The Common Pleas Court, Sumter County, J. Frank Eatmon, J., ordered city to issue permit and city council and Zoning Board appealed. The Supreme Court, Taylor, J., held that "tourist court" or "motor court" was a hotel within zoning ordinance allowing construction of hotels in residence districts.

Judgment affirmed.



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, city council and zoning board, sought review of an order from the Common Pleas Court, Sumter County (South Carolina), which reversed the ruling of the city council and zoning board and ordered the city to issue a permit to respondent property owner to construct a tourist court or motor court on certain property.


OVERVIEW: A property owner applied for a permit to construct a tourist court or motor court on certain property. The zoning board held hearings and refused his application, based on a zoning ordinance. The city council affirmed the findings of the zoning board. The trial court granted a writ of certiorari requiring the city council and zoning board to produce their records and after reviewing them, reversed the ruling of the city council and zoning board and ordered the city to issue the permit. The trial court also issued an order enjoining them from interfering with the construction and requiring them to issue the permit unless they filed a bond conditioned to pay the property owner's costs sustained by reason of the appeal. The court denied the application of the city council and zoning board for a supersedeas staying the order. On appeal, the court affirmed. The court held that the property owner had the right to erect the tourist court in a residential zone under the zoning ordinance, which permitted the erection of hotels and lodging houses in such zones. The court found that the word hotel had a well-recognized meaning in law that encompassed that of tourist court or motor court.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order requiring the city to issue a permit to the property owner to construct a tourist court or motor court.

 

502 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Manning v. Dillon County


16727


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


223 S.C. 240; 75 S.E.2d 250; 1953 S.C. LEXIS 29



March 17, 1953, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Action by taxpayer for declaratory judgment as to constitutionality of Act fixing marriage license fee in county, for adjudication of rights of specified parties in sums collected under said act, and for injunction against transfer of such funds to general funds of the county. The Common Pleas Court, Dillon County, Joseph R. Moss, J., sustained demurrer to complaint, and plaintiff appealed. The Supreme Court, Oxner, J., held that plaintiff could not maintain action for declaratory judgment in absence of showing that he would be injuriously affected by unconstitutionality of the Act, nor did he have status to ask for adjudication as to rights, if any, of other parties in such funds.

Affirmed.



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff taxpayer appealed from a decision of the Common Pleas Court, Dillon County (South Carolina), which sustained the demurrer of defendants, a county and others, to his suit that sought a declaratory judgment as to the constitutionality of Acts 1948, page 1612 (South Carolina), an adjudication of the rights of specified parties in sums collected under the act, and an injunction preventing transfer of such funds to county general funds.


OVERVIEW: The act in question concerned a fixed marriage license fee in the county. The taxpayer alleged that under the general law of South Carolina, the fee payable for the issuance of a marriage license was $ 1.00. The act set the marriage license fee at $ 4.00. In affirming, the court held that the taxpayer failed to show that he would be injuriously affected by the unconstitutionality of the act. The taxpayer did not have status to ask for an adjudication as to rights, if any, to other parties to such funds. As such, the taxpayer was unable to maintain a declaratory judgment action.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed.

 

503 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Dillon County v. Md. Cas Co.


16726


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


223 S.C. 233; 75 S.E.2d 254; 1953 S.C. LEXIS 30



March 17, 1953, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Action by a county against the probate judge thereof and his surety for accounting of the amount of fees for all marriage licenses which he issued or should have issued during a certain period and to restrain him from using blank forms obtained from other counties in issuing such licenses. From an order of the Common Pleas Court of Dillon County, Joseph R. Moss, J., granting a general order of reference, vacating a temporary restraining order requiring the county treasurer to segregate from the general county funds $ 3.00 of each $ 4.00 marriage license fee paid over to him by defendant judge, subject to the court's further order, and directing the treasurer to place the amount segregated in the county's general funds, defendants appealed. The Supreme Court, Oxner, J., held that the order was proper.

Order affirmed.



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, a probate judge and his surety, challenged an order of the Common Pleas Court of Dillon County (South Carolina), which found in favor of respondent county in the county's action for an accounting of the amount of marriage license fees that should have been collected by the judge under Act No. 603 of the 1948 Acts of the South Carolina General Assembly, 45 St. at L. 1612.


OVERVIEW: The county alleged that the judge was not collecting from couples the $ 4.00 license fee described by the statute. Instead, the judge was using forms from other counties to marry couples for only $ 1.00. In an earlier stage, the judge attacked the constitutionality of the statute, but it was held that he could not do so in the equity action. The common pleas court made an order of reference for an equitable accounting, as requested by the county. It also ordered the release to the county of segregated funds that had been held while the constitutionality of the statute was disputed. The court affirmed on appeal, finding no error. The court found that the order of reference was proper because the action was in equity and the relationship between the judge and the county was a fiduciary one. The county was not required to bring its action at law. As to the segregated funds, they were properly released because, regardless of the constitutionality of the statute, the judge could have no further interest in them.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order.

 

504 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Bearden v. State


16723


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


223 S.C. 211; 74 S.E.2d 912; 1953 S.C. LEXIS 23



March 2, 1953, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Habeas corpus proceedings for discharge from State Penitentiary. The County Court, Richland County, Legare Bates, J., dismissed the petition and remanded the petitioner to custody of the Superintendent of the State Penitentiary, and the petitioner appealed. The Supreme Court, Oxner, J., held that action of Probation, Parole and Pardon Board in revoking petitioner's parole for violation of parole condition was valid, as against contention that Governor should have determined whether parole condition was violated.

Affirmed.



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner inmate sought review of a judgment from the Supreme Court of South Carolina, which held that the action of the Probation, Parole, and Pardon Board in revoking the inmate's parole for violation of parole conditions was valid. The inmate's previous petition for habeas corpus relief was dismissed, and he was remanded to the custody of the Superintendent of the State Penitentiary.


OVERVIEW: The inmate was convicted of murder and sentenced to life imprisonment. After approximately six years of penal servitude, the inmate was paroled by the then-Governor, who it was stipulated was the sole judge of what was meant by "good behavior" for parolees. The inmate was thereafter involved in an altercation and was arrested for violating the conditions of his parole. At a hearing held by the Board, the inmate's parole was revoked, and he was recommitted to the State Penitentiary. The inmate brought a habeas corpus proceeding, and his petition therefor was dismissed. On appeal, the trial court upheld the revocation, and the inmate sought review. The court held that although the inmate's parole was initially the responsibility of the then-Governor, following the election of a new Governor, and the amending of the South Carolina Constitution, such power was properly placed with the Board, and thus, its decision to revoke the inmate's parole was one made with proper authority. The court concluded that the prerogative reserved in the inmate's parole was properly transferred to the Board, and there was no showing that it undertook to impose additional terms or conditions.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's judgment.

 

505 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Shipman v. Du Pre


16690


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


222 S.C. 475; 73 S.E.2d 716; 1952 S.C. LEXIS 57



December 9, 1952, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Action by Commercial shrimp fisherman for an adjudication that certain statutory laws of state pertaining to regulation of shrimp fishing were unconstitutional. The Common Pleas Court, Beaufort County, J. Woodrow Lewis, J., rendered a judgment adverse to plaintiffs and plaintiffs appealed. The Supreme Court, Per Curiam, held that statute providing for forfeiture of boat and its rigging and equipment if boat was used to trawl for shrimp in waters of state without a license met constitutional provisions of due process of law.

Order affirmed as modified.

The following is the opinion of Judge Lewis in the Court below:

Certain phases of this matter have heretofore been passed on by the Federal Courts. D. C., 88 F. Supp. 482, and is before this Court by virtue of an opinion by the United States Supreme Court, 339 U.S. 321, 70 S. Ct. 640, 94 L. Ed. 877.

This action is instituted by the plaintiffs, commercial shrimp fishermen, against the South Carolina State Board of Fisheries, its members and certain officers thereof, seeking an adjudication that certain statutory laws of the State of South Carolina pertaining to the regulation of shrimp fishing are unconstitutional.

It [***2] appears that the questions raised by the pleadings concern the constitutionality of Section 3403, Code 1932, Sections 3408, as amended, 3310, 3379, as amended, and 3328, all of the 1942 Code of Laws. Under the statements by counsel of the issues to be determined, however, the questions involve only a consideration of Sections 3379, as amended by Act No. 323 of the 1949 Acts of the General Assembly, 46 St. at Large, p. 609, 3328 and 3408, as amended by Act No. 912 of the 1950 Acts of the General Assembly, 46 St. at Large, p. 2233.

Since the only question before me for determination in regard to Section 3408, as amended, relates to the forfeiture provisions of that Act, and the General Assembly by Act No. 912, supra, eliminated all forfeiture provisions therefrom, it is unnecessary to further consider that section.

This leaves the issues arising under Sections 3379, as amended, and Section 3328. They are considered in the order named.

By the pertinent portions of Section 3379, as amended, it is provided that, in addition to a fine or imprisonment as provided in other sections, any boat trawling for shrimp in the waters of South Carolina, without first securing a license [***3] so to do, shall be confiscated, with its rigging and equipment, to the State, and shall be sold by the State at public sale to the highest bidder for cash before the Court House door of the County in which captured, after giving 10 days notice of said sale in a newspaper published in said County.

There are no other statutory provisions now in effect giving the right to confiscate boats or equipment used in shrimp fishing in the coastal waters of South Carolina.

It will be seen from the above stated provisions of Section 3379 that no right is given to confiscate property of shrimp fishermen who are licensed by the State of South Carolina under other provisions of this section. All of the plaintiffs are licensed by the State of South Carolina, and therefore no statutory right exists for the conscation of their boats, equipment, or cargo under any circumstances by the defendants, so long as they are so licensed.

Since the plaintiffs have paid their licenses required by the statutes of this State, thereby removing any possibility of forfeiture of their property, they have no standing to raise the constitutionality of the provisions of the statute under attack. The fact that [***4] some third party may be effected by these provisions under attack does not give the plaintiffs the right to raise such questions.

However, since all parties urge a decision as to the constitutionality of the forfeiture provisions of Section 3379, as amended, so that all question thereabout may be removed, and public interest dictating that such be done, I have concluded to treat the question as properly before the Court.

I find and hold that Section 3379, as amended by Act 323 of the 1949 Acts, is valid and constitutional for the following reasons:

1: The tax features are reasonable upon a proper classification and upon proper subject matter. Toomer v. Witsell, 334 U.S. 385, 68 S. Ct. 1156, 92 L. Ed. 1460. It is within the taxing power of the State. Hay v. Leonard, 212 S.C. 81, 46 S.E.2d 653.

2: The provisions of the Act that the licensee give a sworn statement showing the name and address of the Master is certainly a valid exercise of police power of the State. No citation of authority is needed here.

3: The presumption that the Captain or Master was on board the vessel at the time of the violation of any law is made a prima facie evidence rule. Such presumptions [***5] are constitutionally valid. See 12 Am. Jur., Constitutional Law, Section 552, page 248.

4: We now come to the penalty provisions of the law relating to forfeitures.

The 1949 Act provides first that its violator shall be fined or imprisoned as provided by Section 3407 of the 1942 Code. It goes on to provide for the confiscation of the boat, rigging and equipment if the boat, trawls without a license. This property is then to be sold after ten days public notice. I find these confiscation features, when construed with other applicable law fully constitutional for the following reasons:

a. The provisions of the Act relating to forfeitures do not violate due process. The right of the State to pass special forfeiture provisions has been sustained. C. J. Hendry Co. v. Moore, 318 U.S. 133, 63 S. Ct. 499, 87 L. Ed. 663. The State has a wide latitude of discretion in the matter of the amount of the penalty or forfeiture. This discretion is governed by the interests of the public, the normal opportunities for committing the offense and the amount necessary to secure a prompt compliance with the statutory enactment. The value of the boats owned by the plaintiffs vary from $ 4,000.00 [***6] to $ 14,000.00 each. The volume of business done according to the plaintiffs who testified is from $ 40,000.00 to $ 60,000.00 per year. The amount of the forfeiture considered in the light of the business transacted during a year cannot be considered so excessive or unreasonable as to violate due process when taken along with all of the other considerations upon which the legislative discretion may rest. See: St. Louis, Iron Mountain, & Southern Railway Company v. Williams, 251 U.S. 63, 40 S. Ct. 71, 64 L. Ed. 139.

b. Before the boat or property can be sold, there will have to be a conviction of the operator for operating without a license. The Act provides for the confiscation "in addition to the punishment provided for in Section 3407." This meets the constitutional provisions of due process because it allows the parties charged a hearing and postpones a sale of the boat until determination of the criminal case against the operators, and conditions forfeiture upon a conviction of the criminal charge. Coffey v. Harlan County, 204 U.S. 659, 27 S. Ct. 305, 51 L. Ed. 666.

In addition, the owner of a boat sought to be confiscated has other remedies to test the legality of the [***7] forfeiture. See discussion thereabout in Shipman v. DuPre, D. C., 88 F. Supp. 482, 487.

The remaining question arises under Section 3328. It is herein provided that:

"It shall be lawful for the inspectors to enter any and all premises, vessels, boats, houses, sheds or warehouses used in fishing or any fishing industry in the tide waters or coastal section of this State and to arrest, without warrant, all persons found actually violating the penal laws, contained in the coastal fisheries law."

Plaintiffs attack as unconstitutional these provisions allowing inspection and arrest without warrant on the premises of the shrimpers. This statute simply gives (1) the right to go upon the premises of shrimpers for the purpose of inspection and (2) the right of arrest without warrant all persons found actually violating the laws relating to coastal fishing. Plaintiffs are licensed by the State of South Carolina and operate under State supervision. No citation of authority is necessary for the well settled principle that under these circumstances the right of reasonable inspection on the part of the proper officers violates no constitutional provision. The power to arrest without [***8] warrant is not given except in those cases where the shrimpers are found actually violating the law. This is but an enactment of the well settled law that an officer may arrest without warrant for an offense committed in his presence. The position of the plaintiffs in regard to Section 3328 is without merit.

The relief sought by the plaintiffs is conditioned upon the unconstitutionality of the Acts of the South Carolina General Assembly in question. The Court having concluded that the Acts contravene no constitutional provisions, the relief sought is denied and the complaint is dismissed.

And it is so Ordered.



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed as modified.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, commercial shrimp fisherman, filed a complaint against respondents, the South Carolina Board of Fisheries and its members and officers, for an adjudication that certain South Carolina statutes pertaining to the regulation of shrimp fishing were unconstitutional. The fisherman filed exceptions to the order of the Common Pleas Court, Beaufort County, South Carolina, which dismissed the complaint.


OVERVIEW: The fishermen claimed that § 3403 of the Code of 1932; § 3379 of the Code of 1942, as amended by Act No. 323 of the 1949 Acts of the General Assembly, 46 St. at L. 609; §§ 3310 and 3328 of the Code of 1942; and § 3408 of the Code of 1942, as amended by Act No. 832 of the 1948 Acts of the General Assembly, 45 St. at L. 2058, which provided for the forfeiture of a boat and its equipment if the boat was used to trawl for shrimp without a license, were unconstitutional. The fisherman also claimed that the trial court erred in dismissing their complaint. The court modified the trial court's order. The court held that all questions that were raised by the fisherman's exceptions to the trial court's order were correctly disposed of in the order. The court also held that the trial court properly found that the statutes were constitutional. The court held, however, the fisherman failed to file an exception to the trial court's order with regard to Act No. 323 of the 1949 Acts of the General Assembly, 46 St. at L. 609, and that it would render no opinion as to the constitutionality of a presumption in that statute.


OUTCOME: The court modified the trial court's order by declaring that it would not render an opinion as to the constitutionality of the one statute. The court affirmed, as modified, the trial court's order dismissing the fishermen's complaint.

 

506 of 598 DOCUMENTS


J. F. Floyd Mortuary, Inc. v. Newman


16684


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


222 S.C. 421; 73 S.E.2d 444; 1952 S.C. LEXIS 46



November 13, 1952, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Action to subject real estate for payment of debt due creditor of deceased. The Common Pleas Court, Spartanburg County, Steve C. Griffith, Jr., held in favor of defendants, and plaintiff appealed. The Supreme Court, Stukes, J., held that where wife died intestate leaving realty subject to mortgage and surviving husband more than six months after his qualification as administrator conveyed the realty and paid the mortgage with the proceeds, creditor of wife's estate who had not brought action within six months of wife's death could not subject the real estate to the payment of the debt.

Affirmed.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff creditor of a deceased brought suit against defendants, administrator of the deceased's estate, purchaser and mortgagee of property, to subject the real estate for payment of a debt due. The Common Pleas Court, Spartanburg County (South Carolina) held in favor of defendants. The creditor appealed.


OVERVIEW: The creditor, a mortuary service, conducted the deceased's funeral. At the time of her death, the deceased owned a house and a lot, which was subject to a mortgage. She died intestate. Over six months after her death, the administrator conveyed the deceased's property to the purchaser, who later conveyed it to the mortgagee in consideration of the assumption of indebtedness. At issue was whether the mortgagee obtained title to the property free of the claim of the deceased's creditor. Section 9033 of the Code of 1942 (South Carolina) provided for a bona fide sale or mortgage by an heir or devisee for valuable consideration after the expiration of six months following the death, free of the claims of creditors of the deceased. Further, the creditor had a statutory remedy against the deceased's estate in § 9001 of the Code of 1942 (South Carolina) that it failed to pursue for more than six months. The creditor, having failed to pursue statutory remedies in a timely fashion and despite the intervening sale of the real estate by the administrator, could thus not maintain the instant suit against the administrator to compel the sale of the deceased's realty.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the trial court.

 

507 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Bookhart v. Central Electric Power Cooperative, Inc.


16670


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


222 S.C. 289; 72 S.E.2d 576; 1952 S.C. LEXIS 33



September 22, 1952, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Two suits each by William B. Bookhart, by James M. Moss, and T. C. Moss, and another, against Central Electric Power Cooperative for injunction. The six suits were tried in Common Pleas Court, Orangeburg and Calhoun Counties, E. H. Henderson and James M. Brailsford, Jr., JJ. Demurrers to the complaints were sustained, and plaintiffs appealed. The Supreme Court held that allegation that no public necessity existed for construction of proposed power line by public power project, and that, hence, power project was not authorized to take plaintiffs' land through eminent domain proceedings for purpose of erecting transmission system thereon failed to state cause of action for injunction.

Affirmed.

The order of Judge Henderson follows:

This is a demurrer by the defendant to the plaintiff's complaint on the ground that it fails to state facts sufficient to constitute a cause of action, in that it appears upon the face of the complaint that the defendant, as a cooperative nonprofit membership corporation organized under and for the purpose stated in the Rural Electric Cooperative Act, Code 1942, § 8555-91 et seq., has the right under that act to obtain the right-of-way sought [***2] over the plaintiff's lands by condemnation, upon the payment to plaintiff of just compensation for the taking thereof as ascertained in the condemnation proceeding, and the facts alleged in the complaint do not in law entitle the plaintiff to have the defendant enjoined from exercising its said right by means of the procedure prescribed in the statutes of South Carolina in such case made and provided.

It was heard by me on September 28, 1951.

There is no contention by the plaintiff that the proposed power line is to be located in an improper place on this land, or that it is unnecessarily wide, or other objection of a local nature, but, as is accurately stated by counsel for the plaintiff in their excellent written brief, the allegations of the complaint raise the following question: "Under the law of South Carolina when a corporation attempts to exercise the power of eminent domain, can a landowner challenge the right of the corporation to exercise that power on the ground that no public necessity exists for the construction of the project?"

In considering a complaint for the purpose of passing upon a demurrer, while of course the facts which are well pleaded are deemed [***3] to be true, the demurrer does admit conclusions of law. Spigner v. Provident Life and Accident Insurance Company, 148 S.C. 249, 146 S.E. 8; Henderson v. McMaster, 104 S.C. 268, 88 S.E. 645.

Many of the matters involved in the complaint have already been passed upon by the Supreme Court in the appeal in the case of Bookhart against this defendant. 219 S.C. 414, 65 S.E.2d 781.

It is clear that a landowner has a right to go to the court of equity for relief if a condemnor attempts to make an unreasonably hurtful location of the power line on his property such as by going through shade trees surrounding the residence, when that could be avoided. Seabrook v. Carolina Power and Light Company, 159 S.C. 1, 156 S.E. 1.

Also the Court will prevent the taking of an unnecessarily wide right-of-way. White v. Johnson, 148 S.C. 488, 146 S.E. 411.

However, in my opinion, the question of the public necessity of constructing the project as a whole is a legislative or political one, and not subject to review by the Courts, in the absence of fraud, bad faith, or clear abuse of discretion on the part of the condemnor.

At 29 C. J. S., Eminent Domain, § 89, page 882, we find the [***4] following:

"The legislature may delegate the power of determining the necessity of exercising the power of eminent domain to public officers or boards or to private corporations vested with the power of eminent domain, and in the absence of any statutory provision submitting the matter to a court or jury the decision of the question of necessity lies with the body of individuals to whom the state has delegated the authority to take. Generally, a determination by the grantee of the power is conclusive and is not subject to judicial review, in the absence of fraud, bad faith, or clear abuse of discretion."

Also see 18 A. J. 734, and Lewis on Eminent domain, Vol. 2, sec. 597.

This defendant has been given authority by the General Assembly to condemn rights-of-way. Code, § 8555-93. See also South Carolina Electric & Gas Co. v. South Carolina Public Service Authority, 215 S.C. 193, 54 S.E.2d 777.

Judging from the foot-notes, and the many additional cases in the pocket part, the principle laid down in 29 C. J. S., Eminent Domain, § 89, page 882, seems to be the almost universal rule and I do not think that the South Carolina cases are to the contrary. These cases deal [***5] with the question of the location of the right-of-way as it crosses the plaintiff's land, and not with the public necessity or expediency of the project as a whole.

In Riley v. Charleston Union Station Company, 71 S.C. 457, 51 S.E. 485, the Court did not question the necessity for the building of a railway station in Charleston, but the point considered was its location, whether on the land of the plaintiff or on lands of other persons.

 Hutchison v. York County, 86 S.C. 396, 68 S.E. 577, was a case where there was already a highway connecting the same communities. The plaintiff contended that the old route was adequate. There was involved a question of location.

 Sanders v. Luther, 164 S.C. 105, 162 S.E. 70, also had to do with the re-location of an existing road, this one in Beaufort County.

The delegation by the State of this great power of eminent domain does not mean that a condemnor is given a free rein, to run rough shod over the lands of the citizens of the State. The Courts will always jealously safeguard the right of landowners against a wrongful method in laying out the right-of-way across their particular tracts of land, but when it comes to the wisdom,  [***6] or expediency, or reasonable public necessity of the entire project, the department of government through which the State speaks is its legislature, and if such power has been delegated, the condemnor must act in good faith and not in a capricious or wantonly injurious manner.

As an example, if the General Assembly should authorize a railroad company to construct a line of railway from Charleston to Columbia and should delegate to it the right of eminent domain for that purpose, I do not think that the judicial department of the State government could step in and hold up its hand and say that the entire project is unwise and not reasonably necessary in the public interest. The General Assembly determines the public necessity of the undertaking as a whole; the Court protects the citizen from bad faith or fraud on the part of the condemnor to whom the State has delegated this far-reaching power.

There are many conclusions of law set forth in the complaint, and also many conclusions of inferences of fact. It should be noted that paragraphs 9 and 10 are in the alternative. Paragraph 9 alleges that the defendant has never made a finding of fact as to the necessity for the proposed [***7] power line. Paragraph 10 says, "If the defendant has ever made any determination that any necessity exists," it is false and fraudulent. Under the principle governing alternative allegations, this does not amount to an allegation that no such finding was made. Daniels v. Berry, 148 S.C. 446, 466, 146 S.E. 420; 41 A. J. 317, section 41; 71 C. J. S., Pleading, § 41, page 109.

As to paragraph 10, the allegation that the finding of necessity has no basis in fact is merely a conclusion. Such conclusions are not admitted by a demurrer. Oliveros v. Henderson, 116 S.C. 77, 106 S.E. 855; McLeod v. Southern Railway Company, 188 S.C. 14, 198 S.E. 425; Duncan v. McCormick County, 192 S.C. 216, 6 S.E.2d 265.

Nor is the plaintiff's conclusion that the finding by the defendant was false and fraudulent admitted by the demurrer. It is essential that the facts and circumstances which constitute fraud should be set out clearly. State v. Jaques, 65 S.C. 178, 43 S.E. 515; Drennan v. Brown, 112 S.C. 340, 100 S.E. 75; Steele v. Kirven, 120 S.C. 88, 110 S.E. 837.

The allegation that the finding constitutes an abuse of discretion is merely a conclusion or inference of fact by the pleader. No [***8] facts are set forth in this paragraph to substantiate the statement. As shown by the case of South Carolina Electric & Gas Co. v. South Carolina Public Service Authirity, above, the facts which are alleged in other paragraphs of the complaint, especially paragraphs 6, 7 and 8, as to the building of the power line into Elloree, do not as a matter of law constitute an abuse of discretion. Bank of Fort Mill v. Rollins, 217 S.C. 464, 61 S.E.2d 41; 71 C. J. S., Pleading, § 261, page 525.

As to the allegation that the determination of necessity was made for the personal benefit of the defendant, no facts are alleged in paragraph 10. If we turn to paragraphs 6, 7 and 8, and other paragraphs of the complaint, the facts there alleged indicate no personal benefit to the defendant, or that it is doing other than to carry out the purposes for which it was organized, and its contract duties, as set forth in the South Carolina Electric & Gas Co. case, above. This, then, is a mere conclusion or inference, and not based on alleged facts; and so is not admitted by the demurrer.

It Is Accordingly ordered that the demurrer of the defendant to the plaintiff's complaint be and the same hereby [***9] is sustained, and the complaint is dismissed.

The order of Judge Brailsford follows:

The plaintiffs, who are the owners of certain farm and timber lands, seek in this action to obtain an injunction restraining the defendant, a corporation organized under the Rural Electric Cooperative Act, Sections 8555-91 et seq., of the Code of Laws of 1942, from condemning a right-of-way over such lands for the construction of an electric transmission line, in a condemnation proceeding which it has commenced for that purpose.

The complaint alleges that the proposed transmission line is a high voltage trunk line designed for the purpose of conducting electric power in wholesale quantities to the area, section and community in and around the town of Elloree where the line will terminate; that this area, section and community is now, and has been for some time, adequately served and supplied with electric power sufficient to meet all present needs and all needs which may arise in the foreseeable future; that the proposed line will not supply electric energy to any of the defendant's members, governmental agencies, political subdivisions, or other persons who do not have an adequate supply [***10] of electric energy available to meet all present and future needs, and will not give as good service as existing facilities; and that no necessity exists for the construction of said line and for the condemnation of plaintiff's land.

The complaint also alleges that the defendant has entered into contracts with South Carolina Public Service Authority which preclude the defendant from selling power in the area, section and community to anyone other than Tri-County Electric Cooperative, Inc.; that the use of the line over and above service to such cooperative will be controlled by the said Authority; and that the defendant is attempting to condemn the right-of-way for a private use, in that the public generally will have no definite and fixed use of the line independently of the will of the defendant and the Authority, since the Authority has full discretionary power in fixing its rates and choosing its customers.

The defendant filed a demurrer to the complaint, on the ground that the same fails to state facts sufficient to constitute a cause of action in that it appears upon the face of the complaint that the defendant, organized under and for the purposes and with the powers [***11] and functions set forth in the Rural Electric Cooperative Act, has the right under that Act to obtain by the exercise of its power of eminent domain the right-of-way sought over the lands of the plaintiffs upon the payment to the plaintiffs of just compensation for the taking thereof as ascertained in the condemnation proceeding referred to in the complaint, and that the facts alleged in the complaint do not entitle the plaintiffs to an injunction preventing the exercise of such power in the condemnation procedure prescribed in the Statutes in such case made and provided.

The matter has been fully argued before me by counsel for the parties; and, in my opinion, the demurrer should be sustained.

The plaintiffs do not challenge the necessity for a right-of-way over their lands if the transmission line is to be built. Their contention is that, because of the existence of other electrical service available in the Elloree area, there is no necessity for the construction by the defendant of its transmission line thereto, and hence that public necessity for the exercise of its power of eminent domain for such construction is lacking. The question thus raised is a legislative or [***12] political one, which is not subject to determination or review by the courts in the absence of fraud, bad faith or clear abuse of discretion on the part of the condemnor. 29 C. J. S., Eminent Domain, § 89, page 882; 18 Am. Jur. 734; Lewis, Law of Eminent Domain, section 597.

In 29 C. J. S., Eminent Domain, § 89, page 882, the applicable principle is thus stated:

"The legislature may delegate the power of determining the necessity of exercising the power of eminent domain to public officers or boards or to private corporations vested with the power of eminent domain, and in the absence of any statutory provision submitting the matter to a court or jury the decision of the question * * * lies with the body of individuals to whom the state has delegated the authority to take. Generally, a determination by the grantee of the power is conclusive and is not subject to judicial review, in the absence of fraud, bad faith, or clear abuse of discretion."

The complaint contains allegations that "the defendant is falsely pretending that a public necessity exists for the construction of its proposed power line," and that "no facts exist which create a public necessity for the construction [***13] of defendant's proposed power line and the false pretence by the defendant that such necessity does in fact exist is made for the purpose of affording the defendant a colorable right to exercise the power of eminent domain, is an effort on the part of the defendant to fraudulently deprive plaintiffs of their property, is an effort to acquire plaintiffs' property for its personal benefit as distinguished from any public benefit arising out of any existing necessity to satisfy the needs of the public for electric power in the area to be served by the said line, constitutes an abuse of the discretion confided in the defendant by applicable statutes, and constitutes a taking of the plaintiffs' property without due process of law."

These allegations are conclusions of law or fact, not admitted by a demurrer, and at most merely characterize the facts set forth in the complaint, which, however, must in themselves show fraud, bad faith, or clear abuse of discretion.

As a cooperative, nonprofit, membership corporation, organized under the Rural Electric Cooperative Act, the defendant has the corporate purpose "of supplying electric energy and promoting and extending the use thereof [***14] in rural areas", Section 8555-92, and has the power under the Act to construct, maintain and operate electric transmission lines, and to exercise the power of eminent domain to obtain rights-of-way therefor, Section 8555-93 (k, l).

"Rural area" is defined as "any area not included within the boundaries of any incorporated or unincorporated city, town, village, or borough having a population in excess of twenty-five hundred (2,500) persons". Section 8555-121 (a).

The Act does not limit the authorized activities of the defendant to rural areas not having existing electric service; it indicated a contrary intention by providing that cooperatives organized under it shall be exempt in all respects from the jurisdiction and control of the Public Service Commission. Section 8555-118.

The complaint does not allege that the area into which the transmission line is to be constructed is not a rural area, as so defined; or that the defendant can carry out its corporate purpose of promoting and extending the use of electric energy in such area without constructing the line; or that the electric service presently available in the area is rendered under a franchise which is exclusive [***15] as against the defendant.

The defendant having the legal right to enter the area to engage in the performance of the purpose for which it was organized, the question whether it should do so in view of the existing electric service with which it will necessarily have to compete was for its determination, and the facts alleged in the complaint are insufficient to authorize or support a finding of fraud, or bad faith, or clear abuse of discretion on its part in making such determination.

The allegation that the condemnation of the right-of-way is for a private use because of the defendant's contracts with the South Carolina Public Service Authority is clearly untenable. It is settled that the defendant's corporate purpose is a public one, and that the exercise of its power of eminent domain to obtain a right-of-way for its transmission line is for a public use. Bookhart v. Central Electric Power Cooperative, Inc., 219 S.C. 414, 65 S.E.2d 781. The Act gives the defendant broad authorization to contract in reference to its transmission system, Section 8555-93 (h), and the Authority has the power to contract with the defendant for use of such system to deliver the electric energy [***16] produced by it to its customers, license to do which it has in the act creating it, "the highest kind of certificate of public convenience and necessity." South Carolina Electric & Gas Co. v. South Carolina Public Service Authority, 215 S.C. 193, 54 S.E.2d 777, 783. Furthermore, it is not alleged in the complaint that more land is required to be taken by the defendant because of its contractual arrangements with the Authority, and the use of its line by the latter. Compare McMeekin v. Central Carolina Power Co., 80 S.C. 512, 518, 61 S.E. 1020, 128 Am. St. Rep. 885.

It is therefore ordered, adjudged and decreed, that the defendant's demurrer to the complaint herein be, and the same hereby is, sustained, and the complaint is dismissed.



DISPOSITION: Exceptions overruled and orders affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff landowners appealed decisions of the Common Pleas Court, Orangeburg and Calhoun Counties (South Carolina), which sustained defendant power corporation's demurrers to the landowners' complaints seeking to enjoin the corporation from condemning a right-of-way across their lands for the purpose of constructing an electric power transmission line.


OVERVIEW: The power corporation brought a condemnation proceeding in order to obtain a right-of-way over the landowners' properties for construction of an electric transmission line. The landowners, in six actions, sought injunctions restraining the corporation, which was organized under the Rural Electric Cooperative Act (Act), S.C. Code Ann. § 8555-91 et seq. (1942), from doing so. The trial courts sustained the corporation's demurrers, which asserted that the complaints failed to state facts sufficient to constitute causes of action where the corporation had authority under the Act to obtain rights-of-way by its power of eminent domain. On appeal, the court affirmed, adopting two trial court orders, and overruled the landowners' exceptions. The court held that the circuit decrees properly disposed of the issues presented where the corporation had the legal right under the act to enter the landowners' property to engage in the performance of the purpose for which it was organized, the facts alleged in the complaints were insufficient to authorize a finding of fraud, bad faith, or clear abuse of discretion, and the question of public necessity was a legislative or political one.


OUTCOME: The court overruled the landowners' exceptions and affirmed the orders of the trial courts sustaining the power corporation's demurrers to the landowners' complaint seeking to enjoin condemnation of their lands for construction of power transmission lines.

 

508 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Talbot v. Myrtle Beach Bd. of Adjustment


16659


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


222 S.C. 165; 72 S.E.2d 66; 1952 S.C. LEXIS 18



August 12, 1952, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Lula E. Talbot and another filed a petition with the Myrtle Beach Board of Adjustment, and others, for a variance from zoning ordinance to permit location of a restaurant in residential zone. The Court of Common Pleas, G. Badger Baker, J., reviewing by certiorari the board's action in denying petition, sustained the board's exceptions to recommendation favorable to petitioners returned by special referee, to whom the matter had been referred, and petitioners appealed. The Supreme Court, Stukes, A. J., held that evidence sustained finding that refusal of application resulted in no unlawful discrimination against petitioners, and, therefore, no deprivation of their property.

Affirmed.



DISPOSITION: Exceptions overruled and judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner landowners sought review of the decision of the Court of Common Pleas (South Carolina), which sustained respondent Myrtle Beach Board of Adjustment's exceptions to a special referee's recommendation that was favorable to the landowners' variance request. The landowners alleged unlawful discrimination in the Board's refusal to grant the landowners a variance to permit the location of a restaurant in a residential zone.


OVERVIEW: The landowners' motor court was included in an R-4 commercial zone that permitted motor courts. Their vacant lots across the highway were zoned R-1, the most restricted residential zoning classification, which did not permit the landowners to construct a public restaurant or dining room there. The landowners contended that enforcement of the zoning ordinance would result in unnecessary hardship to the landowners and that it amounted to an unconstitutional deprivation of property. The court affirmed the trial court's judgment, finding that it could not question the wisdom of the zoning ordinance or the location of the zoning district line that resulted in the vacant lots being included in the restricted residential area. Zoning was within the municipality's legislative discretion, and the court reviewed variance denials for an abuse of discretion. The landowners failed to establish that the refusal of their application for a variance constituted unlawful discrimination. The fact that their vacant lots were zoned for residential purposes even though they were located across the highway from a commercial zone did not establish that they had been discriminated against.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's judgment.

 

509 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Brown v. Moseley


16638


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


222 S.C. 1; 71 S.E.2d 591; 1952 S.C. LEXIS 10



June 12, 1952, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Original action by T. P. Brown against Eugene L. Moseley for a determination that defendant has no right to hold office as sheriff of Kershaw County beyond 1952 and that an election for such office should be held in that year. The Supreme Court, Stukes, J., held that the amendatory statute, providing for the election of the sheriff of such county in the general elections of 1954 and every four years thereafter, is not unconstitutional as a special law concerning a matter to which a general law can be made applicable nor as violating the constitutional provision that an act shall relate to but one subject expressed in its title.

Judgment for defendant and petition-complaint dismissed.

BAKER, C. J., dissented.



DISPOSITION: Judgment dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The court had before it an original action in which plaintiff elector and taxpayer of Kershaw County challenged defendant sheriff's right to hold office as sheriff of that County beyond the year 1952 and asserted that an election for the office should be held in 1952. The validity of Act No. 729 approved February 21, 1952, which specified when elections for sheriff of Kershaw County were to take place, was at issue.


OVERVIEW: A sheriff was elected to a second four-year term and died during it, and defendant sheriff was appointed for the rest of the term, which ended in 1954 counting four years from the incumbent's reelection. Section 3473 of the Code of 1942 said that there was to be an election for sheriff held in each county except certain specified counties every four years starting with 1904. Ergo, an election in 1954 would not have been in conformity with that statute. However, that statute was amended by Act No. 729 approved February 21, 1952 to say that Kershaw County was to have an election for sheriff in 1954 and every four years thereafter. The court rejected the argument that the amended statute could not be applied. Subsection IX of § 34 of Art. III of the South Carolina Constitution of 1895 prohibited a special law where a general law could be applied. The court wrote that a special provision in the general law was the logical remedy as Kershaw County had been off the statutory schedule for sheriff elections for years, and the amended part was not more special than the excepting of several counties from the general schedule in earlier statutes and in the part not amended.


OUTCOME: The court rendered judgment for the sheriff and dismissed the complaint of the elector and taxpayer.

 

510 of 598 DOCUMENTS


State v. McIntire


16636


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


221 S.C. 504; 71 S.E.2d 410; 1952 S.C. LEXIS 118



June 10, 1952, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Defendant was convicted in the General Sessions Court of Richland County, Steve C. Griffith, J., of conspiracy to set up a lottery known as the numbers game and for operating a numbers game, and he appealed. The Supreme Court, Fishburne, J., held that it was reversible error to limit defendant's counsel to reply argument of five minutes.

Judgment reversed.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of a judgment from the General Sessions Court of Richland County (South Carolina), which convicted defendant of conspiring to set up an illegal lottery and of setting up an illegal lottery. In seeking review, defendant claimed various errors, including the trial court's decision to limit defendant's and the co-defendants' time for making reply arguments.


OVERVIEW: After defendant and co-defendants were caught running a numbers game, the parties were indicted jointly, and defendant was convicted of conspiring to set up an illegal lottery and of setting up an illegal lottery. Thereafter, defendant sought review, and the court reversed. Initially, the court held the indictment had sufficiently informed defendant of the charges and had alleged an act within the trial court's jurisdiction that furthered the conspiracy. After finding ample evidence of a conspiracy, the court also held defendant had not been entitled to a severance because the defenses of the various parties had not been separate and distinct. Furthermore, the court rejected defendant's claims that that trial court had erred in calling an alternate, thirteenth juror and that there was not a statutory sentence for conspiring to set up a lottery. However, the court upheld defendant's claim that the trial court had erred in limiting defendant's and the co-defendants' time for making reply arguments. In so holding, the court found the limitation had been too restrictive to allow a full discussion of the defenses, thereby depriving defendant of the right to be fully heard.


OUTCOME: In reversing a judgment which convicted defendant of conspiring to set up an illegal lottery and of setting up an illegal lottery, the court held the trial court had erred in limiting defendant's and the co-defendants' time for making reply arguments.

 

511 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Wagener v. Smith


16630


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


221 S.C. 438; 71 S.E.2d 1; 1952 S.C. LEXIS 109



May 26, 1952, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Action by J. A. Wagener and others, constituting the Township Commissioners of the Township of Folly Island, against F. B. Smith, Bartley J. Riddock and others to test the validity of the corporate existence of the Township of Folly Island and the Town of Folly Beach. The Common Pleas Court, Charleston County, T. B. Greneker, J., entered order in favor of plaintiffs and all the defendants except Bartley J. Riddock appealed. The Supreme Court, Oxner, J., held that upon incorporation of an island as a town the powers and functions of the township commissioners were superseded by the newly created municipal government, at least to the extent of any conflict between jurisdiction and the powers of the two units of government.

Order reversed in part and affirmed in part, and case remanded with directions.



DISPOSITION: Order reversed in part, affirmed in part and case remanded.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: This was an action brought by the Township Commissioners of the Township of Folly Island brought against defendants to test the validity of the corporate existence of the Township of Folly Island and the Town of Folly Beach.
