The Statutes, however, under which the Sheriff here claims are statewide Statutes and, until 1935, it was not permissible that the Legislature make special provision as to a particular County different from these general Statutes. Salley v. McCoy, 182 S.C. 249, 189 S.E. 196. But it was held by the Supreme Court that, notwithstanding the 1935 amendment to Article 3, Section 34, subdivision IX permits such special legislation with respect to the compensation of the officers of particular Counties, that could not be done by the Supply Act (Scott v. Anderson County, 195 S.C. 92, 10 S.E.2d 359). Petitioner recognizes this rule, but contends that the enactment of Section 4084 and the other sections mentioned in the 1942 Code constitutes the enactment of a Statute in accordance with the 1935 amendment as required by the rule stated in the Scott case. However, it is my opinion that this is not a sufficient legislative adoption specifically of a change [***22] in the method of paying the Sheriff of Cherokee County, so as to limit the amounts payable to him as costs and fees to the amounts appropriated by the Supply Act. It is not questioned but that, since the 1935 amendment, this could be done, but it is my view that the necessary Statute has not been enacted.

Petitioner also contends that the allowance of additional claims for this period to the Plaintiff-Sheriff is violative of the provisions of Section 11 of the Cherokee County Supply Act under consideration, which provides in effect that the amounts therein appropriated shall be paid out as near as practical one-twelfth each month, and if there is any overpayment in any one month, that it shall be deducted the following month. If it had sufficiently been legislated as to Cherokee County to make special provision for the payment of compensation to the Sheriff so as to remove him from the general effect of the statewide Statutes, and limit him to the amounts appropriated in any particular Supply Act, then this would be a correct position, but, as indicated just above, the necessary special legislation has not been enacted to accomplish this purpose.

Petitioner also insists that [***23] the allowance of claims to the Plaintiff for this period of time should not be made without determining and deducting the amounts paid to the Sheriff for preceding periods for amounts that represent fees not legally collectible, such as fees for witness warrants not served, unallowable mileage, etc., similar to those disallowed for the period under consideration. It is true that the evidence shows that claims for fees were made and allowed in previous periods on exactly the same basis as made for this period, and that, therefore, it would appear that there have been paid amounts in previous periods for items of costs not legally applicable. This is demonstrated by the testimony of former Sheriff Allison (made applicable to the Clary case) and by the testimony of the Special Auditor who prepared this audit. The Petitioner also has insisted throughout that an audit should be made for this previous period, if necessary, in order to establish the exact amount of such disallowable, but previously paid, items. I am of the opinion that this position should be overruled. The period of time involved in this litigation is only from July 1st, 1947, to December 31st, 1947, and the Order of Judge [***24] Sease specifically limited the making of the audit to this six-month period, and no other months. Furthermore, the claims for these previous months have already been allowed and paid, and it does not seem to me that now the approval of the claims by the County Board of Commissioners, and their payment upon such approval, can be reopened and inquired into. See Richland County v. Miller, 16 S.C. 244, and 16 S.C. 236, and Section 3871 of the 1942 Code.

There are other positions incidental to these major contentions, but what has been said substantially disposes of all positions of the Petitioner presented by the exceptions.

All exceptions of both Plaintiff and Petitioner, except those sustained by the findings and holdings herein made, be and the same are hereby overruled.

It is Ordered and Adjudged that the Plaintiff, Roland T. Clary, as Sheriff of Cherokee County, is entitled to and has valid claims against Cherokee County for $ 4,086.25 for the period from July 1st, 1947, to December 31st, 1947, and the same are approved to this extent, but all others claims disallowed and refused.

It is Accordingly so Ordered.

Order of Judge J. HENRY JOHNSON in the Allison [***25] case.

There is this day being filed an Order signed by me in the case involving the claims of Roland T. Clary, as Sheriff of Cherokee County, in which the issues are in substance the same as those involved in this case, which is a contest over the claims of Lee Allison, as former Sheriff of Cherokee County, for the period from November 1st, 1946, to January 7th, 1947. What has been said in the Clary Order is of equal application to this case, except as to amounts and that Order is, therefore, made a part of this Order.

The Order of the County Board of Commissioners is this case approved as valid claims in favor of Lee Allison against Cherokee County in the amount of $ 1,393.45. This finding is approved with these modifications:

There is also allowed the additional sum of $ 12.00 for service of arrest warrants by Deputy Sheriffs; there is disallowed the sum of $ 104.00 representing the service of arrest warrants by rural policemen, leaving a balance of $ 1,301.45, and it is hereby adjudged that Lee Allison, as former Sheriff of Cherokee County, has valid claims against Cherokee County in the amount of $ 1,301.45, and that all other claims on his part be and the same are [***26] hereby disallowed and refused.

Except to the extent herein indicated, the exceptions of both the Plaintiff and the Petitioner be and the same are herby overruled.

It is Accordingly so Ordered.



DISPOSITION: Judgment modified and affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, a county sheriff and his predecessor, sought writs of mandamus commanding defendants, a county supervisor and board of commissioners, to pass on the sheriffs' claims for fees due them for performance of their duties as sheriff during certain periods. The parties each challenged a judgment of the Common Pleas Court of Cherokee County (South Carolina), which reduced the claims and ordered payment of such reduced amounts.


OVERVIEW: The sheriffs sought writs of mandamus commanding defendants to pass on their claims for fees due them. The board approved in part and rejected in part each of the claims. On appeal, the trial court further reduced the claims and ordered payment of such reduced amounts. Defendants' contention that sums allegedly illegally paid the sheriffs as fees for periods before those involved in the proceedings should be offset against the then instant claims was properly rejected by the trial court as outside the pleadings, which were expressly limited to specific claims submitted to and passed on by the board. But the court held that that the board was not barred from taking such action as it might deem proper to assert a right of recovery of sums theretofore paid in violation of the rules laid down in the trial court's decrees.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the circuit court.

 

532 of 598 DOCUMENTS


National Cash Register Co. v. Burns


16387


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


217 S.C. 310; 60 S.E.2d 615; 1950 S.C. LEXIS 122



July 19, 1950, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Huntington & Guerry, Inc., brought receivership proceedings against E. R. Bull, individually and as executor of the will of Walter P. Bull, and B. M. Bull, copartners, doing business under the trade-name and style of Star Cleaners & Laundry, and John Burns was appointed receiver of Star Cleaners & Laundry. The National Cash Register Company, a corporation, filed its claim in the receivership proceedings for balance due for cash registers which it had sold to the Star Cleaners & Laundry under title retention, installment contracts which were chattel mortgages, and which provided for monthly payments of $ 105.00. The County Court of Greenville County, W. B. McGowan, J., rendered an order directing the receiver to pay the National Cash Register Company, a corporation, five per cent a year on balance of $ 1,077.00 owing for the cash registers, and the National Cash Register Company, a corporation, appealed. The Supreme Court, Stukes J., held that the National Cash Register Company, a corporation, was confined for its remedy to the forum of the receivership, but that County Court could not prevent enforcement of the liens of the National Cash Register Company, a corporation.

Order reversed [***2] and case remanded.

OXNER and FISHBURNE, JJ., dissented.



DISPOSITION: Order reversed and case remanded.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant creditor sought review of an order of the Greenville County Court (South Carolina), which modified its former order and directed respondent receiver to pay the creditor five percent per annum on the decreasing monthly balance due it.


OVERVIEW: Prior to receivership, the creditor had sold the company cash registers, payment for which was $ 105 monthly. The creditor established its claims with the receiver and without notice to the creditor, the trial court ordered that payments to the creditor should be $ 50 per month. The creditor petitioned for possession of the machines in accordance with the contracts and amended at the hearing to ask in the alternative for a sale of the mortgaged property by the receiver in foreclosure of the liens. The trial court denied the petition and modified the order. On appeal, the court reversed and remanded. The trial court erred when it prevented enforcement of the liens. The installment contracts were properly considered by the parties as chattel mortgages and the validity of them as liens was unquestioned. The legal right to enforcement had already been suspended unduly long by the receivership. The court held that the trial court violated the constitutional limitations and abused its discretion with respect to the administration of the property in receivership. It was unjust and therefore inequitable to deny the creditor the right to enforcement of its liens.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the order directing the receiver to pay the creditor five percent per annum on the decreasing monthly balance due it and remanded the case for further proceedings.

 

533 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Tindall v. Byars


16352


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


217 S.C. 1; 59 S.E.2d 337; 1950 S.C. LEXIS 87



May 2, 1950, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Taxpayer's action by James F. Tindall, individually and in behalf of himself and all other taxpayers of Chester County, against W. A. Byars, chairman, and others, constituting the County Board of Directors of Chester County, for a judgment declaring invalid legislative efforts to create a single school district, in Chester County, determining the obligor upon existing school district indebtedness, and enjoining proposed issuance of hospital bonds by Chester County. The Common Pleas Court of Chester County, T. B. Greneker, J., entered a judgment from which plaintiff appealed. The Supreme Court, Stukes, J., held that consolidation of school districts in Chester County into a single district is a proper exercise of legislative authority contained in constitutional amendment and that newly created school district and not the county is chargeable with indebtedness incurred by former school districts.

Exceptions overruled and judgment affirmed.



DISPOSITION: Exceptions overruled and judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff taxpayer filed suit against defendant county board of directors seeking to declare invalid an act creating a single school district coextensive with the territory of a county and determining the obligor on the existing school district indebtedness. He challenged a judgment of the Common Pleas Court of Chester County (South Carolina), which found that the school district was lawfully created and had lawfully assumed the indebtedness.


OVERVIEW: Section 5 of art. XI of the South Carolina Constitution of 1895 prescribed the limits of the area of school districts. 45 Stat. 2510, 46 Stat. 23, amended the Constitution by provided that the limitation did not apply to school districts in a certain county and in that county school districts would be of such area as the general assembly or the county board of education prescribed. The whole area of the county was constituted one school district by the consolidation of all of the former districts. The general assembly passed an act, providing that the new district assumed the indebtedness of the former districts. The taxpayer sought a judgment declaring the creation of the new district invalid. The circuit court ruled against him. The court held that the act consolidating the several school districts of the county into the new district was valid. The amendment to the Constitution removed the county from the limitation of the area of school districts. The new district was chargeable with the indebtedness the former separate districts incurred. The new school district's indebtedness was to be calculated without inclusion of the school district debt.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment.

 

534 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Dillon County v. Maryland Casualty Co.


16345


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


217 S.C. 66; 59 S.E.2d 640; 1950 S.C. LEXIS 96



April 20, 1950, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Action by the County of Dillon against W. E. Allen, Probate Judge of that county and the Maryland Casualty Company, surety, for an accounting with respect to the fees on all marriage licenses issued, or which should have been issued, by him as probate judge. The Common Pleas Court of Dillon County, J. Woodrow Lewis, J., entered an order sustaining a demurrer to the complaint and dismissing the complaint, and plaintiff appealed. The Supreme Court, Oxner, J., held that neither the probate judge, nor his surety, could attack validity of statute requiring the probate judge of Dillon County to perform marriage ceremonies during office hours.

Order reversed and case remanded with directions.



DISPOSITION: Order reversed and case remanded.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff county appealed the judgment by the Common Pleas Court of Dillon County (South Carolina), which sustained the demurrer filed by defendants judge and his surety in the county's action for an accounting.


OVERVIEW: The county contended that the judge had failed to collect fees for marriage licenses under 45 St. at L. 1612 (South Carolina 1948). When the judge failed to account for the fees, the county filed an action against the judge and his surety. The trial court sustained the judge and the surety's demurrer and dismissed the case. On the county's appeal, the court reversed. The fact that only the county in question required the collection of fees for a license issued by a probate judge did not make the law a special law in violation of S.C. Const. art. III, § 34. The judge had no standing to contest the fairness of charging $ 4 for a license in the county when a marriage license cost only $ 1 on other counties. The judge also had no standing to argue that the statute contravened the anti-establishment clause, S.C. Const. art I, § 4. No right of the judge was infringed upon by requiring him to perform marriage ceremonies during office hours.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment and remanded the case.

 

535 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Owens v. Smith


16325


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


216 S.C. 382; 58 S.E.2d 332; 1950 S.C. LEXIS 26



March 9, 1950, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Actions between John J. Owens, and F. O. Smith and others, and between Jessie Lee and Harry L. Carter, Jr., and others, involving the constitutionality of acts of the General Assembly authorizing commissioners of certain public service districts to promulgate and enforce zoning regulations. From decisions of the Common Pleas Court of Charleston County, William H. Grimball, J., holding the acts to be unconstitutional, F. O. Smith and others and Harry L. Carter, Jr., and others, respectively, appealed. The Supreme Court, Stukes, J., held that Act April 14, 1948, 45 St. at Large, p. 1996, and Act April 24, 1948, 45 St. at Large, p. 2004, authorizing commissioners of the public service district of Charleston County to promulgate and enforce zoning regulations, were invalid as violative of constitutional prohibition against enactment of a special law in cases where a general law can be made applicable.

Affirmed.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The Common Pleas Court of Charleston County (South Carolina) declared invalid two acts authorizing the commissioners of a certain public service district to promulgate and enforce zoning regulations. Appellants sought review of the judgment.


OVERVIEW: Respondents argued, and the lower court concurred, that the acts in question were invalid because they conflicted with § 34 of Art. III, subsection 9, of the State Constitution of 1895, which prohibited the enactment by the legislature of a special law in cases where a general law could be made applicable. The court affirmed the judgment, holding that there was no showing in the record of any need for special legislation for the named public service district. The court found that the authority of government to zone the use of privately owned property was founded in the police power. The court found that there no good reason appeared why the police power should be exercised by the corporate authorities of one district and not by the others, particularly when those districts were comparable in size and population. Nothing in the acts authorizing the commissioners to promulgate and enforce zoning regulations justified the classification. The court found that because the subject of the legislation was reasonably susceptible to general treatment, the special treatment contained in the acts violated the constitutional prohibition.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed.

 

536 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Harrell v. Columbia


16323


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


216 S.C. 346; 58 S.E.2d 91; 1950 S.C. LEXIS 24



March 3, 1950, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] J. C. Harrell and others, personally and on behalf of all persons having similar interests, and H. G. Moore and others, personally and on behalf of all persons having similar interests, brought separate suits against the City of Columbia, its mayor and members of the city council, for judgment declaring elections for annexation of areas to the city, null and void, and for injunctive relief. The Court of Common Pleas of Richland County, T. B. Greneker, J., ordered that the complaints should be dismissed and rules to show cause dissolved, and plaintiffs appealed. The Supreme Court, L. D. Lide, A. A. J., held that the defects complained by the elections were at most irregularities not invalidating the elections, and that the annexations did not deprive plaintiffs of their constitutional rights as to due process and taxation without representation.

Orders affirmed.



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant taxpayers filed an action against respondents, a city, its mayor, and its city council, for a judgment declaring elections for the annexation of property under Code, § 7230, as amended, was null and void, and for injunctive relief. The Court of Common Pleas of Richland County (South Carolina) entered orders dismissing the complaint and dissolving the rules to show cause. The taxpayers appealed.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayers contended that the annexation was void and unconstitutional because of procedural irregularities and because the additional tax burden deprived them of their property without due process of law. In affirming the dismissal of the complaint, the court held that (1) the circuit judge did not err in holding that the petitions were accompanied by adequate descriptions of the areas involved because persons of reasonable and average intelligence were able to identify the property involved, (2) the city council properly determined that a majority of the freeholders signed each of the petitions for the elections, (3) the notices of the elections constituted a sufficient compliance with § 7230, and in spite of the fact that one of the notices was published 4 days before the election in stead of 10 days as required by § 7230, there was no evidence that the irregularity deprived anyone of the right to vote, and (4) the taxpayers did not have the right to complain on appeal that § 7230 was defective because it did not provide a hearing to contest the petitions that were in favor of the annexation because they never requested a hearing before the city council.


OUTCOME: The orders that dismissed the taxpayers' complaint and dissolved the rules to show cause was affirmed.

 

537 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Parker v. Bates


16284


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


216 S.C. 52; 56 S.E.2d 723; 1949 S.C. LEXIS 122



November 18, 1949, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Original action by Thomas Parker, a Greenville citizen and taxpayer, to enjoin Jeff B. Bates, Treasurer, and E. C. Rhodes, Comptroller General of the State of South Carolina, from carrying out provisions of the act authorizing allocation of state tax funds to counties for construction of health centers and hospitals.

The Supreme Court, Stukes, J., held that the act was valid except the appropriation item which permitted use of the funds by counties for "other public uses", which was stricken as unconstitutional, and injunction was denied with respect to valid provisions of the act.

Oxner and Taylor, JJ., dissented.



DISPOSITION: Injunction denied for valid provisions of act, and temporary restraining order dissolved.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff county taxpayer sought to enjoin the treasurer and comptroller general of the State of South Carolina from carrying out the provision of Act. No. 344 of the Acts of the General Assembly of 1949, 46 S.C. Stat. 768, an act authorizing allocation of state tax funds to counties for construction of health centers and hospitals.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiff challenged the constitutionality of the Act No. 344 of the Acts of the General Assembly of 1949, 46 S.C. Stat. 768, entitled "An Act to allocate funds to the counties of the State for the construction of health centers, hospitals, or for other public purposes; and further relating to the fiscal affairs of the State," on the grounds that the provision permitting money to be used for privately owned eleemosynary hospitals was invalid because it was a grant of public funds for a sectarian purpose; that the provisions permitting the money to be used "for other public uses" was invalid because it failed to specify the uses; and that the hospital and health center provisions of the Act were invalid because they constituted a use of state funds for a county purpose. The court held that the act was valid except the appropriation item which permitted the use of the funds by counties for "other public uses." In the Act, the legislature set out to itemize specified public uses or purposes, which would have been undone by the sustention of the alternative appropriation for "other public uses."


OUTCOME: The court determined that the Act was valid except for the appropriation provision allowing use of the funds for "other public uses," which was stricken as unconstitutional. The court denied the injunction with respect to the other, valid provisions of the Act, and the temporary restraining order theretofore issued was dissolved.

 

538 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Prosser v. Seaboard Air Line R.R. Co.


16267


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


216 S.C. 33; 56 S.E.2d 591; 1949 S.C. LEXIS 121



October 11, 1949, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Proceeding by C. Prosser intendant and other wardens of the town of Johnsonville to establish a crossing over the Seaboard Air Line Railroad Company.

At a hearing before the Florence County Governing Board it was found that convenience and necessity required the crossing and an appeal was taken to the court of common pleas at Florence County, L. D. Lide, J., which dismissed petition to the order and the railroad company appealed.

The Supreme Court, Taylor, J., affirmed the judgment holding that the evidence established that the crossing was necessary, that the railroad was not deprived of its property without compensation and without due process and that the fact that three members were absent from the hearing of the board but joined in signing the order did not invalidate it.



DISPOSITION: Exceptions dismissed and judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant railroad company sought review of a decision of the Court of Common Pleas for Florence County (South Carolina), which dismissed all exceptions by the railroad company to the order of a county governing board, which ordered the establishment of a street crossing, constructed pursuant to § 8434 of the 1942 Code of Laws for South Carolina in an action by respondent town intendant and town wardens.


OVERVIEW: Respondents filed a petition with the county governing board for the construction of a street crossing over the railroad's right of way. Respondents alleged that the crossing was required by public convenience and necessity. The railroad alleged that the county governing board's order constituted an unconstitutional taking, that the crossing was contrary to the public's safety, and that the hearing on the issue before the board was conducted in the absence of its full membership. The evidence showed the town's population, the use of the streets, and the need of the public for the crossing. On appeal, the court affirmed. The court was bound by the findings of fact of the board, which were approved by the circuit court judge, as there was evidence upon which to base the findings. The evidence supported the order for the street crossing. The order was not a taking in violation of the railroad's due process rights, as the railroad was subject to state police power, and it received its charter and franchise subject to the implied right of the state to open streets across its right of way. The board's proceedings were in accordance with § 4351 of the 1942 Code for South Carolina.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the circuit court.

 

539 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Textile Hall Corp. v. Hill


16256


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


215 S.C. 262; 54 S.E.2d 809; 1949 S.C. LEXIS 87



August 18, 1949, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] The Textile Hall Corporation, incorporated under law relating to non-stock eleemosynary corporations and organized primarily for holding biannual textile expositions, sought to recover from A. W. Hill, Treasurer of Greenville County, property taxes, including penalties, covering the year 1944 on the ground that plaintiff was a charitable corporation and that its real estate was exempt from taxation.

From a judgment in the Common Pleas Court of Greenville County, L. D. Lide and Steve C. Griffith, Judges, for the plaintiff, the defendant appealed.

The Supreme Court, Baker, C. J., reversed the judgment, holding that the special exemption statute was invalid, and that the corporation was not within the constitutional exemption.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant, a county treasurer, sought review of a judgment of the Common Pleas Court of Greenville County (South Carolina), which was entered for plaintiff, a nonstock eleemosynary corporation, in the corporation's action to recover property taxes on the ground that the corporation was a charitable corporation whose real estate was exempt from taxation.


OVERVIEW: The county placed the corporation's real estate on the tax books for a particular year. The corporation protested the action, but the county levied taxes and imposed penalties for nonpayment. The corporation paid the taxes under protest and filed an action for refund in the circuit court. The corporation asserted that its real estate was exempt from taxation by the county because it was an eleemosynary corporation within the provisions of S.C. Code § 8158 et seq., and because the corporation was expressly exempted from state, county, or city taxes by name under a 1936 act codified at S.C. Code § 2578(54). The circuit court disapproved the recommendations of a master and held that the corporation was entitled to the exemption it claimed. The court held that the 1936 act was not a valid exercise of legislative power because the corporation had only private character and purposes and the absence of factual support for recitals in the preamble of the 1936 act and the corporation's property was not exempt from taxation under applicable constitutional and statutory provisions.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the trial court's judgment.

 

540 of 598 DOCUMENTS


South Carolina Electric & Gas Co. v. South Carolina Public Service Authority


16244


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


215 S.C. 193; 54 S.E.2d 777; 1949 S.C. LEXIS 81



August 1, 1949, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal from Court of Common Pleas of Berkeley County; E. H. Henderson, Judge.

Action by the South Carolina Electric & Gas Company and others against the South Carolina Public Service Authority to enjoin the defendant from alleged intended violations and evasions of state and federal statutes and for a declaratory judgment declaring that plaintiffs had right to freedom in their areas from competition by defendant, that defendant is subject to jurisdiction of Public Service Commission in certain respects, and that construction, operation, and acquisition of proposed electric transmission system are ultra vires. From an order overruling the demurrer of the defendant, the defendant appeals.

Reversed and remanded.



DISPOSITION: Reversed and remanded.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant, the South Carolina Public Service Authority (authority), appealed from an order of the Court of Common Pleas of Berkeley County (South Carolina), which overruled its demurrer to the complaint. Plaintiff power companies' complaint sought a declaratory judgment that the power companies had the right to freedom in their areas from competition by the authority.


OVERVIEW: The power companies were unsuccessful in their attempt to enjoin the construction and operation of the authority, which was a municipal owned power generation plant that was to deliver energy to coops within the power companies' service areas. The power companies then sought a declaration that they had a right to freedom from competition, that the authority was subject to the jurisdiction of the South Carolina Public Service Commission (commission) in certain respects, and that construction, operation, and acquisition of the proposed electric transmission system were ultra vires. The authority's demurrer was overruled by the trial court, but the court sustained the demurrer on appeal. The court held that the power companies did not have an exclusive franchise for the sale of electric current, and thus, no right of theirs was invaded by the competition. The authority was excluded from the commission's jurisdiction pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. § 8555-1 et seq. The trial court erred by holding that the complaint stated a cause of action for declaratory relief because it contained no allegations of fact that warranted any present or future relief in law or equity to the power companies.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the order, which had overruled the demurrer to the power companies' complaint that sought a declaration that they had a right to be free from competition by the authority. The court remanded for entry of an order sustaining the authority's demurrer.

 

541 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Kalber v. Redfearn


16242


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


215 S.C. 224; 54 S.E.2d 791; 1949 S.C. LEXIS 83



July 29, 1949, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal from Court of Common Pleas of Darlington County; J. Woodrow Lewis, Judge.

Action by G. A. Kalber against J. B. Redfearn and others, constituting the Board of Trustees of Hartsville School District No. 32 of Darlington County, the State of South Carolina, for determination of whether joint resolution proposing amendment to constitution was required to be presented to Governor before becoming effective. From an adverse judgment, plaintiff appeals.

Exceptions overruled and judgment affirmed.

Order of Judge Lewis follows:

This matter comes before me on motion of the plaintiff to overrule the demurrer to his complaint.

The plaintiff is a resident and taxpayer of Hartsville School District No. 32, of Darlington County, the State of South Carolina. The defendants constitute the Board of Trustees of said School District.

The issue here requires the determination of a constitutional question, novel in this jurisdiction. It is the question of whether it is required that there be presented to the Governor, in the manner contemplated by Section 23, Article IV, of the Constitution, Joint Resolutions adopted by the General Assembly pursuant to Section 1 of Article [***2] XVI, proposing amendments to the Constitution of the State.

The 1948 session of the General Assembly adjourned sine die on Thursday, April 15th, 1948. On that date, three Joint Resolutions, each proposing Amendments to the Constitution, were duly enrolled, ratified, and signed by the President of the Senate and Speaker of the House of Representatives. Each of these contained proposals that Section 5 of Article X of the Constitution be amended by enlarging the then existing debt limits of three school districts (See Permanent Senate Journal for 1948, pages 1473, 1479 and 1481). The Joint Resolution, which is concerned in this litigation, 45 Stat. at Large, page 2586, proposed that the original provisions of Section 5, Article X, imposing a limit on Hartsville School District No. 32 be stricken therefrom and in lieu of the original provisions that said School District be authorized to issue bonds to an amount not exceeding fifteen per centum (15%) of the assessed value of all taxable property therein. Section 3 of the Joint Resolution provided that the Resolution should take effect upon its approval by the Governor.

It appears that after the original Joint Resolution was enrolled [***3] and ratified by the action of the two Houses, and signed by the President of the Senate and Speaker of the House, it was delivered on the same day by the Clerk of the Senate to the Governor, in accordance with Rule 7 of the Joint Rules of the Senate and House. Thereafter, the Governor wrote across the cover of the Joint Resolution:

"Amendment to Constitution--Governor's Signature not required. J. Strom Thurmond, April 17, 1948."

Governor Thurmond's action in respect to this Resolution was similar to his action on every Joint Resolution proposing amendments to the Constitution that were adopted by the General Assembly during his term of office. But in all cases, except with respect to the three Resolutions enrolled on this particular day (April 15th, 1948), his failure to return them to the House in which they originated within the time limit prescribed by Section 23 of Article IV, had the same effect upon these other Joint Resolutions, as though he had signed them. Cf. Goree v. Greenwood County Supervisor, 93 S.C. 312, 76 S.E. 705.

Notwithstanding the fact that the Governor failed to approve the Joint Resolution, the Secretary of State submitted the question proposed [***4] by the Joint Resolution in the General Election held on November 2nd, 1948, on which occasion the same was approved by a vote of 3,392 to 605. During its 1949 session, the General Assembly ratified the proposed amendment as a part of the State Constitution.

The Governor's action in refusing to approve this Joint Resolution squarely raises the question of whether his approval was necessary, for it is seen from the foregoing recitation of facts that the General Assembly's adjournment on the day that the Joint Resolution was presented to him prevented the running of the three-day period provided for in Section 23, Article IV of the Constitution. His action also raises the subordinate question as to whether this particular Resolution became effective in time to justify the submission of the question at the 1948 Election, notwithstanding that it might be unnecessary for the Governor to sign Resolutions of this sort, because by its own terms it provided that it should not take effect until it had been signed by the Governor. If the answer to this question be the negative, then the Joint Resolution did not finally become effective until two days following the convening of the 1949 General [***5] Assembly, to wit, on January 13th, 1949, with the result that the proposal submitted at the election held in November, 1948, was prematurely submitted. I shall discuss these questions in the order presented.

Question 1

Do Joint Resolutions proposing Amendments to the Constitution of this State and agreed to by two-thirds of the members elected to each House fall within the purview of Section 23, Article IV of the Constitution, which provides that "Every Bill or Joint Resolution which shall have passed the General Assembly, except on a question of adjournment, shall, before it becomes a Law, be presented to the Governor * * *."

It is, of course, a recognized principle of American constitutional law that questions relating to the Constitution of the several States must be interpreted by the Courts of each State.

"The conformity with the State Constitution of the proceedings in the enactment of the law is a question for the determination of the State Court and its judgment is final." Smith, Rec'r. v. Jennings, 206 U.S. 276, 27 S. Ct. 610, 611, 51 L. Ed. 1061.

For this reason, decisions of other courts interpreting questions arising under the Constitution of their [***6] respective States are interesting and, perhaps, persuasive, but they are not controlling. Consequently, it occurred to me that I should first examine this question from the standpoint of the present Constitution of South Carolina, and former Constitutions of this State, and decide the question, if possible, by reference to those documents, and afterwards determine if my views found support in the Courts of other jurisdictions. With that in mind, I have examined not only the provisions of our present Constitution, but I have referred also to our former Constitutions.

Since its disavowance of allegiance to the British Crown, South Carolina has had five Constitutions. The first is that adopted by the Congress held in Charleston over the period beginning November 1st, 1775, and ending March 26th, 1776. This document is referred to as the "Constitution of South Carolina, 26th of March, 1776". Two matters, of interest to this question, appear in this document.

In the first place, there is no provision in the document for its amendment. In this respect, the document is statutory in nature, for its alteration could take place by subsequent statutory enactments. Just such an alteration [***7] did take place with the enactment of March 19, 1778, which was the Act of the General Assembly establishing the Constitution of 1778.

A second matter of interest in the 1776 document is the provision of Article VII, which vested the legislative authority of the Colony, as this State was referred to in that document, in the President (of the Colony), the General Assembly (a body comparable to the present House of Representatives) and the Legislative Council (a body whose modern counterpart with enlarged powers is the Senate). Article VIII provided that all bills must be presented to the President and that they would not become law without his assent.

The Constitution established in 1778 vested the legislative authority in a General Assembly to consist of two distinct bodies, a Senate and a House of Representatives. It thus removed the veto power which existed under the Constitution of 1776. It also provided that the document itself might not be amended without 90 days notice and unless a majority of the members of the House of Representatives and the Senate consent. The Constitution of 1778 remained in force until that adopted in 1790, which, because of the fact that it is [***8] our first Constitution adopted subsequent to the adoption of the Constitution of the United States and afterwards remained in effect for 78 years, makes it a document of considerable significance. Under this document there was no power of veto, the applicable Section providing merely that Bills and Ordinances should have the force of law when the same had been read three times on three several days in each House, had the Great Seal affixed to it, and had been signed in the Senate House by the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives (Section 16, Article I). Article XI provided for the amendment of the Constitution and because there exists a significant difference between this provision and those appearing in the Constitutions of 1868 and 1895, I shall make reference to it. It states, in part:

"No part of this constitution shall be altered, unless a bill to alter the same shall have been read three times in the house of representatives, and three times in the senate, and agreed to by two-thirds of both branches of the whole representation * * *."

I shall later emphasize that those writing this document contemplated that the vehicle proposing [***9] amendments to it be in the form of a Bill.

The Constitution of 1868 restored the veto power of the State's Chief Executive. Section 22, Article III. The provisions of this Section are, for the purposes of this discussion, substantially identical to the provisions now appearing in the present Constitution and found therein as Section 23 of Article IV. The veto power in both documents provides that,

"Every Bill or Joint Resolution which shall have passed the General Assembly, except on the question of adjournment, shall, before it becomes a law, be presented to the Governor."

The Constitution of 1868 contained provisions permitting its amendment. Article XV of that document prescribes the way in which the Constitution is to be amended, and while, once again, minor differences exist between the provisions of the Constitution of 1868, dealing with the amendment of that document, and those found in the Constitution of 1895, as Article XVI, for the purpose of this discussion, the provisions may be deemed identical.

The provisions of the two Constitutions dealing with the manner of proposing amendments, provide:

"That any amendment or amendments to this Constitution [***10] may be proposed in the Senate or the House of Representatives if the same be agreed to by two-thirds of the members elected to each House, such amendment or amendments shall be entered on the Journals respectively, with the yeas and nays taken thereon; and the same shall be submitted to the qualified electors of the State, at the next general election thereafter for Representatives * * *."

Some twelve amendments were made to the Constitution of 1868. An examination of the Statutes at Large of South Carolina for the applicable years shows that in every instance the amendments were proposed by Joint Resolutions. Apparently, each was presented to the Governor for in every instance there appears a notation that the same was approved. Countless amendments have been proposed to the Constitution of 1895, and from an examination of the legislative action taken in proposing these amendments, it seems that the Joint Resolution has invariably been the vehicle used by the General Assembly. In every instance, they were submitted to the Governor for his approval and most of them contain a provision similar to that found in Section 3 of this Resolution, providing that the Joint Resolution should [***11] take effect upon its approval by the Governor. In at least one instance, the Governor has undertaken to veto a Joint Resolution. In 1938, the General Assembly, by Joint Resolution, proposed to amend the Constitution to provide for the retirement of Judges of the Supreme Court and Circuit Courts. This Resolution was delivered to Governor Johnston on May 9th, 1938, and he vetoed it subsequent to the adjournment of the General Assembly on July 23, 1938. Notwithstanding his veto, the question proposed was submitted in the election held in November of that year, but failed to carry. When it was returned to the House of Representatives, from whence it originated, the Speaker ruled the matter of the veto out of order because of the fact that the proposal had failed to carry in the election.

It has been strongly argued to me, that this course of conduct on the part of the General Assembly, in submitting Joint Resolutions proposing Amendments, to the Executive, since the restoration of the veto power by the 1868 Constitution, requires the Court to construe Section 1 of Article XVI, and Section 23 of Article IV in such a way as to harmonize the two. It has been urged that the longstanding [***12] precedent, followed by each General Assembly, for a period of nearly 90 years, and the acquiescence therein by all of the State's Chief Executives, except the present incumbent, establishes a persuasive, if not a binding precedent. I recognize that the Courts, where possible, will adopt a construction of a constitutional provision in keeping with the construction given to the provision by the coordinate branches of the Government. But such constructions are not controlling. In the last resort, the Constitution must be interpreted by the Court. Gentry v. Taylor, 192 S.C. 145, 5 S.E.2d 857. For this reason, I do not consider the precedent of these many years controlling.

My attention has also been directed to decisions of our Court declaring that Joint Resolutions, proposing amendments to the Constitution, were subject in certain respects to the Enrolled Bill Rule. For example, there is the case of Lucas v. Barringer, 120 S.C. 68, 112 S.E. 746, 750, in which the following appears:

"The plaintiff had introduced in evidence, over objection of defendants, the whole Senate and House Journals for 1918, and attempted to show that the joint resolution had not received three readings [***13] in either the Senate or House, and on the third reading in the Senate it had not been entered in the journal in form as amended, and that the journal entries were not in accordance with the requirements of article 16, § 1 of the Constitution. The defendants objected to any further examination of the Journals being made, inasmuch as they had shown that the joint resolution had been entered once on both the Senate and House Journals with the yea and nay votes thereon, and this one entry fulfilled the constitutional requirements, and, as the certificate of the Secretary of State attached to the copy of the joint resolution certified that it had been read three times on three several days in each house of the General Assembly, duly ratified and signed by the President of the Senate and Speaker of the House of Representatives, approved by the Governor and the great seal of the state impressed thereon, the court was not at liberty to inquire further into what the journals of the two houses may show as to the successive steps which may have been taken in the passage of the original joint resolution.

"I sustained the objection and would not allow the introduction of the balance of the [***14] journals, and did so under the ruling in the case of State ex rel. Hoover v. Town Council of Chester, 39 S.C. 307, 17 S.E. 752, and Graham v. Ervin, 114 S.C. 419, 103 S.E. 750."

Similar indications that a Joint Resolution proposing an amendment to the Constitution was subject to certain phases of the Enrolled Bill Rule appear in Stevenson v. Carrison, 122 S.C. 212, 115 S.E. 251, and Fleming v. Royall, 145 S.C. 438, 143 S.E. 162, 167.

The doctrine of the Enrolled Bill Rule was established in this State by the decision of our Supreme Court in the case of State ex rel. Hoover v. Chester, supra, a decision which overruled earlier decisions of our Court, approving the examination of the original Journals of the Houses to determine the contents of Statutes. The definition of the Enrolled Bill Rule given in the case of State ex rel. Hoover v. Chester, supra, has been frequently quoted as follows [39 S.C. 307, 17 S.E. 755]:

"We announce that the true rule is that, when an act has been duly signed by the presiding officers of the general assembly, in open session in the senate and house, approved by the governor of the state, and duly deposited in the office of the secretary [***15] of the state, it is sufficient evidence, nothing to the contrary appearing upon its face, that it passed the general assembly, and that it is not competent either by the journals of the two houses, or either of them, or by any other evidence, to impeach such an act. And, this being so, it follows that the court is not at liberty to inquire into what the journals of the two houses may show as to the successive steps which may have been taken in the passage of the original bill."

From a casual reading of the foregoing, it would seem that the Governor's signature upon an Act is one of the essentials to the application of the doctrine. However, such cannot be the case because the Enrolled Bill Rule has been applied to vetoed bills. Cf. State ex rel. Coleman v. Lewis, 181 S.C. 10, 186 S.E. 625, and because of this, I have concluded that the Governor's signature is not one of the essentials of the Enrolled Rule Bill. For this reason, references to the necessity of the Governor's signature upon Joint Resolutions proposing amendments to the Constitution, in order to bring them within the Enrolled Bill Rule, are of no real significance.

When those writing Article XV of the Constitution [***16] of 1868 and its present counterpart, Article XVI of the Constitution of 1895, omitted therefrom any descriptive reference to the nature of the legislative vehicle to be used in proposing an amendment, it was done advisedly and with full knowledge of the fact that under the Constitution of 1790, the legislative vehicle to purpose the amendment had been specifically designated as a Bill. I have already pointed out that under the Constitution of 1790, Executive assent or approval to legislative Acts was not required. However, with the restoration of the veto, Executive assent or approval, except on matters of adjournment, was required to every Bill or Joint Resolution. Bills and Joint Resolutions are the accepted style of legislative enactments. Consequently, the omission of any designation of the proposing legislative vehicle is highly significant and must mean that those writing the provisions of our last two Constitutions dealing with their amending intended that the Executive should take no part in the amending process.

It was held in the case of Fleming v. Royall, supra, that a Title to a Joint Resolution proposing a constitutional amendment was not essential. And, in that case,  [***17] the Court pointed out that in many respects the Legislature in proposing constitutional amendments is not subject to rules controlling ordinary legislative action. Now, the Constitution provides that every Act or Resolution having the force of law shall relate but to one subject, and that shall be expressed in the Title. Section 17, Article III. Consequently, in reaching the conclusion which it did in the Fleming case, supra, the Court recognized the principle, that legislative action in proposing amendments to the Constitution did not fall within the purview of Acts or Joint Resolutions, as those documents are contemplated by other provisions of the Constitution.

For the foregoing reasons, I am satisfied that notwithstanding its designation as a "Joint Resolution", the legislative vehicle here was not a Joint Resolution of the sort referred to in either Section 23, Article IV, or Section 17, Article 3, and that, consequently, the Governor's action on the matter was completely unnecessary.

A still further and compelling reason leads me to this conclusion. In order for legislative vehicles, proposing joint resolutions, to become effective, they must be voted upon favorably [***18] by two-thirds of the members elected to each House. This means that 83 members of the House of Representatives must vote favorably upon the proposing vehicle, and, at present, 31 members of the Senate. On the other hand, vetoes may be overriden by two-thirds of a quorum.

In Smith v. Jennings, supra, it was specifically held that under the Constitution of 1895 2/3 of a quorum may override a veto. This decision cites other South Carolina judicial precedents dealing with the comparable provision of the Constitution of 1868. Now, a quorum of each House is a mere majority. Section 11, Article III. Consequently, it is to be seen that even if the Governor's approval was necessary, his action could be overriden by as few as 43 members of the House (2/3 of 63) and 11 Senators (2/3 of 16). Such a result would be wholly illogical. Accordingly, I conclude, and so hold, that the Governor is not a part of the legislative machinery contemplated by Section 1 of Article XVI.

Counsel for the defendants call my attention to the fact that my ruling here is in keeping with an opinion of the Attorney General of the State. While the opinions of the Attorney General are not binding upon the Court,  [***19] they are persuasive, for that official occupies a quasi judicial position and it is gratifying to find that my views are in harmony with his opinion.

As previously pointed out, there is an absence of judicial precedent on this question in this State. However, similar questions have been presented to other Courts in several other jurisdictions, including the Supreme Court of the United States. In every instance that I have found, with but one possible exception, the results reached sustain my views.

During the course of the argument before the United States Supreme Court in the case of Hollingsworth v. Virginia, 3 Dall. 378, 1 L. Ed. 644, it was argued that the 11th Amendment to the Constitution had not been proposed in due form, for the reason that it had not been presented to the President of the United States for his approval. The Attorney General of the United States, in answer, pointed out that the same course had been pursued relative to the adoption of the 11th amendment as had been pursued in the case of the 10 other Amendments previously adopted. At this point in his oral argument, he was interrupted by Justice Chase of the Supreme Court, who made the following statement:

 [***20] "There can, surely, be no necessity to answer that argument. The negative of the President applies only to the ordinary cases of legislation. He has nothing to do with the proposition or adoption of amendments to the Constitution."

While the United States Supreme Court did not deliver a written opinion, it was unanimously ruled on the following day that the 11th Amendment was constitutionally adopted. This case appears to be the one occasion when this question was presented to the United States Supreme Court.

Other cases sustaining my views are as follows:

People ex rel. Stewart v. Ramer, 62 Colo. 128, 160 P. 1032; Collier v. Gray, 116 Fla. 845, 157 So. 40; State of Louisiana v. American Sugar Refining Co., 137 La. 407, 68 So. 742; Warfield v. Vandiver, 101 Md. 78, 60 A. 538, 4 Am. Cas. 692; Commonwealth ex rel. Elkins v. Griest, 196 Pa. 396, 46 A. 505, 50 L.R.A. 868; State ex rel. Morris v. Mason, 43 La. Ann. 590, 9 So. 776; In re Senate File 31, 25 Neb. 864, 41 N.W. 981; Green v. Weller, 32 Miss. 650; and Keohler v. Hill, 60 Iowa 543, 14 N.W. 738, 15 N.W. 609.

Passing comment on some of these appears to be in order.

In the case of People ex rel. Stewart [***21] v. Ramer, supra, a Resolution of the General Assembly of the State of Colorado had been vetoed by the Governor, and the question was, therefore, squarely before the Supreme Court of that State. The Court held that the veto was inoperative and that the Governor was not a part of the legislative machinery involved in proposing amendments to the Constitution of that State. It appears from the decision of the Court that the Colorado Constitution gave to the Governor the power to veto other legislative matters.

The case of Louisiana v. American Sugar Refining Company, supra, is of considerable interest because the Court took occasion to make reference to the many Constitutions the State of Louisiana seems to have had. In the case before it for decision, it held that the Governor was not required to approve any proposed amendment to the Constitution, calling attention to the fact that under earlier Constitutions the Governor had been given that right.

The decision in Commonwealth ex rel. Elkins v. Griest, supra, was a decision before the Court of last resort of the State of Pennsylvania. An examination of the facts stated in the opinion shows that the Constitution of Pennsylvania [***22] contained provisions substantially similar to the two provisions in our own Constitution, which I have been discussing. The Court held that the approval of the Governor of Pennsylvania to amendments to the Constitution was not required, pointing out that the only authorities which have any right to assent or dissent to any constitutional amendment were the two Houses of the General Assembly and the people.

In the case reported as In re Senate File 31, supra, it had been urged upon the Supreme Court of Nebraska that it had been the long-standing custom to submit to the Executive of that State proposals to amend the Constitution. In answer to that contention, the Nebraska Supreme Court said [25 Neb. 864, 41 N.W. 984]:

"Suppose, however, that, through mistake or a superabundance of caution, it is submitted to him, and he approves it, or, as in this case, retains it for more than five days, Sundays excepted, in what way does that affect the Resolution? It is still but a proposition, which has gained nothing from approval of the governor; but, to be of any validity it must be adopted by * * * the electors * * *. Suppose each branch of the legislature, under a mistake as to their [***23] duty, should cause the bill or resolution to be read at large on six different days (the Constitution of Nebraska required one reading on three different days), or perform any other act in its passage not required by law, would the bill or resolution, therefore, be void, if the acts done included all that the law requires? No one will so contend."

The Court then stated that there was a material difference between a failure to perform all that the Constitution required and the performance of more than was requisite.

In the course of its opinion in Warfield v. Vandiver, supra, the Maryland Court, holding that the approval of the Governor was not necessary to a Joint Resolution proposing an amendment to the Constitution of Maryland, took occasion to point out that [60 A. 541]:

"Unless the express language of the Constitution has unequivocally clothed the Governor with such an authority in relation to proposed constitutional amendments, as is the case in Delaware, but in no other state, it cannot be borrowed from some other provision pertaining to a wholly different subject. Whilst the Governor is intrusted with power to protect the people against hasty legislation, he [***24] is not given a prerogative to guard them against themselves in the matter of amending the organic law. He is not superior to them. It is their will which he must obey; it is not his will which they must subserve."

Like South Carolina, the Maryland Constitution contained a provision requiring executive approval of every Bill passed by the General Assembly of that State.

The only seeming authority against the proposition to which my attention has been called is the California case of Hatch v. Stoneman, 66 Cal. 632, 6 P. 734. Unfortunately, the volume containing this decision was not available to counsel, and the holding of the California Court has been ascertained from comments made by other Courts, whose decisions were available. While it appears that the Supreme Court of California had held that before the question of amending the Constitution be submitted to the people, the approval of the Governor was required, it would seem that the method required of the California Legislature differed substantially from the method provided for in our Constitution and in other State Constitutions. Two legislative steps appeared necessary. The first was the adoption by the Legislature [***25] of California by the requisite vote of the proposed Amendment, and the second was the enactment of a Bill directing that the proposals thus agreed upon be submitted. The decision of the California Court seems to be that the Governor's approval on the Bill submitting the question was essential for the reason that the Bill was similar to other legislative enactments.

I have earlier, in this opinion, indicated that authorities from other jurisdictions would not be controlling upon the Courts of this State. It is, however, a matter of satisfaction to find that other authorities do sustain the position which I have taken.

Question 2

Was this particular Resolution adopted in such a way as to justify the submission of the amendment it proposed to the electors at the election held November 2nd, 1948?

Counsel have argued to me that notwithstanding that it was unnecessary to secure the Governor's approval to the Joint Resolution proposing the Amendment, the Legislature saw fit to make the effective date of the Resolution the occasion that it be approved by the Governor, and since it was presented to the Governor on the day of sine die adjournment, it did not become effective [***26] or operative until two days following the convening of the 1949 General Assembly. They have argued that because of this, the act of the Secretary of State in causing the question of the adoption of the Amendment to be submitted in the 1948 General Election was premature.

I recognize that as a general proposition, the Legislature may designate in the future the date upon which legislative action shall take effect. I have no argument with the soundness of this general rule, but, for the reasons which I shall point out, one Legislature may not make the effective date of a Joint Resolution proposed by it the occasion when a new or subsequent Legislature convenes. The provisions of Section 1, Article 16 of the Constitution, specifically state that if an Amendment be proposed and agreed to it must be submitted at the next general election thereafter for representatives. Furthermore, in order for it to become effective, it must be ratified by the next General Assembly. In other words, the approving action of two succeeding Legislatures is required. Consequently, if the argument advanced by the plaintiff were to be followed, we would have a case where one General Assembly, the 87th, proposed [***27] the amendment; it became effective upon the convening of the 88th, and would have to be ratified by the 89th. In other words, we would not have the action of two successive General Assemblies upon the amendment. An entirely different General Assembly would intervene. This is counter to the plain mandate in the Constitution.

It is argued to me, however, that a Court cannot restate the language of legislative enactments in order to make it agree with some possible conclusion as to its intention. In support of this contention, they cite the case of Bray v. City Council of Florence, 62 S.C. 57, 39 S.E. 810, 812, wherein our court said:

"The language declaring the intent of an act is as much beyond our power as the subject to which that declaration relates, and it would violate the principles of law to change the phraseology of a statute to make it conform to the assumed purpose of the lawgiver in any other way than as warranted by the rules of construction."

Once again, the proposition propounded by the plaintiff is correct, but it overlooks the fact that it is not only within the power of the Court, but its duty to declare the true legislative intent. One can be left in [***28] no doubt as to the legislative intent, if the Resolution as a whole is read. Section 2 directs the question propounded therein be submitted to the qualified electors at the next general election. That could mean but one thing viz., the election of November 2nd, 1948.

It has been pointed out that it was beyond the power of the General Assembly to,

(1) require the Governor's approval to the legislative vehicle, proposing the amendment to the Constitution, and,

(2) That it could not make it effective upon the occasion of the convening of the next General Assembly.

For this reason, the provisions of Section 3 are unconstitutional and of no effect.

Does this destroy the Act in toto? I think not. It is the duty of the Court to sustain the constitutional portions of an Act, when the constitutional part is capable of being severed from the unconstitutional part, so that each part may be read and stand by itself. Gillespie v. Blackwell, 164 S.C. 115, 161 S.E. 869. The situation here falls within that rule.

When, therefore, did the proposing resolution become effective? The answer is obvious. At such time as was necessary in order to permit the Secretary of State [***29] to perform the functions required by law of him in order that the proposal be properly submitted to the people at the election in 1948.



DISPOSITION: Exceptions overruled and judgment affirmed.

 

542 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Shillito v. Spartanburg


16239


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


215 S.C. 83; 54 S.E.2d 521; 1949 S.C. LEXIS 69



July 20, 1949, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal from Common Pleas Circuit Court of Spartanburg County; J. Woodrow Lewis, Judge.

Taxpayer's action by William F. Shillito against City of Spartanburg, with Leon Moore as its Mayor, R. Fred Maddox, W. D. Coan, Neville Holcombe and Charles Holland as its councilmen and others, wherein decree adjudging a statute unconstitutional was affirmed on appeal and case remanded for action on application of plaintiff for allowance of reasonable attorney's fees. From a judgment fixing reasonable attorney's fees, the defendant appeals.

Reversed and remanded.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed and case remanded.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants, a city and its officials, appealed a judgment of the Common Pleas Circuit Court of Spartanburg County (South Carolina), which fixed an amount of a fee to be allowed plaintiff taxpayer's attorney in an action brought by the taxpayer to challenge the constitutionality of a tax statute.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiff brought the action against defendants to challenge the constitutionality of a statute providing for an annual tax levy in the city. The trial judge found the statute unconstitutional. On appeal the decree was affirmed and the case was remanded for action on the application of plaintiff for allowance of reasonable attorney's fees. Plaintiff then moved for the allowance of attorney's fees, which the trial judge granted after he transferred to a different circuit. Defendants appealed. The court reversed because the trial judge lost jurisdiction to pass upon the amount of attorney's fees to be allowed after adjourning court sine die and leaving the circuit where the action was brought. The only issue with reference to attorney's fees heard by the trial judge while holding court where the action was brought was whether or not any fee was allowable. The order made in the other circuit that fixed the amount of the fee contained and constituted new matter not presented to him or marked "heard." It was in no sense supplemental or germane to the enforcement of the original judgment; therefore, it was void for lack of jurisdiction.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the trial court and remanded the case.

 

543 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Johnson v. Baldwin


16222


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


214 S.C. 545; 53 S.E.2d 785; 1949 S.C. LEXIS 57



May 30, 1949, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal from Common Pleas Circuit Court of Greenville County; J. Robert Martin, Jr., Judge.

Action by Mrs. Joseph T. Johnson, suing for the benefit of herself and all other common stockholders of the Brandon Corporation, against Summerfield Baldwin, Jr., and others, as directors of the Brandon Corporation and individually, and G. B. Dorsey, to recover damages for alleged mismanagement of the Brandon Corporation. From a judgment sustaining the motion of Summerfield Baldwin, Jr., and G. B. Dorsey, to vacate and set aside service of summons on them, the plaintiff appeals.

Judgment affirmed.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff stockholder brought an action against defendant directors to recover damages for alleged corporate mismanagement. Two of the directors, who had never resided in South Carolina but were residents of other states, filed a motion to vacate and set aside the service made under 1947 S.C. Acts 277. The Common Pleas Circuit Court of Greenville County (South Carolina) granted the motion and the stockholder sought review.


OVERVIEW: The stockholder filed the action on July 14, 1945. The two directors resigned and had ceased to be directors on December 20, 1946. After several unsuccessful attempts of service, the stockholder sought to serve the directors under the provisions of 1947 S.C. Acts 277. The trial court found that the provisions of the Act for substituted service did not apply retrospectively to former directors of a domestic corporation who had ceased to be directors prior to the effective date of the Act, May 19, 1947. On review, the court affirmed, holding that the Act evinced an legislative intent that it should operate prospectively. Under the Act, the Secretary of State was considered as an attorney in fact upon whom process may be served only when certain acts were done by a non-resident after the passage of the Act. A retroactive intent of the legislature would not be assumed, and it was in fact doubtful whether the legislature was empowered to make it so. Further, a statute would not be given retrospective effect unless such a construction was required by the express words of the statute or was necessarily implied from its terms.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's grant of the directors' motion to vacate.

 

544 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Gaud v. Walker


16209


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


214 S.C. 451; 53 S.E.2d 316; 1949 S.C. LEXIS 47



April 29, 1949, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Original action by Henry T. Gaud against William W. Walker and others, to have act providing for a system of municipal government for Charleston County declared unconstitutional.

Petition granted in part and refused in part.



DISPOSITION: Petition dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff, a taxpayer and qualified elector, brought suit against defendant, members of the county council, to have declared unconstitutional a special election Act, 1948 S.C. Acts 764, providing for a system of municipal government for Charleston County. Plaintiff alleged that the Act was in conflict with various provisions of the Constitution of South Carolina.


OVERVIEW: The special election Act provided for a system of municipal government, administered by a County Council as the corporate authority, including a delegation of the police power to the Council. The court held that the legislature could not delegate its power to pass a charter governing a city or county to any other body or community. It could, however, draft a charter or optional form of government for municipalities, and make its adoption dependent upon the vote of the locality. Although the word "levy" was not used in the constitution, the authority of the General Assembly to delegate to cities and towns the power to levy taxes was clear. However, there was no more right inherent in a city than in a county to have this power bestowed upon it, and counties were included along with cities and towns. Thus, the court found that the police power could not have been delegated to the corporate authorities of one county and withheld as to all others, especially in view of S.C. Const. art. 8, § 1. The court determined that there was nothing in the Act to justify this classification; thus, that portion of the Act purporting to delegate the police power to the County Council was invalid.


OUTCOME: The court enjoined the county from exercising any of the powers conferred by a certain part of the Act, but in other respects the petition was dismissed. The court held that the Act was constitutional, except that part which purported to delegate the police power to the County Council. When that portion of the Act was eliminated, the remaining Act was capable of execution in accordance with the legislative intent.

 

545 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Powell v. Thomas


16202


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


214 S.C. 376; 52 S.E.2d 782; 1949 S.C. LEXIS 39



March 30, 1949, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Original action by Fred J. Powell, Sr., chairman, in behalf of himself, and all other members of the Chester County War Memorial Commission, against W. A. Thomas, Chairman, W. A. Byars, J. T. McDonald, L. C. Wise, and Clyde Templeton, members constituting the county board of directors of Chester County, South Carolina, to determine the validity of Act April 9, 1948, 45 St. at Large, p. 2504, § 1 et seq.

Act held valid in part and invalid in part.



DISPOSITION: Petition granted in part and refused in part.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner war memorial commission filed an original action against respondent county board of directors to determine the validity of the Act April 9, 1948, 45 St. at Large, p. 2504, § 1 et seq. (S.C.), which authorized the issuance of general obligation bonds to pay for the construction of a war memorial, a health center, and a cattle barn and show ring.


OVERVIEW: The Act of April 9, 1948, 45 St. at Large, p. 2504, § 1 et seq. (S.C.), authorized a county to issue general obligation bonds to finance construction of a war memorial, a health center, and a cattle barn and show ring. The war memorial commission filed an action to determine the constitutionality of the act, i.e., whether it was authorized by Article 10, § 6 of the South Carolina Constitution. This provision prohibited the General Assembly from authorizing a county to issue bonds for any purpose except for education, to build and repair public roads, buildings, and bridges, and for a few other purposes. The court held that the act was invalid insofar as it authorized the issuance of bonds to pay for the war memorial. A war memorial, although serving a public purpose, did not serve a purpose embraced in Article 10, § 6. Further, the proposed memorial, although housing a public library, was not a public building within the meaning of Article 10, § 6, because a large part of its was to have been given over to the American Legion, which was a private organization. The act was valid as to the cattle barn and show ring because that building was intended to serve an educational purpose.


OUTCOME: The court held the statute at issue unconstitutional to the extent that it authorized issuing bonds to finance construction of a war memorial. The court held the statute valid to the extent that it authorized issuing bonds to finance the construction of a medical center and a cattle barn and show ring.

 

546 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Shillito v. Spartanburg


16154


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


214 S.C. 11; 51 S.E.2d 95; 1948 S.C. LEXIS 11; 5 A.L.R.2d 863



December 7, 1948, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal from Common Pleas Circuit Court of Spartanburg County; J. Woodrow Lewis, Judge.

Action by William F. Shillito, a resident and taxpayer of City of Spartanburg, in his individual capacity and for benefit of himself and all other citizens and taxpayers, against City of Spartanburg and others, involving validity of statute providing for an annual tax levy in the City of Spartanburg for the benefit of the Spartanburg City Firemen's Pension Fund. From a judgment for plaintiff, the defendants appeal.

Affirmed and remanded.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant city appealed the judgment of the Common Pleas Circuit Court of Spartanburg County (South Carolina) which was entered in favor of plaintiff taxpayer in his action challenging the constitutionality of 1946 S.C. Acts 841 (the Act) that provided an annual tax levy for the benefit of city firemen's pension fund.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayer sued the city, alleging that the Act that imposed an annual tax levy for the benefit of city firemen's pension fund was unconstitutional. The trial court entered judgment for the taxpayer. On appeal, the court affirmed. The Act was unconstitutional under S.C. Const. art. III, § 34 because it provided for a general tax on all property within the city which would be used solely for the benefit of a specified class, the city firemen. The court held that the taxpayer could maintain his action challenging the Act on behalf of all taxpayers. The trial court properly ordered that the funds be transferred to the city's general fund because to transfer them to the firemen's pension fund would constitute an unlawful diversion. The taxpayer was entitled to attorney fees from the taxes that were unlawfully collected.


OUTCOME: The judgment holding that the Act that imposed an annual tax levy benefiting city firemen's pension fund was unconstitutional was affirmed.

 

547 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Whitmire v. Cass


16119


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


213 S.C. 230; 49 S.E.2d 1; 1948 S.C. LEXIS 94



August 5, 1948, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal from Common Pleas Circuit Court of Greenville County; J. Robert Martin, Jr., Judge.

Action by N. A. Whitmire and others, suing for the benefit of themselves and all others in like situation, against J. Kenneth Cass, as Mayor, and others as Aldermen of the City of Greenville, S.C., and their successors in office, for a writ of certiorari requiring defendants to certify and deposit for filing with clerk of court all records and documents in their possession relating to annexation election, for a decree declaring the election void, and for an injunction against defendants, enjoining them from exercising any authority or jurisdiction over territory annexed, and over people therein. From an adverse judgment, the plaintiffs appeal.

Judgment affirmed.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants filed an action against respondents, a mayor, aldermen of the city, and their successors, for a writ of certiorari for a decree declaring an annexation election void and for an injunction against respondents preventing them from exercising jurisdiction over the annexed territory. The Common Pleas Circuit Court of Greenville County (South Carolina) entered judgment for respondents. Appellants sought review.


OVERVIEW: The election was ordered after respondents received a petition that contained the signatures of a majority of the freeholders of the annexed area, as required by Code § 7230. Appellants contended that the election did not comply with Art.
