On appeal, defendant argued that the trial judge erred in refusing a motion for a directed verdict of not guilty on the ground that the evidence was insufficient to sustain a conviction and that the sentence was excessive in violation of S.C. Const. art. I, § 19. The court affirmed the conviction, holding that the circumstantial evidence was sufficient to enable the jury to find defendant guilty. However, the sentence was set aside and the matter was remanded for resentencing. The court noted that the sentence imposed was the equivalent of a life sentence and that there was nothing to justify the trial judge in disregarding the jury's recommendation. The court concluded that the sentence was manifestly too severe and constituted an abuse of discretion.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's conviction for burglary. However, the court set aside defendant's sentence and remanded for resentencing.

 

556 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Hardee v. Lynch


16032


SUPREME COURT OF SOUTH CAROLINA


212 S.C. 6; 46 S.E.2d 179; 1948 S.C. LEXIS 19



January 16, 1948, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal from County Court of Florence County; R. W. Sharkey, County Judge.

Suit in equity by A. L. Hardee, as surviving partner of the partnership of Willcox & Hardee, attorneys, against W. S. Lynch, Jr., as executor of the last will of W. S. Lynch, deceased, to enforce the collection of an unrevived domestic judgment. From an adverse judgment, defendant appeals.

Judgment reversed.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant, the executor for a deceased judgment debtor's estate, challenged a decision of the County Court of Florence County (South Carolina), which found in favor of respondent attorney in the attorney's suit in equity to collect an unrevived domestic judgment that was more than 10 years in the past.


OVERVIEW: In 1927, the attorney's client recovered an alimony judgment against the judgment debtor. The client assigned a portion of the judgment to the attorney. The judgment debtor died in 1945. The attorney filed suit to collect on the judgment in 1946 without having revived the judgment at any time. The executor alleged that the suit was untimely, either because the 10-year statute of limitations had run or because the Act of the South Carolina General Assembly approved March 22, 1946, 44 Stats. page 1436, had eliminated the 20-year statute of limitations. The trial court awarded a money judgment to the attorney. The court reversed on appeal. The court held that the attorney could not collect on an unrevived judgment that was more than 10 years old without permission of the trial court, which he did not obtain. Thus, the trial court had no jurisdiction over the action. The suit was not one in equity because only money was sought. In any event, a judgment lien could not be enforced in equity where it could not be enforced at law. As an alternate ground, the court held that the 1946 Act would also bar the suit.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment below.

 

557 of 598 DOCUMENTS


State v. Higgenbottom


Opinion No. 3074


COURT OF APPEALS OF SOUTH CAROLINA


337 S.C. 637; 525 S.E.2d 250; 1999 S.C. App. LEXIS 169


October 7, 1999, Heard  
November 16, 1999, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal From Aiken County. Gary E. Clary, Circuit Court Judge.



DISPOSITION: AFFIRMED.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought appeal of an Aiken County Court (South Carolina) resentencing, upon a motion for reconsideration of his probationary sentence extending the length of his probationary term, contending that it was based on the trial court's vindictiveness in violation of due process rights.


OVERVIEW: The day after entering an Alford plea and being sentenced, defendant moved for reconsideration of his probationary sentence. The court extended his probationary term from 18 to 24 months. Contending that the increased punishment was vindictive in violation of due process rights, defendant appealed. The reviewing court affirmed, holding that the Pearce rule of presumption of vindictiveness applied only when there was a reasonable likelihood that the increase in sentence was a product of actual vindictiveness on the part of the sentencing authority. Where there was no such reasonable likelihood, the burden was on defendant to prove actual vindictiveness. Defendant failed to meet the burden of proving actual vindictiveness. Resentencing was based on a review of facts. The court did not believe defendant's explanation of how the cocaine-laced spoon made its way into his pocket.


OUTCOME: Resentencing was affirmed because there was no reasonable likelihood of vindictiveness in a case where the trial court was reconsidering a defendant's sentence upon defendant's request.

 

558 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Eargle v. Horry County


Opinion No. 2880


COURT OF APPEALS OF SOUTH CAROLINA


335 S.C. 425; 517 S.E.2d 3; 1999 S.C. App. LEXIS 64


December 9, 1998, Heard  
April 26, 1999, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal From Horry County. A. Victor Rawl, Circuit Court Judge.



DISPOSITION: AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, a South Carolina county and its administrator, sought review of a judgment of the Circuit Court of Horry County (South Carolina), which ruled that appellants lacked authority to suspend employees of appellee, the elected county auditor.


OVERVIEW: Appellants, a South Carolina county and its administrator, argued that the trial court erred by concluding that appellants lacked the statutory authority to suspend employees of appellee, the elected county auditor. Specifically, appellants asserted that the powers granted to them by S.C. Code Ann. § 4-9-25(1998) and S.C. Const. art. VIII, § 17 may not, by law, be construed to limit their authority. Thus, their administration of personnel policies, including suspension, was not precluded by S.C. Code Ann. § 4-9-30(7) -- barring counties from hiring or firing an elected official's employees -- as this provision did not expressly prohibit suspensions. The court disagreed, ruling that appellants lacked express authority to suspend appellee's employees. To give a county control over an elected official's employees, the court explained, could force appellee to place the county's interests over those of the electorate, and could have a devastating impact on appellee's ability to carry out his duties. However, the award of attorney fees to appellee pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. § 15-77-300 was improper, as the trial court failed to make the requisite statutory findings.


OUTCOME: Judgment affirmed that appellants, a South Carolina county and its administrator, lacked authority to suspend employees of appellee, an elected official, as appellants' power to administer personnel policies did not, absent explicit statutory authorization, extend to officials whose interests were to serving electorate, but reversed and remanded as to attorney fee award to appellee, as trial court failed to make requisite statutory findings.

 

559 of 598 DOCUMENTS


International Mariculture Resources v. Grant


Opinion No. 2947


COURT OF APPEALS OF SOUTH CAROLINA


1999 S.C. App. LEXIS 30


November 5, 1998, Heard  
February 16, 1999, Filed


NOTICE:

 [*1] THIS DECISION IS NOT FINAL UNTIL TIME EXPIRES TO FILE REHEARING MOTION AND, IF FILED, DETERMINED.


PRIOR HISTORY: Appeal from Charleston County. Roger M. Young, Special Circuit Court Judge.



DISPOSITION: REVERSED AND REMANDED.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant corporation sought review of a decision by the Charleston County Court (South Carolina) granting respondent Chilean resident's motion to dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction, in an action brought by appellant alleging breach of fiduciary duty, fraud, and civil conspiracy.


OVERVIEW: In an action brought by appellant corporation alleging breach of fiduciary duty, fraud, and civil conspiracy, appellant sought review of the trial court's decision granting respondent Chilean resident's motion to dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction. The court held that S.C. Code Ann. § 36-2-803(1)(c) (1976), the state's long-arm statute, authorized service of process on respondent. Complaint alleged that respondent acted to cause appellant a tortious injury within the state. The court held that an exercise of jurisdiction over respondent comported with the due process requirements under U.S. Const. amend. XIV. Respondent established minimum contacts with the state by allegedly committing several intentional torts by devaluing a state corporation. In addition, if respondent acted to compromise the financial condition of a state corporation, respondent could have reasonably anticipated being haled into the state court. The court held that jurisdiction would be fair given the significant state interest in preventing tortious injury within the state and because respondent should not be allowed to tortiously purchase state assets without having to abide by the state's laws.


OUTCOME: The court reversed because exercising personal jurisdiction over respondent Chilean resident was proper according to the state's long arm statute and the Fourteenth Amendment's Due Process Clause. Respondent's alleged commission of intentional torts within the state satisfied the requirement of minimum contacts. If respondent committed those acts, respondent could have reasonably anticipated being haled into the state court.

 

560 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Rowe v. City of W. Columbia


Opinion No. 2941


COURT OF APPEALS OF SOUTH CAROLINA


334 S.C. 400; 513 S.E.2d 379; 1999 S.C. App. LEXIS 31


December 8, 1998, Submitted  
February 16, 1999, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal from Lexington County. Thomas J. Ervin, Circuit Court Judge.



DISPOSITION: VACATED.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant, a police officer whose employment was terminated by respondent city, challenged the affirmation of his termination by the Circuit Court of Lexington County (South Carolina).


OVERVIEW: Appellant police officer was terminated by respondent city due to allegedly working at another job while simultaneously performing his duties as a police department shift supervisor. The city grievance committee and the city council recommended upholding his termination. Appellant challenged this determination in the circuit court, which concluded that it lacked subject matter jurisdiction over the appeal because neither the city council nor the grievance committee was an agency under the Administrative Procedure Act, S.C. Code Ann. §§ 1-23-310 - 1-23-400, but which determined that it had jurisdiction to review the termination pursuant to a writ of certiorari. The circuit court ruled in favor of respondent, and on appeal, the court vacated the circuit court's order due to lack of subject matter jurisdiction. It held that although neither the County and Municipal Employee Grievance Act, S.C. Code Ann. § 8-17-110-160, nor the Administrative Procedure Act, provided for a judicial appeal of the termination, certiorari review was inappropriate because a breach of contract or wrongful discharge action provided appellant an opportunity for judicial review of the governmental decision.


OUTCOME: The court vacated the decision of the circuit court, concluding that the circuit court lacked subject matter jurisdiction to hear the claim on certiorari because an action for breach of contact or wrongful discharge would provide appellant with an opportunity for judicial review of the governmental decision which was not otherwise appealable.

 

561 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Eldridge v. City of Greenwood


Opinion No. 2851


COURT OF APPEALS OF SOUTH CAROLINA


331 S.C. 398; 503 S.E.2d 191; 1998 S.C. App. LEXIS 82


November 6, 1997, Heard  
June 15, 1998, Filed


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied August 20, 1998.
Related proceeding at Eldridge v. State DOT, 2007 S.C. App. Unpub. LEXIS 56 (S.C. Ct. App., July 11, 2007)


PRIOR HISTORY: Appeal From Greenwood County. Alexander S. Macaulay, Circuit Court Judge.
Eldridge v. City of Greenwood, 308 S.C. 125, 417 S.E.2d 532, 1992 S.C. LEXIS 76 (S.C., 1992)



DISPOSITION: AFFIRMED IN PART AND REVERSED IN PART.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In respondent individuals' action claiming title in certain real property, appellant public entities challenged a determination from the Circuit Court of Greenwood County (South Carolina) that the relevant railroad had obtained only an easement in three segments of the rail corridor.


OVERVIEW: The public entities contended that the appellate court lacked subject matter jurisdiction, as well as asserting that the railroad had a fee simple interest in the disputed three segments of the rail corridor. The appellate court affirmed in part and reversed in part the judgment of the trial court. The Interstate Commerce Commission (ICC) had approved all aspects of the relevant relocation project and, accordingly, the ICC's jurisdiction terminated upon issuance of the certificate of abandonment. The appellate court determined that it had subject matter jurisdiction over this action. Also, the appellate court agreed that the railroad obtained only an easement in the properties acquired by deed and by the statutory presumption of grant provisions in the railroad's charter. However, the railroad had a fee simple interest in the property acquired by condemnation.


OUTCOME: The trial court's judgment was affirmed in part and reversed in part.

 

562 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Ballenger v. South Carolina Dep't of Health & Envtl. Control


Opinion No. 2767


COURT OF APPEALS OF SOUTH CAROLINA


331 S.C. 247; 500 S.E.2d 183; 1998 S.C. App. LEXIS 71


May 6, 1998, Submitted  
May 6, 1998, Filed


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: Rehearing Denied June 18, 1998.


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal From Spartanburg County. Thomas J. DeZern, Special Circuit Court Judge.

This Opinion Substituted on Grant of Rehearing for Withdrawn Opinion of December 15, 1997, Previously Reported at: 1997 S.C. App. LEXIS 171.



DISPOSITION: AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, citizens and environmental organization, contested the action of respondent, the South Carolina Department of Health and Environmental Control (DHEC) in issuing a permit to respondent waste management company to expand an existing landfill. The Board of Health and Environmental Control upheld the issuance of the permit. The Spartanburg Circuit Court (South Carolina) affirmed the board's decision and appellants sought review.


OVERVIEW: Appellants raised several claims of error. The court affirmed in part and reversed in part. The court rejected appellants' claim that the waste management company gave false and misleading information that they relied on in deciding not to file a petition. The court found that appellants were not prejudiced because this misinformation involved technical environmental issues that were not negotiable issues under the facility issues negotiation process. The court also found that the waste management company complied with the statutory notice provisions. However, the court held that the lower court erred in finding that appellants were afforded an adjudicatory hearing on the merits of the issuance of the permit. The court found that citizens had standing to request an adjudicatory hearing on the merits of the issuance of a landfill permit, but that they were never granted such a hearing because the hearing officer's decision only addressed the motion to dismiss. In addition, the court found that the lower court erred in finding that the waste management company complied with the statutory requirements regarding demonstration of the need for the expansion of its facility.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the issuance of the permit and the lower court's finding that appellants received an adjudicatory hearing on the merits of the issuance of the permit. The court remanded the case for an adjudicatory hearing on the merits of the issuance of the permit.

 

563 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Hagy v. Pruitt


Opinion No. 2837


COURT OF APPEALS OF SOUTH CAROLINA


331 S.C. 213; 500 S.E.2d 168; 1998 S.C. App. LEXIS 66


December 2, 1997, Heard  
May 4, 1998, Filed


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied June 19, 1998.


PRIOR HISTORY: Appeal from Horry County. Clyde K. Laney, Jr., Family Court Judge.



DISPOSITION: REVERSED.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant adoptive parents sought review of the judgment of the Horry County Family Court (South Carolina), which granted respondent birth mother's motion to set aside an adoption.


OVERVIEW: The birth mother gave consent to the adoption of her baby by her father and stepmother. Neither the birth mother nor birth father attended the adoption hearing. Two years after the trial court issued a final order of adoption, the birth mother took the child and fled. She was charged with kidnapping. After her arrest she filed an action to vacate the adoption and restore her parental rights. The trial court set aside the adoption finding that the birth mother's consent to the adoption was procured by fraud. The adoptive parents appealed and the court reversed and remanded. The court found that S.C. Code Ann. § 20-7-1800 provided that an adoption decree was not subject to collateral attack after a period of one year following its issuance. Because the birth mother's motion to set aside the adoption was filed more than one year after the final order of adoption was filed, her action was barred.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the trial court's order setting aside the adoption.

 

564 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Staubes v. City of Folly Beach


Opinion No. 2834


COURT OF APPEALS OF SOUTH CAROLINA


331 S.C. 192; 500 S.E.2d 160; 1998 S.C. App. LEXIS 87


April 7, 1998, Heard  
April 27, 1998, Filed


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Petition for Rehearing Denied June 19, 1998.


PRIOR HISTORY: Appeal From Charleston County. James E. Lockemy, Circuit Court Judge.



DISPOSITION: AFFIRMED IN PART; REVERSED IN PART and REMANDED.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant owner challenged an order of the Circuit Court of Charleston County (South Carolina), which held that the refusal of appellees, the City of Folly Beach and its zoning board, to grant a permit was neither a taking nor a violation of due process and that his action was statutorily barred .


OVERVIEW: Appellant owner obtained a repair permit for his damaged duplex from appellees, the City of Folly Beach (city) and its zoning board, that was later revoked because damages exceeded 50 percent of the market value. Although his appeal of the revocation was previously reversed by the court, the state supreme court dismissed the writ. Appellant brought an action alleging that the city's actions prevented him from making repairs. The trial court granted summary judgment to the city. The court affirmed the findings that the city's action did not constitute a taking because appellant was not deprived of all economically viable use of his property and that he was not deprived of his due process rights under the U.S. Const. amend. V or 42 U.S.C.S. § 1983. The court reversed the finding that the negligence claim was barred by the South Carolina Tort Claims Act, S.C. Code Ann. § 15-78-10.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order finding that the refusal of appellees, the City of Folly Beach and its zoning board, was not a taking or a deprivation of due process rights. The court reversed the finding that appellant owner's negligence claim was barred by the South Carolina Tort Claims Act.

 

565 of 598 DOCUMENTS


McQueen v. S.C. Coastal Council


Opinion No. 2779


COURT OF APPEALS OF SOUTH CAROLINA


329 S.C. 588; 496 S.E.2d 643; 1998 S.C. App. LEXIS 6


December 2, 1997, Heard  
January 12, 1998, Filed


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] As Corrected February 12, 1998. Rehearing Denied March 19, 1998.
Rehearing denied by, 03/19/1998
Reversed by McQueen v. S.C. Coastal Council, 340 S.C. 65, 530 S.E.2d 628, 2000 S.C. LEXIS 88 (S.C., 2000)
Reversed by McQueen v. S.C. Coastal Council, 2003 S.C. LEXIS 102 (S.C., Apr. 28, 2003)


PRIOR HISTORY: Appeal From Horry County. John L. Breeden, Jr., Master-in-Equity.



DISPOSITION: AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent landowner applied to appellant South Carolina Coastal Council for permits to bulkhead and backfill two noncontiguous lots. The council denied the permits and the landowner sought review. The matter was referred to the master-in-equity for Horry County (South Carolina) to enter a decision with finality. The master found a taking had occurred and ordered that the landowner be compensated. The council sought review.


OVERVIEW: The council claimed that the master erred by basing his findings and conclusions of law on alleged irregularities committed by the council and that there was substantial evidence to support the council's denial of the permits. The council also claimed that the master erred in determining that the permit denial constituted an unconstitutional taking without just compensation. The court affirmed in part and reversed in part. The court held that the master's findings of the council's irregularities were irrelevant to the determination of a taking. The court agreed with the council that the record supported the denial of the permits on the basis that the lots were wetlands and that erecting bulkheads and adding fill to the lots would have an adverse environmental impact. However, the court upheld the determination that a taking had occurred because the denial of the permits left each of the landowner's lots without any economically beneficial use. Because there was insufficient evidence to support the compensation award made by the master, the court remanded the case for a determination of the appropriate amount to be awarded to the landowner.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the master's determination of a taking by the council, but remanded the case for a determination of the proper amount of compensation for the landowner.

 

566 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Reliance Ins. Co. v. Smith


Opinion No. 2694


COURT OF APPEALS OF SOUTH CAROLINA


327 S.C. 528; 489 S.E.2d 674; 1997 S.C. App. LEXIS 94


May 6, 1997, Heard  
June 30, 1997, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal From Lexington County. George W. Jefferson, Special Circuit Court Judge.



DISPOSITION: AFFIRMED.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant taxpayer challenged an order of the Lexington County Court (South Carolina) that affirmed the decision of the administrative law judge (ALJ) in favor of respondents, county assessor and the county, as to the valuation of the taxpayer's property.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayer's predecessor in interest purchased the property in 1991 for $ 16,610,000. At the time of the county's appraisal, the improvements on the property were one year old and 75 percent of the property's finished space was occupied. The county assessor analyzed the property using the cost method, the income capitalization method, and the sales comparison method. He then performed an equitable analysis comparing his appraisals of the property to those of other properties. The ALJ concluded that the cost approach yielded the most accurate valuation of the property and determined that the property should be valued at $ 9,000,000 for the 1992 tax year. On appeal, the proceeding before the ALJ is in the nature of a de novo hearing. There was sufficient evidence presented to support the $ 9,000,000 valuation of the property. While the state constitution required equality and uniformity in tax assessments, absolute accuracy with respect to valuation and complete equality and uniformity were not practically attainable. The fact that another property may be undervalued did not render the accurate valuation of the property constitutionally defective. The court affirmed.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment.

 

567 of 598 DOCUMENTS


State v. Andrews


Opinion No. 2582


COURT OF APPEALS OF SOUTH CAROLINA


324 S.C. 516; 479 S.E.2d 808; 1996 S.C. App. LEXIS 157


October 8, 1996, Heard  
October 28, 1996, Filed


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied January 24, 1997.


PRIOR HISTORY: Appeal From Anderson County. H. Dean Hall, Circuit Court Judge.



DISPOSITION: AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed a judgment of the Anderson County Circuit Court (South Carolina), which convicted him of distribution of marijuana and possession of marijuana with intent to distribute.


OVERVIEW: After being convicted of both distribution of marijuana and possession of marijuana with intent to distribute, defendant appealed, claiming that the trial court erred by: (1) allowing into evidence taped recordings of his telephone conversations with a confidential informant; and (2) giving a burden-shifting jury instruction on the charge of possession with intent to distribute marijuana. The court affirmed defendant's conviction of distribution of marijuana but reversed and remanded for a new trial with regard to defendant's conviction of possession with intent to distribute marijuana, holding that: (1) the introduction of defendant's telephone conversations with the informant did not violate defendant's right to privacy under either U.S. Const. amend. IV or S.C. Const. art. I, § 10; and (2) the trial court's instruction that possession of more than 28 grams or one ounce of marijuana was "prima facie evidence" of guilt of possession with intent to distribute marijuana was error because it improperly shifted the burden of proof to defendant. On remand, the court offered a suggested instruction that would comply with constitutional mandates.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's conviction of distribution of marijuana and reversed his conviction of possession with intent to distribute marijuana and remand for a new trial based on the trial judge's burden-shifting jury instructions.

 

568 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Freeman v. Freeman


Opinion No. 2535


COURT OF APPEALS OF SOUTH CAROLINA


323 S.C. 95; 473 S.E.2d 467; 1996 S.C. App. LEXIS 105


May 7, 1996, Heard  
July 8, 1996, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal From Charleston County. Louis E. Condon, Master In Equity.



DISPOSITION: AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART AND REMANDED.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, one of several children of a decedent, and an illegitimate putative daughter of a child by the decedent, brought an action to quiet title and for partition and sale of real property against defendants, the heirs of the decedent. The heirs appealed a decision from a trial court, Charleston County (South Carolina), which held in favor of plaintiffs.


OVERVIEW: The decedent died owning the property at issue. The putative daughter's late father died intestate. Plaintiffs entered into a contract to sell the property, sought to quiet title, and to partition the property by sale. The trial court held, in part, that the putative daughter was an heir by virtue of representation through her late father. The court reversed as to the putative daughter, but otherwise affirmed. At the time of the decedent's death, South Carolina law allowed illegitimate children to inherit only from their mothers. That law was later declared unconstitutional and given a limited retroactive application based upon a tripartite test. Although the putative daughter met two of the conditions, being that innocent persons would not be adversely affected and the estate administration was subject to further resolution, she failed a third criteria requiring that her paternity had been conclusively established either by court order or decree issued prior to the death of the father or by an instrument signed by the father acknowledging paternity.


OUTCOME: The judgment was reversed as to the determination that the illegitimate daughter could inherit her putative father's share. The court affirmed as to all remaining issues and remanded for entry of an order consistent with the opinion.

 

569 of 598 DOCUMENTS


State v. Easler


Opinion No. 2512


COURT OF APPEALS OF SOUTH CAROLINA


322 S.C. 333; 471 S.E.2d 745; 1996 S.C. App. LEXIS 79


April 2, 1996, Heard  
May 13, 1996, Filed


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied June 20, 1996.


PRIOR HISTORY: Appeal From Cherokee County. John C. Hayes, III, Circuit Court Judge.



DISPOSITION: AFFIRMED


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant challenged his convictions for reckless homicide, assault and battery of a high and aggravated nature, felony driving while under the influence (DUI) causing great bodily injury, DUI causing death, leaving the scene of an accident, and driving under suspension entered by the Cherokee County Circuit Court (South Carolina).


OVERVIEW: Defendant, while driving a truck, swerved into the opposite lane and hit a car, injuring the driver and killing a passenger in the car. After the accident, defendant left the scene. When an officer caught up with him, he agreed to return to the scene of the accident. He told the officer that he did not have a driver's license and that he had been drinking just before the accident. Defendant made a motion to suppress these statements, claiming they violated Miranda. At the scene, witnesses identified defendant as the driver of the truck, at which time defendant was arrested and read his Miranda rights. The court held that there was no custodial interrogation requiring Miranda warnings before defendant was arrested and given his rights. The court further held that the trial court did not err in denying his motion for a change of venue due to pretrial publicity because the trial court thoroughly questioned the jurors as to any publicity they had encountered. The court further held that the trial court did not err in allowing defendant to receive punishments for both reckless homicide and felony DUI causing death because the "same offense" test was not satisfied.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment.

 

570 of 598 DOCUMENTS


State v. Brown


Opinion No. 2354


COURT OF APPEALS OF SOUTH CAROLINA


319 S.C. 400; 461 S.E.2d 828; 1995 S.C. App. LEXIS 123



August 24, 1995, Refiled


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal From Richland County. Costa M. Pleicones, Circuit Court Judge. Heard March 8, 1995 - Filed May 30, 1995.

This Opinion Substituted on Grant of Rehearing for Withdrawn Opinion of May 30, 1995, Previously Reported at: 1995 S.C. App. LEXIS 77.



DISPOSITION: AFFIRMED IN PART; VACATED IN PART


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed a judgment from the Circuit Court of Richland County (South Carolina), which convicted him of possession with intent to distribute crack cocaine, distribution of crack cocaine, and the same offenses near a school. Defendant alleged that there was insufficient evidence for the possession charges and that his convictions of possession with intent to distribute and distribution violate his double jeopardy rights.


OVERVIEW: Defendant agreed to sell four ounces of crack cocaine to a narcotics agent, but because the agent decided at the last minute to buy two ounces, defendant's accomplice kept two ounces. As a result, defendant was convicted on drug charges. On appeal, the court vacated the convictions and sentences for possession with intent to distribute and possession with intent to distribute within proximity to a school. The court held that because defendant had actual knowledge of the cocaine kept by his accomplice, whether defendant had constructive possession with intent to distribute the cocaine found in the accomplice's apartment was a jury question. However, because both distribution of cocaine and possession with intent to distribute were found in S.C. Code Ann. § 44-53-375(B) (Supp. 1994), and because a completed sale was not required to constitute distribution, defendant's conviction for distribution and possession with intent to distribute for the same acts violated defendant's rights against double jeopardy.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the convictions and vacated the sentences for possession with intent to distribute and the related school charges. The court affirmed the rest of the judgment.

 

571 of 598 DOCUMENTS


State v. Black


Opinion No. 2385


COURT OF APPEALS OF SOUTH CAROLINA


319 S.C. 515; 462 S.E.2d 311; 1995 S.C. App. LEXIS 113


June 6, 1995, Submitted  
August 7, 1995, Filed


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied September 20, 1995.


PRIOR HISTORY: Appeal From York County. J. Buford Grier, Special Circuit Court Judge.



DISPOSITION: AFFIRMED


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of the order of the Circuit Court, York County (South Carolina), which affirmed defendant's conviction, after a jury trial in a magistrate court, for speeding in violation of S.C. Code Ann. § 56-5-1510 (1976).


OVERVIEW: Defendant was stopped by a state trooper for speeding. A magistrate court jury found defendant guilty. Defendant claimed that the jury was chosen in violation of S.C. Code Ann. § 14-7-130 (Supp. 1994) and that the trooper, who acted as the prosecuting attorney, made improper statements in his closing argument. The court affirmed defendant's conviction. The court held that the jury list was prepared using the voter registration list pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. § 22-2-50 (1989), that § 22-2-50 permitted the exclusion of jurors who were not registered voters, that jurors in magistrate's court were required to be residents of the precinct in which the magistrate sat, and that § 22-2-50 did not violate equal protection principles. The court also held that the trooper stated in closing argument that he was driving an unmarked car, that the trooper did not testify as to the type of car he was driving, that the statement was not probative of the issue of whether defendant was speeding, that defendant was not prejudiced, and that the magistrate court properly denied defendant's motion for a mistrial.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's conviction for speeding.

 

572 of 598 DOCUMENTS


State v. Barroso


Opinion No. 2357


COURT OF APPEALS OF SOUTH CAROLINA


320 S.C. 1; 462 S.E.2d 862; 1995 S.C. App. LEXIS 73


March 10, 1995, Heard  
June 12, 1995, Filed


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied October 25, 1995.


PRIOR HISTORY: Appeal From Darlington County. John H. Waller, Jr., Circuit Court Judge.



DISPOSITION: AFFIRMED IN PART AND REVERSED IN PART


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Seven defendants sought review of a judgment rendered by the Circuit Court for Darlington County (South Carolina), which convicted them of trafficking in more than 400 grams of cocaine, in violation of S.C. Code Ann. § 44-53-370(e)(2)(e) (Supp. 1993).


OVERVIEW: In addition to double jeopardy, each defendant challenged various issues, including: sufficiency of evidence, admission of evidence of other drug-related bad acts, refusal to grant a mistrial despite the jury's exposure to hearsay evidence, admission of improper impeachment testimony, improper jury charge, and refusal to allow presentation of constitutional claims after the verdict. They also argued that the cocaine trafficking cocaine statute violates the Equal Protection Clause, and denied them the opportunity to participate in supervised furlough. The court upheld all of the convictions, except for one, holding that the State failed to present sufficient evidence to show transactions that constituted trafficking or participation in the conspiracy as to that defendant. As to the remaining defendants, the court stated that the evidence was sufficient to find them guilty and the State did not violate their rights to a fair trial or subject them to double jeopardy. The court also held that evidence of marijuana dealing, although a prior bad act, was admissible to show identity and motive. The constitutional attacks on the cocaine trafficking statute were without merit.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed in part, holding that all of the defendants, except for one, was properly convicted of trafficking in more than 400 grams of cocaine. The court reversed in part, holding that one of the defendants' convictions was reversed due to lack of evidence.

 

573 of 598 DOCUMENTS


City of Columbia v. Brown


Opinion No. 2240


COURT OF APPEALS OF SOUTH CAROLINA


316 S.C. 432; 450 S.E.2d 117; 1994 S.C. App. LEXIS 140


September 7, 1994, Heard  
October 10, 1994, Filed


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied November 22, 1994.


PRIOR HISTORY: Appeal From Richland County. Joseph A. Wilson, II, Circuit Court Judge



DISPOSITION: AFFIRMED


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of a judgment from the Circuit Court, Richland County (South Carolina), which affirmed his conviction by a municipal court for violating a city ordinance against loitering.


OVERVIEW: Defendant overheard three police officers talking and confronted them. The officers testified that he used vile and vulgar language and made racial slurs. The officers asked him to leave the area, but he refused. He continued his verbal assault after the officers informed him that if he refused to leave, he would be arrested. Defendant was convicted of violating Columbia, S.C. Ordinance § 2-2039, which prohibited loitering and his conviction was affirmed by the circuit court. On further appeal, the court affirmed. The court held that the ordinance did not violate defendant's constitutional right to freedom of speech. He was arrested while shouting obscenities and racial streets on a public street. He was arrested not merely for his words, but for his behavior. Defendant's behavior met the requirement of "fighting words" and the officers clearly exercised a higher degree of restraint than was expected from the average citizen. Defendant knowingly waived his right to counsel at trial and the circuit court was not required to make a second specific inquiry to determine whether he made his decision to continue proceeding pro se was knowing and intelligent.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's conviction.

 

574 of 598 DOCUMENTS


T.W. Morton Builders v. Von Buedingen


Opinion No. 2235


COURT OF APPEALS OF SOUTH CAROLINA


316 S.C. 388; 450 S.E.2d 87; 1994 S.C. App. LEXIS 135


February 8, 1994, Heard  
September 30, 1994, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal from Aiken County. Kelly F. Zier, Special Master



DISPOSITION: AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART AND REMANDED.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Both parties appealed from the judgment of an Aiken County, South Carolina court, which held in favor of plaintiff contractor in a case involving defendant customers' failure to pay in full for renovations to their home.


OVERVIEW: A contractor brought a foreclosure action against customers for their alleged failure to pay in full for renovations to their home. The customers counterclaimed for, among other things, breach of contract and unfair trade practices. On appeal, the court affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded. The court affirmed the judgments against the customers. The findings of a cost plus contract and the customers' liability for extra costs, changes, and deficiencies were supported by sufficient evidence. There was no evidence to support their unfair trade practices claim. With respect to the contractor, the court affirmed the denial of prejudgment interest. The contractor failed to meet its burden of establishing a stated account and the parties' agreement, express or implied, that the account was a true statement due at a specific point. However, the court reversed the denial of attorney fees. The court held that, in order to protect the private interest of contractors who dealt directly with an owner, "may," as used in S.C. Code Ann. § 29-5-10, should have been interpreted to mean that costs, including a reasonable attorney's fee, were secured by the mechanic's lien.


OUTCOME: The judgment below was affirmed as to the judgment against the customers and the denial of prejudgment interest to the contractor, reversed as to the denial of attorney fees to the contractor, and remanded.

 

575 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Petersen v. City of Clemson


Opinion No. 2104


COURT OF APPEALS OF SOUTH CAROLINA


312 S.C. 162; 439 S.E.2d 317; 1993 S.C. App. LEXIS 195


November 3, 1993, Heard  
December 13, 1993, Filed


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Denied January 19, 1994.


PRIOR HISTORY: Appeal From Pickens County. R. Murray Hughes, Special Referee



DISPOSITION: AFFIRMED


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant property owners sought review of the decision of the special referee, which found in favor of respondent city in an action for a declaration that the zoning ordinance was invalid and that the rezoning was invalid. The matter had been referred to the special referee by the Pickens County Circuit Court (South Carolina).


OVERVIEW: The property owners challenged the zoning ordinance which rezoned a tract of land adjacent to their properties from residential to Planned Development Mixed-Use (PD). The property owners argued that the city rezoned the properties in an arbitrary and capricious manner without proper notice and without a public hearing. The court concluded that: (1) there was ample evidence to support the finding of the special referee that the city council met the requirement that a public hearing be held by setting the date and time for that hearing before the Planning Commission; (2) although no written report was prepared, the minutes of the Planning Commission meeting contained extensive consideration of the factors listed in City of Clemson, S.C., Zoning Ordinance § 1003; (3) there was evidence to support the referee's conclusions that the zoning ordinance did not create a means to evade traditional zoning classifications, and that the rezoning was in compliance with the land use plan; and (4) it was not the role of the courts to substitute their judgment for that of local legislative bodies, which were better qualified to act on local zoning matters.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed in the zoning dispute.

 

576 of 598 DOCUMENTS


State v. Austin


No. 1706


Court of Appeals of South Carolina


306 S.C. 9; 409 S.E.2d 811; 1991 S.C. App. LEXIS 132


September 10, 1991, Heard  
October 7, 1991, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal From Cherokee County; E. C. Burnett, III, Judge.



DISPOSITION: REMANDED


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed the judgment of the Cherokee County Court (South Carolina), which convicted him of possession with intent to distribute marijuana.


OVERVIEW: The police received information from an informant that defendant had marijuana. The police obtained a search warrant and searched defendant's cousins' house. The police found marijuana. At trial, defendant objected to the introduction of the marijuana into evidence because the search warrant was defective. The trial judge ruled that the warrant was defective, but that the evidence was admissible under the good faith exception. Defendant was convicted of possession with intent to distribute marijuana. Defendant appealed. The court found that the trial judge correctly ruled that the warrant was defective because the affidavit did not contain information sufficient for the issuing magistrate to make a determination of probable cause. The court held that the good faith exception did not apply because there was no objective basis for concluding that the officer acted in reasonable reliance on the warrant, believing it to be valid. The officer testified that he knew the affidavit was supposed to contain information concerning the reliability of the informant, and he had no explanation for not having included the information. The court remanded for a determination of the standing issue.


OUTCOME: The court remanded the case for a determination of whether defendant had standing to contest the search of his cousins' home.

 

577 of 598 DOCUMENTS


White v. Wilbanks


No. 1327


Court of Appeals of South Carolina


298 S.C. 225; 379 S.E.2d 298; 1989 S.C. App. LEXIS 59


March 20, 1989, Heard  
April 24, 1989, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal From Spartanburg County, Dan F. Laney, Jr., Judge.



DISPOSITION: Reversed and remanded.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant, a putative executor of a will, sought review of a judgment of the Probate Court for Spartanburg (South Carolina), which ruled in favor of respondents, a putative executor of a will and relatives of the decedent, that the destruction of a 1982 will did not revive a prior will and that the decedent's estate passed by intestate succession.


OVERVIEW: Appellant was named executor under a 1980 will. Respondent was named executrix under a will allegedly executed in 1982. The original of the 1982 will was never presented to the probate court. The probate court ruled that the 1980 will was properly executed and the 1982 will had also been properly executed, but, because the original was never located, it was presumed destroyed animo revocandi. The probate court also held that the presumed destruction of the 1982 will did not revive the 1980 will because the evidence did not show that the decedent intended to revive the will. Appellant sought review and the court reversed and remanded for a new trial. The court found that the probate court erred in applying the 1987 Probate Code to the trial of the case. Because the decedent could have intentionally destroyed the 1982 will knowing that the law as it then existed would have revived the 1980 will, the presumption under S.C. Code Ann. § 62-2-508 (1987) would have frustrated the intent of the decedent. The court also found that the appellant, having made no objection, request for a curative instruction, or motion for a mistrial, could not complain of some of the probate court's remarks.


OUTCOME: The court reversed and remanded for a new trial.

 

578 of 598 DOCUMENTS


National Health Corp. v. South Carolina Dep't of Health & Environmental Control


No. 1326


Court of Appeals of South Carolina


298 S.C. 373; 380 S.E.2d 841; 1989 S.C. App. LEXIS 75


January 19, 1989, Heard  
April 24, 1989, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal From Richland County, Tom J. Ervin, Judge.



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff health corporation brought an action seeking review of a final administrative decision of defendant, the South Carolina Department of Health and Environmental Control. The Department denied the health corporation's application for a certificate of need (CON) to build a long-term care nursing facility and granted a CON to defendant health care center. A circuit court Richland County (South Carolina) affirmed and plaintiff appealed.


OVERVIEW: The circuit court addressed each of plaintiff's arguments and issued an order affirming the Department's decision. Plaintiff's appeal raised the identical issues as raised in the trial court. On appeal, the court found that the judgment of the agency (the Department) was reasonable and proper. The record contained more than sufficient evidence to support the conclusions of the administrative review board. Further, it was clear from the board's order read as a whole that the board fully exercised its authority to weigh the evidence, and make a decision on the merits based upon the preponderance of evidence. Review of the hearing officer's report and recommendations and the transcript of record left no doubt that all of the issues raised by plaintiff were thoroughly addressed throughout the administrative process. The board's findings, with regard to inconsistency with the funding plans of the state Medicaid agency and failure to demonstrate financial feasibility, were supported by the record. The record also contained abundant evidence that the health care center's project was superior to that of plaintiff's.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the decision of the Department denying plaintiff's application for a CON.

 

579 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Glenn v. School Dist.


No. 1102


Court of Appeals of South Carolina


294 S.C. 530; 366 S.E.2d 47; 1988 S.C. App. LEXIS 10


January 25, 1988, Heard  
February 29, 1988, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal From Anderson County, Ellis B. Drew, Jr., Master-In-Equity.



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant property owner sought review of a decision by the trial court (South Carolina), which affirmed the master's grant of summary judgment in favor of respondents, a school district and a county, in the property owner's action to recover for damages to his property.


OVERVIEW: The property owner's parcel of land was located behind the school district's property. The property owner's land formed the low point for the flow of surface water from the school district's property. The school district constructed a school on its property and built a drainage system to drain surface water away from its property. The property owner's land eroded and made it unsuitable for the planned development of the property. On appeal, the court stated that the property owner's complaint fell under the two exceptions to the Common Enemy Rule. The two exceptions were: that a landowner could not use his land in a manner to create a nuisance and that he could not discharge water in a concentrated form upon his neighbor's land. The court determined that the property owner's complaint was barred by the statute of limitations because his damages resulted from an incident that occurred more than six years prior to the date in which he filed his action. The court also determined that there was no indication in the court papers to indicate that the problem with the ditch could be abated.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's grant of summary judgment in favor of the school district and the county.

 

580 of 598 DOCUMENTS


South Carolina Dep't of Social Services v. Father


No. 1100


Court of Appeals of South Carolina


294 S.C. 518; 366 S.E.2d 40; 1988 S.C. App. LEXIS 23


December 9, 1987, Heard  
February 29, 1988, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal from Greenville County, Willie T. Smith, Jr., Family Court Judge.



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant mother and father challenged the judgment of the Greenville County Family Court (South Carolina), which found that they abused and neglected their child based upon a petition of appellee department of social services.


OVERVIEW: The father beat the child with a belt after she failed to obey him leaving extensive bruising. He also hit the girl in her face. The bruising was reported to the department. The father argued that his conduct did not amount to child abuse under S.C. Code § 20-7-490 (1976). In the alternative, the father argued that the statute was unconstitutional because, he claimed, the basis of the child's punishment, was his religious belief. The mother argued she was not guilty of neglect based upon the father's actions. The court found that, excluded from the definition of child abuse was corporal punishment that met certain guidelines, listed in § 20-7-490(C)(1)(e). A doctor testified at the abuse hearing that a great deal of force was required to inflict the bruises on the child. The court found that the force used by the father was not reasonable. The court also found that § 20-7-490 was not unconstitutional because it did not, as the father argued, impinge upon the father's right to free exercise of religion. An argument that the father's privacy was violated was not reviewed because it was not raised before the trial court.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the findings of abuse and neglect.

 

581 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Fairfield Ocean Ridge, Inc. v. Edisto Beach


No. 1087


Court of Appeals of South Carolina


294 S.C. 475; 366 S.E.2d 15; 1988 S.C. App. LEXIS 14


December 14, 1987, Heard  
February 8, 1988, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal From Colleton County, Hubert E. Long, Judge.



DISPOSITION: Reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant Town of Edisto Beach, South Carolina, challenged an order of the Circuit Court of Colleton County (South Carolina), which reversed a decision of the Town's Zoning Board of Adjustment. The trial court held that plaintiff landowner was not using its property in a manner prohibited by the Town's ordinance, and that its use constituted a preexisting, non-conforming use permitted by the ordinance.


OVERVIEW: The largest of the landowner's tracts was zoned as a planned unit development (PUD) and was the principal location of the development. The property involved in the appeal was a smaller parcel, referred to as the "Cabana" property. The Town alleged that the landowner was using the Cabana property for commercial activities that violated a zoning ordinance because the parcel was located in an R-1 district. The town claimed that the trial court applied the wrong standard in reviewing the Zoning Board's decision. In reversing, the court held that, under S.C. Code Ann. § 6-7-780, the trial court was required to affirm the factual findings of the Board if there was any evidence to support them, and the findings were not influenced by an error of law. Further, § 6-7-780 did not violate due process because the right to appellate review was not a necessary element of due process. The court opined that it was undisputed that the Cabana Property was in an R-1 zone, and that the prohibited commercial activities that the Town complained about were not taking place when the zoning ordinance was adopted. Thus, in the court's view, there was no prior non-conforming use.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the trial court.

 

582 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Bocook Outdoor Media, Inc. v. Summey Outdoor Advertising, Inc.


No. 1060


Court of Appeals of South Carolina


294 S.C. 169; 363 S.E.2d 390; 1987 S.C. App. LEXIS 430


October 19, 1987, Heard  
December 7, 1987, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal From Anderson County, Thomas J. Ervin, Judge.



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In an action in which both parties alleged interference with contractual relations and violation of the South Carolina Unfair Trade Practices Act (SCUTPA), plaintiff and defendant, competitors in the outdoor advertising business, appealed various aspects of the judgment entered by the Anderson County, South Carolina, trial court following a jury verdict for plaintiff on its claim and for defendant on its counterclaim of violation of SCUTPA.


OVERVIEW: The court affirmed and found no exemption for the outdoor advertising industry from SCUPTA where neither the Highway Advertising Control Act nor the regulations under it addressed unfair competition among outdoor advertisers. There was no error in the admission of expert testimony that industry customs did not condone the practice of one outdoor advertiser contacting landowners who had previously leased a site to another advertiser in an effort to obtain the lease on the location. Testimony by plaintiff's president that landowners contacted him about increased rents, in which he was attempting to show he had to pay more rent in order to keep his leases due to defendant's actions, was not hearsay. The issue of whether particular practices engaged in by the parties constituted improper interference and the issue of alleged unfair competition were matters for the jury to decide. The trial court did not err in denying defendant's motion for new trial nisi additur or in resubmitting the unfair trade practices matter to the jury for clarification after the jury found that plaintiff had violated the Unfair Trade Practices Act but awarded no damages.


OUTCOME: The judgment in favor of each party on its SCUPTA claim was affirmed.

 

583 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Oyler v. Oyler


No. 0977


Court of Appeals of South Carolina


293 S.C. 4; 358 S.E.2d 170; 1987 S.C. App. LEXIS 336


May 18, 1987, Heard  
June 22, 1987, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal from Richland County, Berry L. Mobley, Family Court Judge.



DISPOSITION: Reversed and remanded.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant former wife appealed from an order of the Family Court of Richland County (South Carolina) in plaintiff former husband's action for divorce, which barred her from alimony under S.C. Code Ann. § 20-3-130 (1976) because she had admitted engaging in post-separation adultery.


OVERVIEW: The husband sought a divorce on the ground of one year's continuous separation, and the wife counterclaimed for support for herself and the parties' children. The husband replied to the counterclaim with a general denial that he should be required to pay support to the wife. At a hearing on issues of equitable distribution and support, over the wife's objection that adultery had not been pled, the trial court concluded that the husband's general denial of the wife's request for support was sufficient to support the introduction of evidence on the wife's adultery and allowed the husband's attorney to cross-examine the wife regarding her adulterous relationships after the separation. The trial court then held that § 20-3-130 (1976) barred the wife from recovering alimony. The court reversed. Insofar as the husband's adultery claim went beyond the wife's basic claim for support and depended on additional facts to defeat the support claim, it was an avoidance that introduced new matter and had to be pled pursuant to S.C. R. Civ. P. 8(c). Since it was not pled, the evidence relating to adultery was inadmissible, and the wife was not barred form receiving alimony.


OUTCOME: The order was reversed and the case was remanded.

 

584 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Wilson v. Wilson


No. 0955


Court of Appeals of South Carolina


292 S.C. 362; 356 S.E.2d 422; 1987 S.C. App. LEXIS 312


March 23, 1987, Heard  
May 11, 1987, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal from Dillon County, Ernest A. Finney, Jr., Judge.



DISPOSITION: Affirmed as modified.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant wife and respondent son appealed from the trial court, Dillon County (South Carolina), which found that the wife was entitled to admeasurement of dower, referred the matter to a special referee, made new findings, and awarded the wife a certain sum for admeasurement of dower.


OVERVIEW: During the wife's marriage to the husband, the husband deeded the marital property to the son. A fire partially destroyed the house and insurance proceeds were paid into court. The court concluded that the trial court incorrectly subtracted her insurance recovery from her dower interest. The wife had no property interest to insure, and therefore what was insured was only her expectancy of dower in the property. The trial court did not err in declining to apply the law of quarantine. The doctrine of quarantine did not apply because the wife did not have an interest in the house after her husband died. Therefore, her dower interest could be offset against by amounts awarded to the son. The wife's right to receive interest on her dower award accrued only from the date she vacated the property after the fire. The wife was not entitled to interest on her award because she had not been deprived of her right to dower in the property. The wife was entitled to reimbursement for repairs on the property as she did not have an interest in the property. The son was entitled to $ 350 per month rent on the property while the wife lived on the property.


OUTCOME: The court modified the award, but otherwise affirmed the judgment.

 

585 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Hampton v. Richland County


No. 0785


Court of Appeals of South Carolina


292 S.C. 500; 357 S.E.2d 463; 1987 S.C. App. LEXIS 298


December 16, 1986  
April 13, 1987, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Reheard December 16, 1986.


PRIOR HISTORY: Appeal from Richland County, Owens T. Cobb, Jr., Judge.



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant landowners sought review from a judgment of the Circuit Court of Richland County (South Carolina), which refused to require respondent county council to rezone certain property. Appellants brought the action in mandamus to compel the rezoning of the property. The dispositive issue was whether the county council's action in rezoning the property was arbitrary, unreasonable, and capricious.


OVERVIEW: The lower court consolidated two actions challenging the rezoning of certain land. The lower court later dismissed both actions, holding that the county council acted reasonably and within its sound discretion in rezoning the subject property. On appeal, the court held that the action of the county council in declining to change the zoning classification of the property from D-1 to C-3 and in changing the zoning classification of the property to C-1 was not patently unreasonable. It was not unreasonable to refuse to zone it as commercial property because the property was not surrounded by commercial property. The property abutted commercial and residential property. The court found that regardless of whether the county council's act of rezoning the subject tract was a legislative function or a quasi-judicial function, the court found that there was substantial evidence that the land in question was susceptible to a reasonable and lawful use under the classification imposed.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the lower court's decision refusing to require the county council to rezone the property at issue.

 

586 of 598 DOCUMENTS


McGann v. Mungo


No. 0626


Court of Appeals of South Carolina


287 S.C. 561; 340 S.E.2d 154; 1986 S.C. App. LEXIS 278


December 9, 1985, Heard  
February 3, 1986, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal from Lexington County, WAlter J. Bristow, Jr., Judge.



DISPOSITION: Affirmed in part and reversed in part.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants, property developers, government agencies and officials, and related persons (developers), appealed the decision from a trial court in Lexington County (South Carolina), which denied the developers' demurrers to the amended complaint by plaintiffs, a class of property residents and owners (residents), in their suit for an alleged unconstitutional taking, negligent construction, and a breach of an implied warranty.


OVERVIEW: The owners alleged that they suffered damage from a development project. The developers argued that the class should not have been certified, that there was improper joinder, and that the pleadings were insufficient. On appeal, the court agreed with the trial court in part. Since the date of the trial court's order, a new rule on joinder, S.C. R. Civ. P. 18(a), went into effect. The rule was applied, and there was no longer a requirement that all causes of action affect all parties. The class was proper. The new rule on class actions, S.C. R. Civ. P. 23, allowed for more liberality in defining classes. There was no improper joinder of parties plaintiff under the new rule, that of S.C. R. Civ. P. 20(a). The fact that the class had a fluid membership did not render it indefinable. The failure of the developers to make positive improvements did not constitute a taking. Certain objections to the suit were raised for the first time on appeal and waived. A cause of action existed for an implied warranty of fitness of improved land. However, there had to be a sale, and the owners did not sufficiently allege facts alleging sales. The owners could obtain injunction relief.


OUTCOME: The judgment of the trial court was reversed in part and affirmed in part. The trial court incorrectly failed to dismiss the claim for an unconstitutional taking and the claim for a breach of an implied warranty of fitness. The trial court ruled properly in all other respects.

 

587 of 598 DOCUMENTS


State v. Boyd


No. 0619


Court of Appeals of South Carolina


288 S.C. 206; 341 S.E.2d 144; 1986 S.C. App. LEXIS 292


October 22, 1985, Heard  
January 27, 1986, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal from Abbeville County E. C. Burnett, III, Judge



DISPOSITION: Affirmed in part; reversed in part and remanded.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed his conviction and sentencing by the trial court for Abbeville County (South Carolina) for possession of marijuana with intent to distribute. Defendant was sentenced as a third offender under the Controlled Substance Act based on two prior convictions arising from a single incident.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was stopped and arrested for driving under the influence. In the process of moving defendant's van, police performed an inventory search and discovered a large amount of marijuana, which led to defendant's conviction for possession of marijuana with intent to distribute. On appeal, the court affirmed the conviction, but reversed and remanded for resentencing. The trial court did not abuse its discretion in refusing to sequester witnesses whose testimony was related. The inventory search of the van did not violate defendant's constitutional rights. However, the trial court erred in sentencing defendant as a third offender. Because defendant's prior conviction of two counts under the Controlled Substance Act arose out of acts committed in the course of a single incident, they counted as one for the purpose of the sentence below.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's conviction of defendant, but reversed and remanded for sentencing as a second offender.

 

588 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Timms v. Timms


No. 0522


Court of Appeals of South Carolina


286 S.C. 291; 333 S.E.2d 74; 1985 S.C. App. LEXIS 420


May 23, 1985, Heard  
July 9, 1985, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal From Lexington County, George Bell Timmerman, Jr., Judge



DISPOSITION: Reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent father, as administrator of his son's estate, brought an action against appellant mother for the wrongful death of their 14-year-old son. The mother appealed a judgment entered against her in a Lexington County trial court (South Carolina), arguing that the suit was barred by the doctrine of parental immunity. Her motions for nonsuit, directed verdict, and judgment n.o.v., all based on the defense of parental immunity, were denied.


OVERVIEW: The family was traveling in their vehicle when the mother lost control of the vehicle, resulting in the son's fatal injuries. The mother's various motions at trial had been denied on the ground that at the time of the collision, the doctrine of parental immunity had been abolished in automobile accident cases. The mother argued that she was entitled to the defense of parental immunity because the doctrine had not been effectively abolished at the time the cause of action arose. The father conceded that the case law following the partial abrogation of the doctrine of parental immunity by the South Carolina Legislature supported the mother's position; however, he argued that an exception should have been made to allow the suit where insurance was available to satisfy any damages awarded. The court declined to carve out such an exception and overturned the decision below. The court first noted that the father had failed to raise preserve the issue for appeal. Second, the court could not look beyond the record on appeal in order to verify the insurance coverage. Finally, the court opined that if such an exception was to be made, the state supreme court should make it.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the trial court.

 

589 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Wagner v. Wagner


No. 0457


Court of Appeals of South Carolina


285 S.C. 430; 329 S.E.2d 788; 1985 S.C. App. LEXIS 358


February 27, 1985, Heard  
May 1, 1985, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal from Newberry County, Walter T. Lake, Family Court Judge



DISPOSITION: Reversed in part and remanded.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In an action by respondents, a mother and a son, against appellant father for support and maintenance for college expenses of the 18-year-old son, the father challenged the order of a Newberry County trial court (South Carolina), which required him to pay a monthly amount as support toward the education of the son.


OVERVIEW: The mother and the son filed an action against the father for support and maintenance for college expenses of the son, who was 18 years old at the time and planned to attend college. The trial court ordered the father to pay a monthly sum as support toward the education of the son. On appeal, the court reversed and remanded. The trial court erred in awarding attorney's fees without making findings of fact, so the trial court was ordered to determine appropriate attorney's fees on remand. The court found that the trial court properly considered four facts in determining whether support should have been ordered. However, two other considerations were to be taken into account when ordering support for an emancipated child to attend college: (1) the availability of grants and loans; and (2) the ability of the child to earn income during the school year or on vacation. The trial court was required, therefore, to make findings of fact as to the two additional factors.


OUTCOME: The court reversed and remanded a part of the order for the purpose of determining appropriate attorney's fees and for consideration of two additional factors in determining whether support should have been ordered.

 

590 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Moore v. Columbia


No. 0375


Court of Appeals of South Carolina


284 S.C. 278; 326 S.E.2d 157; 1985 S.C. App. LEXIS 277


October 22, 1984, Heard  
January 28, 1985, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal From Richland County, Kenneth M. Powell, Special Circuit Judge



DISPOSITION: Affirmed in part and reversed in part.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant administratrix sought review of the decision by the Richland County Circuit Court (South Carolina), which sustained the demurrers brought by respondent city to the administratrix's wrongful death and survivorship actions against the city.


OVERVIEW: The administratrix alleged that the city violated 42 U.S.C.S. §§ 1983, 1985 when its police officers shot and killed her son as he fled apprehension. On appeal, the court affirmed in part and reversed in part. The court reversed the decision as to the claims under 42 U.S.C.S. § 1983. The court found that the complaints that alleged a violation of § 1983 stated a cause of action. The court reasoned that there was no question that the administratrix alleged deprivation of her son's constitutionally protected right to due process of law prior to the taking of his life. The court further found that, though poorly drafted, the complaints sufficiently alleged § 1983 actions in that they alleged that the city's twelve-month persistent practice of unreasonably failing to disseminate the executive order to many of its policemen constituted tacit authorization of or deliberate indifference to the officers' use of lethal force to apprehend a person posing no threat to the officer's safety and amounted to a custom or policy of the city.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed in part the decision as to the claims under 42 U.S.C.S. § 1985 and reversed in part the decision as to the claims under 42 U.S.C.S. § 1983, and remanded.

 

591 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Brooks v. Winecoff


No. 0343


Court of Appeals of South Carolina


284 S.C. 58; 324 S.E.2d 339; 1984 S.C. App. LEXIS 629


October 22, 1984, Heard  
December 19, 1984, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal from Chester County, George F. Coleman, Judge



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant, the administrator of his daughter's estate, challenged a grant of summary judgment by a Chester County trial court (South Carolina) in favor of respondents, the administrators of the estate of the daughter's mother, in appellant's consolidated survival and wrongful death actions. The mother and daughter were killed in an automobile accident.


OVERVIEW: At issue was whether the doctrine of parental immunity existed so as to bar suit by the daughter's estate against the mother's estate for damages resulting from the accident. Appellant maintained that the actions were not barred because S.C. Code § 15-5-210 (1976) was in existence at the time the daughter received her fatal injuries in the crash. In affirming, the court noted that § 15-5-210 had been held unconstitutional. Thus, on the date the actions were begun, the statute no longer precluded a parent from asserting the doctrine of parental immunity as a defense to an action brought by his or her unemancipated child for personal injuries received by the child in a motor vehicle accident. Moreover, because the abrogation of the doctrine of parental immunity applied prospectively only and the doctrine could be interposed as a defense to a tort action brought by an unemancipated child based on an event occurring before the doctrine's abrogation, the court concluded that the doctrine clearly afforded the mother's estate a complete defense to the tort actions brought by the daughter's estate, as they were based on an event that happened prior to the doctrine's abrogation.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's judgment.

 

592 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Langley v. Boyter


No. 0325


Court of Appeals of South Carolina


284 S.C. 162; 325 S.E.2d 550; 1984 S.C. App. LEXIS 635


January 26, 1984, Heard  
November 29, 1984, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal From Richland County, C. Victor Pyle, Judge



DISPOSITION: Reversed and remanded.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant injured individual filed suit against respondents driver and his employer, alleging that her injuries were caused by the driver's negligent driving as an agent for the employer. The trial court charged the jury with contributory negligence and rendered judgment for the driver and the employer based on the verdict. The injured individual appealed, and the Supreme Court of South Carolina transferred the appeal to the court of appeals.


OVERVIEW: The injured individual excepted to the trial court's instruction of the jury regarding contributory negligence, and appealed as error the trial court's refusal to charge comparative negligence. The court traced the history of contributory negligence in South Carolina and concluded that it had been applied simply because it was never challenged. The court reviewed several statutes and concluded that there was no statutory basis for the general application of contributory negligence in South Carolina. The court reviewed the history of the comparative negligence doctrine and concluded that it had never been applied in South Carolina because the use of contributory negligence had not been challenged. The court determined that it had the implied authority from the state supreme court to abrogate contributory negligence. The court adopted a modified form of comparative negligence, holding that a plaintiff would be able to recover as long as his negligence was not greater than that of the defendant, and that the plaintiff's recovery would be reduced in proportion to the negligence. The court held that the doctrine would be applied prospectively.


OUTCOME: The court abrogated the doctrine of contributory negligence, adopted the doctrine of comparative negligence, reversed the trial court's judgment, and remanded for a new trial.

 

593 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Gale v. State Bd. of Medical Examiners


No. 0224


Court of Appeals of South Carolina


282 S.C. 474; 320 S.E.2d 35; 1984 S.C. App. LEXIS 515


June 1, 1984, Heard  
August 8, 1984, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal From Richland County, William J. McLeod, Special Circuit Judge.



DISPOSITION: Accordingly, the order of the circuit court is affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant doctor sought review of an order of the circuit court (South Carolina), which dismissed his petition for reversal or modification of the decision of respondent State Board of Medical Examiners of South Carolina (board) to revoke his license to practice medicine in the state of South Carolina.


OVERVIEW: The board initiated a complaint against the doctor, a practicing psychiatrist. The board's disciplinary panel found that the doctor had been convicted of eight counts of housebreaking and grand larceny, had written prescriptions for controlled substances outside a bona fide physician-patient relationship, repurchased them, and had engaged in conduct which was indicative of sociopathic and possibly psychopathic behavior. The panel recommended revocation of the doctor's license. The board adopted the recommendation. The trial court dismissed the doctor's petition for judicial review of the board's decision. The doctor appealed. The court held that the panel findings were supported by substantial evidence and there was no abuse of discretion in the imposition of license revocation as a sanction for the doctor's violations of the law and board regulations. The court rejected the doctor's argument that the circuit court erred in not reversing the revocation order on the ground that the finding that he suffered from a mental disorder lacked a substantial evidentiary basis. The panel specifically disclaimed this finding as necessary to its recommendation that his license be revoked.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the circuit court's order.

 

594 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Hibernian Soc. v. Thomas


No. 0219


Court of Appeals of South Carolina


282 S.C. 465; 319 S.E.2d 339; 1984 S.C. App. LEXIS 513


March 20, 1984, Heard  
July 16, 1984, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal From Charleston County, C. Anthony Harris, Judge.



DISPOSITION: Affirmed in part, reversed in part.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, a city and a county, sought review of a judgment from the trial court, Charleston County (South Carolina), which ruled that certain real property owned by respondent society qualified under S.C. Code Ann. § 12-37-220B(12) for an exemption from ad valorem taxation. The society appealed the trial court's failure to award any interest on the refund.


OVERVIEW: The society sought a refund of ad valorem taxes paid under protest. The court affirmed the ruling in favor of the society on tax exemption, finding that the society was a fraternal organization within the meaning of S.C. Code Ann. § 12-37-220B(12) because it was formed with the purpose of engaging in charitable work, its hall was used primarily for holding the society's meetings and the conduct of its business, and no profit or benefit from such business inured to the benefit of any individual society member. The court reversed the trial court's failure to award interest on the refund, finding that S.C. Code Ann. § 12-47-230 required a city or town to pay six percent interest from the date of payment on a refund of taxes paid under protest. The city argued that § 12-47-230 was unconstitutional as a denial of equal protection under S.C. Const. art. 1, § 3 because of the different treatment of cities and counties. The court determined that because there was no express authority in the South Carolina Constitution that allowed the city to challenge the validity of § 12-47-230, the city was required to pay interest on the society's tax refund.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's ruling on tax exemption. The court reversed the trial court's failure to award interest on the society's tax refund.

 

595 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Niemann v. Niemann


No. 0199


Court of Appeals of South Carolina


282 S.C. 127; 317 S.E.2d 472; 1984 S.C. App. LEXIS 492


April 24, 1984, Submitted  
June 11, 1984, Decided
