PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal from Berkeley County, L. Mendel Rivers, Jr., Family Court Judge



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant former husband challenged an order of the Family Court of Berkeley County (South Carolina) that granted a divorce to respondent former wife on the ground of continuous separation for one year pursuant to S.C. Code § 20-3-10(5).


OVERVIEW: The husband, who was a naval officer, was on involuntary sea duty for seven months of the one year period. He contended that including his period of military service in the 12 months needed for a no-fault divorce was contrary to public policy and a violation of the Equal Protection Clause of U.S. Const. amend. XIV. The court affirmed the order. When a spouse served in the military and the parties were separated before the military service began or when the separation was independent of military service, though during service, a divorce on the grounds of separation was proper. The parties' separation was independent of the husband's military service because the wife clearly manifested her intent to separate before the husband left for sea duty. Granting the divorce was not against public policy because a one-year separation was a ground for divorce under § 20-3-10(5), which was passed to implement a constitutional amendment favorably approved by referendum. The husband's equal protection rights were not violated because § 20-3-10(5) was presumed to be constitutional. Members of the military were protected by the rule that separation had to be independent of military duty.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order.

 

596 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Wardlaw v. Peck


No. 0182


Court of Appeals of South Carolina


282 S.C. 199; 318 S.E.2d 270; 1984 S.C. App. LEXIS 475


January 24, 1984, Heard  
May 25, 1984, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal From Greenwood County, Francis B. Nicholson, Judge.



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of an order of the Greenwood County Court (South Carolina), which entered judgment in favor of plaintiff student in her action for slander. Defendant contended that his statement, uttered at a school function, was not actionable because no one could interpret it as a literal charge of unchastity, and that S.C. Code Ann. § 15-75-10 (Law. Co-op. 1976) was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was angry with her because she did not pick him up at the airport, as she was supposed to do. He told the college chaplain he would deal with her in convocation. At that event, he made several offensive remarks about her, including a statement that he had a recurring nightmare that she and a male student were breeding under his sink. On appeal, the court affirmed the student's slander judgment. The court held that under modern rule, words were given their ordinary and popular meaning. Because the jury found the words were defamatory, the court refused to set aside their verdict. The court held that § 15-75-10, which made the false imputation of unchastity to a female actionable without proof of special damages, was constitutional because it applied to males in the same way. The court reviewed the historical context that gave rise to the statute and found that the statute was adopted solely to change a rule set down in a case that happened to involve an accusation of unchaste behavior by a female. There was no reason that the statute would not apply equally to males who were accused of unchastity, therefore the statute treated both sexes the same.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment entered in favor of the student in her action against defendant for slanderous remarks made during a convocation at her school.

 

597 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Oswald v. County of Aiken


No. 0146


Court of Appeals of South Carolina


281 S.C. 298; 315 S.E.2d 146; 1984 S.C. App. LEXIS 441



April 13, 1984 


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal From Aiken County, George F. Coleman, Judge.



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant county sought review of a decision of the Aiken County Court (South Carolina), which upheld a jury verdict in favor of appellee former deputy sheriff in an action seeking to recover payment for compensatory time accumulated prior to the deputy's resignation.


OVERVIEW: The deputy accumulated compensatory time due to being required to perform an extra-ordinary amount of overtime work. The deputy's job performance was rated excellent. The deputy resigned from the position and requested to be paid for the compensatory time. The county denied the request based on the passing of an "emergency ordinance," which prohibited such payments to terminating employees. Because no payment was forthcoming, the deputy filed suit to recover payment for the compensatory time. The county defended based on the ordinance. The deputy claimed that the county was estopped from denying payment. A jury returned a verdict in favor of the deputy. The court affirmed holding that, based on the facts, the county could be estopped from denying its established policy of paying for compensatory time. Payment for compensatory time by a county was not an ultra vires act and the county had the power to make such payments.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the verdict in favor of the deputy in the action seeking to recover payment for compensatory time accumulated prior to the deputy's resignation.

 

598 of 598 DOCUMENTS


Ex parte Dibble


No. 0024


Court of Appeals of South Carolina


279 S.C. 592; 310 S.E.2d 440; 1983 S.C. App. LEXIS 89



December 19, 1983 


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal From Richland County, John Hamilton Smith, Judge



DISPOSITION: Remanded.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, two attorneys appointed to represent a state penitentiary inmate in civil actions against the penitentiary, challenged an order of the Richland County Circuit Court (South Carolina) that refused to vacate the order appointing them to act as counsel for the inmate even though the inmate was not entitled to appointed counsel.


OVERVIEW: An inmate of a state penitentiary instituted several civil actions against that facility. The circuit court appointed two attorneys to represent in the inmate in those proceedings. The attorneys filed a motion seeking to be relieved of their appointment, contending that the circuit court deprived them of their constitutional rights under U.S. Const. amends. XIV and XV in requiring them to represent the inmate without compensation. The circuit court agreed that the inmate was not entitled to appointed counsel; despite this finding, however, the circuit court refused to vacate the order of appointment. The attorneys appealed. In remanding for reconsideration, the court concluded that courts had the power to do all things reasonably necessary to ensure that just results were reached, and this included the power to appoint lawyers to serve without compensation where justice so required. Before such appointment would be proper, however, the appointing court must determine that the case is extraordinary and requires the appointment of counsel in order to render justice and that the litigant is unable to secure a lawyer on his own.


OUTCOME: The matter was remanded to the circuit court for a further review of its order of appointment.
